‚ÄúGen Z wants purpose.‚Äù ‚ÄúBoomers don‚Äôt like change.‚Äù I have heard all these generational labels in the work context‚Äîeven from leaders. In my opinion labels are an expression of lazy leadership! Here‚Äôs why.Some young people are driven by purpose. Others are seeking security and stability. The same goes for older employees, too. Some older employees resist change. Others drive it. The same is true for young people, too.People are individuals. Not walking age groups. It is not the year you were born that defines you, but who you are and what is important to you. The real problem isn‚Äôt the difference between generations that data suggests‚Äîit‚Äôs our assumptions about differences.When we rely on assumptions and labels, we practice lazy leadership‚Äîand miss out on who people really are, what their strengths are and what they value. True leadership is not about reading research on people in the workplace, telling people what to do, wearing suits or flying first class. True leadership begins with active listening! Only when I listen actively, can I support people in their development, trust, empower, or inspire them.What experiences have you had with generational labels in the workplace?

üéâ 30 Years of Deutsche Telekom! üéâ500 guests, classical and modern music, sports, politics, two grand pianos (in Bonn and Hamburg) coming together for a piece of music, and an elephant. Yesterday, we kicked off the celebrations for the 30th anniversary of Telekom with a festive event. We celebrated ourselves, and we were also celebrated a little: 200,000 Telekom employees worldwide.Who would have thought that the authority called Telekom would once become a modern company? Growing from 37 million to over 300 million customers worldwide? Increasing revenue from 34 billion to 116 billion euros? And rising from number six to the most valuable telecom company in Europe?Our journey has been one of transformation and design. It has been about decision-making and action. But above all, it has been about people. Like Ron Sommer, who visionary opened up new markets. Or Kai-Uwe Ricke, who took Telekom out of debt and made new investments possible. Or my friend Ren√© Obermann, who, like no one else, put our customers at the center of our operations. Most importantly, it has been the many Telekom employees who are with us today or who once were. Those who never gave up. Those who continually reinvented themselves and our company, even in the face of headwinds. Change has also left wounds. That is part of our history.Birthdays certainly evoke nostalgia and reflection. But not reflection that keeps us stagnant. Instead, reflection that serves as motivation. We, too, must reinvent Telekom every day. AI represents a significant revolution. If we use it wisely, we will become even more efficient, customer-oriented, and faster. Hopefully: unbeatable.My highlight yesterday was the unveiling of the "Gran elephant dret" by Miquel Barcel√≥. It symbolically represents what Telekom stands for: It is no longer "gray and sluggish." Instead, it is colorful and agile, curious and playful. The elephant that now stands in front of the Telekom headquarters should remind us to "Think again!" It embodies the power of change and the courage to continually reinvent the future. Those who understand the art of making the impossible possible can also achieve remarkable feats.Thank you to our guests, the Beethoven Orchestra with Dirk Kaftan, Walter Smerling from the Kunst und Kultur Foundation, Mayor Katja D√∂rner, Prime Minister (NRW) Hendrik W√ºst, Digital Minister Karsten Wildberger, Minister Nathanael Liminski, Philipp Schindera , and everyone who contributed to the success of our festive event.The "T" in the Deutsche Telekom logo will also continue to stand for transformation and technology, but also for trust and teamwork. And recently also for T√∂rr√∂√∂√∂!hashtag#DeutscheTelekom hashtag#30Years hashtag#Innovation hashtag#Transformation hashtag#ConnectingYourWorld

üéâ 30 Jahre Deutsche Telekom! üéâ500 G√§ste, klassische und moderne Musik, Sport, Politik, zwei Fl√ºgel (in Bonn und Hamburg), die sich zu einem St√ºck vereinen und ein Elefant. Gestern haben wir bei einem Festakt die Feiern zum 30-j√§hrigen Bestehen der Telekom er√∂ffnet. Wir haben uns gefeiert. Und ein wenig wurden auch wir gefeiert: 200.000 Telekomerinnen und Telekomer weltweit.Wer h√§tte gedacht, dass aus der Beh√∂rde Telekom einmal ein modernes Unternehmen werden w√ºrde? Auch bei Gegenwind. Wandel hat auch Wunden geschlagen. Auch das geh√∂rt zu unserer Geschichte. Geburtstage sind sicher Nostalgie. R√ºckblick. Aber kein R√ºckblick im Verharren. Sondern R√ºckblick als Ansporn. Auch wir heute m√ºssen die Telekom t√§glich neu erfinden. KI bedeutet eine gro√üe Revolution. Er steht sinnbildlich f√ºr das, was die Telekom ausmacht: Sie ist nicht mehr ‚Äûgrau und beh√§big‚Äú. Sondern bunt und agil, neugierig und spielerisch. Der Elefant, der nun vor der Telekom-Zentrale steht, soll uns ‚ÄûDenk mal!‚Äú sein. F√ºr die Kraft des Wandels und den Mut, die Zukunft jedes Mal neu zu erfinden. What an honor to be in Cleveland, Ohio, celebrating 40 years of partnership with Case Western Reserve University, a collaboration that began just two years after MRI technology became available. It‚Äôs great reconnecting with renowned experts and colleagues to reflect on how far we‚Äôve come since installing our first clinical system there. When we first started working together, many of the applications we rely on today were still on the horizon. Scans were slow, the experience for patients was often uncomfortable, and image quality was a far cry from what we expect now. Together, we were motivated by the possibilities to shape this field and so, we started pushing boundaries early on. For example, our work on real-time MRI in the 80s helped lay the groundwork for what we now know as minimally invasive, image-guided procedures. These helped make interventions safer and patient recovery times shorter. Then, thanks to various breakthroughs in the following decades, 3D imaging became reality, scans got faster and more precise, and images became clearer and more detailed. Because of contributions from partnerships like ours, MRI turned into what we know today: a quicker, more comfortable experience for patients, and a powerful and versatile tool for providers to screen, diagnose, and treat with confidence. It‚Äôs been an exciting journey of transforming ùêõùê®ùê•ùêù ideas into solutions used around the world. In many ways, we‚Äôre just getting started. We‚Äôre already exploring what‚Äôs next in precision imaging, AI-driven workflows, and scaling innovations across entire fleets of scanners.A heartfelt congratulations to the team of experts at Case Western and Siemens Healthineers who have made these 40 years so meaningful. Your camaraderie, curiosity, and brilliance are behind every breakthrough and the reasons this partnership continues to move forward and deliver real impact for patients and communities. Thank you, Eric Kaler, Cliff Megerian, Mark Griswold, Jeffrey Sunshine Donna Plecha, Andreas Schneck Tobi Kober, Kera Westphal David Grodzki, Murat Gungor, Katie Grant, Steve Cauley Chad Rittle, Marc  A. Quinn, Kecheng Liu, Kinpritma Sangha, Jinnan Wang ... your teams, and so many more!

Whilst Europe‚Äôs leaders gather in Rome to discuss how to support Ukraine‚Äôs reconstruction and resilience, Russia launched its most severe drone attack since the full-scale invasion began.For more than three years, Ukraine‚Äôs people have endured the unthinkable. And yet ‚Äì the lights are still on. Because every day, under fire and under pressure, people step up. They deserve more than admiration. They need unity in action and not just in words.A year ago, at the Ukraine Recovery Conference in Berlin, we launched the Business Advisory Council (BAC) ‚Äì a group of leaders from 17 countries, determined to move from promises to progress.Since then, we have launched five real projects: war risk insurance to unlock investment, a port infrastructure assessment, a social housing roadmap, a standardized PPA framework to support renewables and a practical travel guide to help businesses re-engage.These are concrete steps ‚Äì built for impact, built to scale, and built on the belief that Ukraine‚Äôs future must be one of strength, freedom, and opportunity.As I now hand over the BAC‚Äôs leadership to Barbara Cimmino and continue as a member, I want to thank every colleague around the table for your contributions and commitment. Much remains to be done ‚Äì and following the example of the Ukrainian people, we will keep going.

The EU Commission presents an ‚ÄúAction Plan‚Äù for the chemical industry and puts hashtag#resilience front and center. Why I see this as one of Ursula von der Leyen‚Äòs most decisive moves yet and why we mustn‚Äôt stop there. üëáThe so called "Critical Chemical Alliance" aims to address what keeps us awake at night. In a world where geopolitical tensions, protectionism and supply chain disruptions have become our reality, this new body can protect Europe's critical chemical production sites - and maintain Europe's strategic autonomy.The comprehensive thought behind the alliance seems promising. It focuses on protecting capacity and modernizing investments while coordinating across EU member states and tackling trade challenges. If implemented, it can move Europe from analysis to action - finally.And there's more: The "Action Plan" fosters affordable energy, drives innovation with new fiscal incentives, simplifies and reduces regulation, and takes a reasonable, science-based approach to PFAS.I particularly appreciate that Ursula von der Leyen is pushing this package forward at unprecedented speed. Because: timing is everything. With mounting global pressures, we must implement these measures swiftly and pragmatically. The chemical industry stands ready to turn her vision into reality.

These days, there is a lot of debate about what hashtag#Europe needs to be more competitive, more agile, and more resilient. hashtag#DigitalSovereignty is one topic that often comes up in these conversations, but to fully understand its impact on Europe‚Äôs future, we also need a clear and common definition of what it means.At its core, digital sovereignty means having control over your data and digital infrastructure.¬†It cannot mean complete isolation. We live in a world of tech dependencies that need to be considered. Even when European companies run data centers, key components ‚Äì like processors and networking gear ‚Äì still come from other parts of the world. And further up the¬†technology chain, many European businesses are using non-European software solutions. Pushing for complete independence would mean banning all tech from outside Europe ‚Äì both hardware and software ‚Äì something that would hurt our economy and slow down innovation.What we need instead is a holistic understanding of digital sovereignty in Europe ‚Äì one that focuses on self-determination,¬†mutual dependencies, and de-risking, not isolation. We need control over critical technology and data ‚Äì but in a way that allows us to use the best technologies available, no matter where they‚Äôre from. This is possible ‚Äì if Europe works together.The next wave of hashtag#AI innovation¬†will not be at the layer of the infrastructure. Our strengths lie in what we can build on top of that infrastructure. Great AI¬†is about¬†great input and great use cases ‚Äì and Europe is in a unique position to deliver on¬†these¬†with huge amounts of domain data, deep industry expertise, and very exciting AI startups.¬†We need revised regulatory frameworks in Europe that support this kind of innovation instead of holding it back.Read more of my thoughts on this important topic here (German only): https://lnkd.in/epGfHaed

Jeder zehnte Todesfall vor dem 70. Lebensjahr w√§re vermeidbar durch Pr√§vention, sch√§tzen die World Health Organization und die OECD - OCDE. Wir wollen das Bewusstsein daf√ºr sch√§rfen: f√ºr mehr medizinische Vorsorge und einen besseren Zugang zur optimalen Versorgung. Daran arbeiten wir jetzt gemeinsam mit der Charit√© - Universit√§tsmedizin Berlin.Wir werden in der hashtag#Pr√§ventionsmedizin nicht nur zusammen forschen, sondern klinische Ma√ünahmen auch schnellstm√∂glich in die Praxis umsetzen. Wir starten damit in der Kardiologie, denn Herz-Kreislauf-Erkrankungen sind die h√§ufigste Todesursache in Deutschland. Damit wollen wir uns nicht abfinden. Mit neuen Bildgebungs-Techniken und KI-basierten Werkzeugen, um diese Bilder auszuwerten, k√∂nnen wir Patienten schneller und gezielter behandeln ‚Äì im besten Fall, bevor eine Krankheit entsteht und Schaden anrichtet. Damit verbessern wir nicht nur die Lebensqualit√§t von vielen Menschen, sondern helfen auch, Gesundheitskosten zu senken. Ich freue mich daher sehr √ºber diese neue Kooperation: Sie ist eine gute Nachricht f√ºr Patienten, Mediziner und unser Gesundheitssystem.

Some of you asked about my workout routine in the comments. So, I thought I‚Äôd share a few things that keep me on track, even if I have a quite packed agenda and as day-to-day schedules change üòâ On intense business trips like last week's ASEAN tour, maintaining routines becomes even more crucial. My rule? The busier the schedule, the more important the workout and discipline becomes. Workouts Most importantly, you must make sure that workout sessions are part of your schedule. Don‚Äòt leave anything to chance!¬†I start the day at 5:30 a.m. (if schedule allows 6:00 am üòâ), afterwards straight to the gym, with weights, HIIT training like¬†jumping rope in between sets. (Fun fact: I helped design Siemens‚Äô fitness facilities ‚Äî and as a post-pandemic hobby, built the jump ropes myself! I am a new customer to hardware store's electric cable section üòâ). Healthy meals I‚Äôm strict about what I consume. Just as AI is only as good as its data, you‚Äôre only as good as what you put into you body üòâ¬†Pizza is off the table for more than a decade, egg-white omelets and low-fat yoghurt are on. I find lower carbs and higher protein set me up for sustained energy throughout the day. That said, I do enjoy some cake and sweets, too!¬†Tried many of them during the ASEAN trip. Remember: ‚ÄûThe dose makes the poison‚Äú  Staying energized on the roadTravel is a big part of the job, and jet lag can be tough. My tip? Adjust to the local time zone right away, on the very same day you land! And no matter how long the flight, skipping a workout is not an option.¬†I have a great team who selects the hotel according to the gym with proper equipments. That‚Äôs a a MUST. In case we don‚Äòt find one, there is always a public gym nearby and I book a day pass.  SleepYou still should get enough sleep, this is the time when your body, your brain and your muscles recover.¬†The strategy is to start dinner a bit earlier. And yes, I do stay out a bit longer with my team or with customers and partners ‚Äî for a drink or good conversation. But I don‚Äôt do that every day during my trips. Important warning: Don‚Äòt exercise when you feel sick. It can delay your recovery, can cause myocarditis, etc.. What's your strategy for staying energized during business travel? Do let me know! üëá

Bestes Netz aller europ√§ischen Fl√§chenl√§nderDie Deutsche Telekom hat das beste Mobilfunknetz der europ√§ischen Fl√§chenl√§nder. Der Testanbieter umlaut best√§tigt, was mir immer auch gro√üe Internetkonzerne sagen und was ich pers√∂nlich wahrnehme, wenn ich im Ausland unterwegs bin. Ich freue mich, dass 1,4 Milliarden Nutzer-Daten meine "anekdotische Evidenz" best√§tigen. Also letztlich: Unsere Kundinnen und Kunden. Umso mehr, als dass oft mit "anekdotischer Evidenz" argumentiert wird, bei der das Glas im deutschen Mobilfunknetz eher halbleer und nicht halbvoll ist.Umlaut wollte es genauer wissen und hat verglichen, wie es tats√§chlich um die Netze in Deutschland, Spanien, Frankreich, Polen, UK und Italien steht. Gl√ºckwunsch auch an die Kollegen der T-Mobile Polska, die das beste polnische Netz liefern. Nachzulesen ist der Test in der aktuellen ‚ÄûConnect‚Äú.  In Deutschland liefert die Telekom demnach mit einer Fl√§chenabdeckung von knapp 98 Prozent das beste Ergebnis. In knapp 96 Prozent aller gemessenen F√§lle war 4G oder 5G m√∂glich. Kein Netz in den verglichenen europ√§ischen Fl√§chen-L√§ndern erreicht diese Werte.Der Test best√§tigt au√üerdem, was auch bei anderen Messmethoden (etwa mit Messfahrzeugen, die oft nochmal pr√§ziser sind als Nutzerdaten) regelm√§√üig herauskommt: Die Telekom hat das beste Netz in Deutschland und ist hier die unangefochtene Nummer 1. Und wie sich zeigt: Auch in Europa sind wir f√ºhrend. Auf diese Infrastruktur k√∂nnen wir alle im Land also ein wenig stolz sein. Gratulation an Abdu Mudesir und alle Teams √ºberall, die das erreicht haben.F√ºr mich ist dieses Ergebnis Ansporn, weiterzumachen und weiter zu investieren. Wir wollen und werden die Qualit√§t unseres Netzes weiter verbessern. Ja, es gibt hier und da noch wei√üe Flecken. Und ja, manchmal bricht auch ein Gespr√§ch ab. Aber das Glas ist mindestens halbvoll. Voller als anderswo. Und (erst) wenn es ganz voll ist, sto√üen wir an! hashtag#wewontstop

Today‚Äôs visit to Brussels with Minister-President Hendrik W√ºst and fellow industry leaders sent a clear message: North Rhine-Westphalia is ready to shape Europe‚Äôs industrial future. Thank you, Ursula von der Leyen, for the opportunity to engage in a direct and constructive dialogue. As CEO of an industrial company deeply rooted in hashtag#Europe, I took the opportunity to highlight three key priorities: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Europe must urgently strengthen its hashtag#industrial base ‚Äì through faster decision-making, clear political signals, and coordinated investments in key technologies. 2Ô∏è‚É£ hashtag#Hydrogen can only become a pillar of the green transformation if Europe ensures competitive energy prices, sufficient supply, and a reliable infrastructure. 3Ô∏è‚É£ To safeguard the European hashtag#steel industry, the EU must enforce strict tariffs on unfair imports and close remaining loopholes in trade defense. The path to hashtag#climateneutrality is non-negotiable. But it must not come at the expense of our industrial backbone. That requires bold European decisions ‚Äì and an unwavering commitment to our industrial strength. At thyssenkrupp, we stand ready to take responsibility. The hashtag#Draghi report offers a clear roadmap. Now it's time to implement it. I called for a strong alliance of European companies ‚Äì united for a competitive, resilient, and climate-friendly industrial future. Let‚Äôs act together: to produce, invest, and hashtag#innovate ‚Äì in Europe!üì∏: Land NRW / Marius Becker

In today‚Äôs world, shaped by persistent inflation, rising living costs, and rapid digital transformation, managing money has become more complex than ever. Financial literacy is essential for both individual security and societal resilience. Yet Allianz research shows that only 10 to 18% of respondents in major developed countries demonstrate a high level of financial literacy, while up to a third lack even the basics. A recent European Central Bank study reveals that only 48% of euro-area adults can answer three basic finance questions. This is a clear signal for action. Financial literacy empowers people to make informed decisions and unlock opportunity, especially for women, young people and low-income communities. At Allianz, we believe financial education must be:‚úÖ Inclusive by design‚úÖ Simple but never simplistic‚úÖ Relevant and accessible People want guidance from trusted partners. That is why we have launched our Financial Literacy Hub, mentorship programs, and global partnerships like the new Fudan-Allianz Finance and Insurance Research Center in China. These initiatives are designed to build your financial confidence. We also regularly share insights and resources on financial literacy across our global and local social media channels to encourage dialogue and build momentum. How do you see the path to universal financial literacy? What financial insight has shaped your perspective? hashtag#FinancialLiteracy hashtag#Allianz

Just returned from the inaugural session of the World Economic Forum Leaders for European Competitiveness group. Everyone agrees that Europe has to invest in AI to boost its competitiveness. For maximum value, we should focus our limited resources less on commodity technologies such as chips, data centers, or even basic AI models - and much more on accelerating AI adoption and application in companies and in the public sector across Europe. This is where AI really creates exponential value for our economy and society, this is where Europe can still win the global race. And especially in the public sector, a European-wide sovereign cloud solution will be the chief way to get there.  A big thank you to the European Commission for seeking and fostering these important conversations, especially to President Ursula von der Leyen and Executive Vice President Henna Virkkunen. The ideas are all there. Our true success will now depend on how we implement them.

Meine Gedanken in meinem neuen Blogbeitrag (Link in den Kommentaren). Eines ist sicher: Echte Transformation gelingt nur durch Zusammenarbeit statt Silomentalit√§t.

Back in January at the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting, I sat down with Linda Lacina for a conversation on the ‚ÄúMeet The Leader‚Äù podcast ‚Äî a thoughtful exchange that just went live.We talked about a special initiative to expand access to stroke care in Vietnam, the role of AI in closing health equity gaps, and how lessons from physics and basketball continue to shape my work and perspectives.This particular clip touches on something we‚Äôre always working to improve at Siemens Healthineers: how we support care providers in navigating today‚Äôs biggest healthcare challenges ‚Äî from staff shortages to rising costs to the growing burden of noncommunicable diseases. +++Breaking News: Siemens completes the acquistion of Dotmatics +++ Exciting news today: We just completed the acquisition of Dotmatics. Here are 5 things about our latest acquisition that you should know: üî¨ 1. Who is Dotmatics? Dotmatics is a leading provider of R&D software for the Life Sciences sector, based in the U.S. They support more than 2 million scientists around the world. Their portfolio combines advanced scientific applications with their Scientific Intelligence Platform, Luma ‚Äì a unique, AI-enabled multimodal data platform trusted by top pharma and biotech companies.  üí° 2. Why is this acquisition so important? Here's a striking fact: bringing just one new medicine to market typically takes over a decade and costs billions of dollars. One of the biggest challenges is that important research data is scattered across different systems - imagine trying to solve a puzzle when the pieces are spread across different rooms. ü§ù 3. Why This Partnership is Revolutionary By joining forces, Siemens and Dotmatics are creating what we call a "digital thread" ‚Äì a seamless connection from early laboratory research straight through to production. By combining Dotmatics‚Äô scientific intelligence with our industrial AI technologies and digital twins we are creating a powerhouse that will accelerate medicine development and make treatments more affordable. üöÄ 4. The Integration Plan Dotmatics will be integrated into our Digital Industries Software business. While we already serve the Life Sciences sector with our automation technology, software solutions and smart infrastructure for research facilities and production sites, this acquisition significantly expands our footprint in this dynamic market. We see great potential not only in Life Sciences but also in adjacent industries like chemicals, food & beverage, and materials. üí™ 5. The Bigger Picture: ONE Tech Strategy This acquisition perfectly exemplifies our ONE Tech strategy in action. We're not just adding another company to our portfolio; we're creating a technological ecosystem that will transform how scientific research is conducted. The end goal? Stronger customer focus, faster innovations, and higher growth.  So, to sum things up: With Dotmatics, we‚Äôre building a new era of innovation in Life Sciences. From research through to production ‚Äì we‚Äôre creating a unique, end-to-end digital thread. This will allow us to help our customers accelerate breakthroughs, reduce development cycles, and bring life-saving pharmaceuticals faster and more affordably to the market ‚Äì to reach the people, who need them most.

From Telegraphenamt to tech powerhouse - last week, we came full circle in Berlin! üè¢ Our new Siemens Berlin office opened in the historic Main Telegraph Office - just circa 3 kilometers from where Werner von Siemens started Europe's first tech startup 178 years ago. A place that once connected Europe through telegraphs (with Siemens technology, of course üòâ) will now help shape Germany's digital future.This isn't just about a new location. It's about creating a space where innovation meets impact, where industry meets politics, and where today's challenges become tomorrow's opportunities. Special thanks to Federal Minister Thorsten Frei for being our guest speaker and discussing what needs to be done to secure Germany‚Äôs and Europe‚Äôs competitiveness.

Manche Menschen machen den Unterschied. Michael Sommer war so ein Mensch. Von 2000 bis 2018 war er Mitglied unseres Aufsichtsrats. Sein Tod macht uns traurig; er wird nicht nur der Telekom, sondern auch mir pers√∂nlich fehlen. Als kompetenter Moderator und kritischer Aufseher hat Michael Sommer der Telekom nachhaltige Impulse gegeben. Besonders in Zeiten der Ver√§nderung und des Fortschritts war er nicht nur Anwalt der Arbeitnehmenden, sondern immer auch Anwalt der Telekom und ihrer Zukunft insgesamt. Soziale Gerechtigkeit schloss bei ihm immer auch die kommende Generation ein. Seine konstruktive Herangehensweise an die Arbeit im Aufsichtsrat war vorbildlich. Gerade, weil sein Einsatz f√ºr die Rechte der Arbeitnehmer aufgrund der eigenen Biografie immer authentisch und glaubw√ºrdig war. Sozialpartnerschaft hatte f√ºr ihn einen hohen Stellenwert, und er pflegte selbst in Konfliktsituationen den Geist der Zusammenarbeit. Sozial und partnerschaftlich! Er hat Entscheidungen nicht nur moderierend herbeigef√ºhrt, sondern sie auch mitgetragen und aktiv vertreten. Besonders gesch√§tzt habe ich seine Klugheit, mit der er mir immer ein guter pers√∂nlicher Ratgeber war. Und wenn es einmal allzu ernst war im Aufsichtsrat, hat er mit seinem subtilen, zum Teil auch bissigen Humor die Stimmung gel√∂st. Wir haben (konstruktiv) gestritten. Aber wir haben auch viel gelacht. Manchmal √ºbereinander. √ñfter miteinander.  Michael Sommer redete nie um den hei√üen Brei herum. Es war leidenschaftlich in der Sache. Er war klar in seiner Meinung. Er war klar in den Zielen. Aber er war auch klar in den Argumenten. Vertrauliches blieb vertraulich. Er hat dadurch Vertrauen gestiftet, aber er hat Vertrauen auch geschenkt.  Die Telekom und ich werden Michael Sommer vermissen, aber nicht vergessen. Er hat unser Unternehmen und die Arbeit im Aufsichtsrat gepr√§gt. Das wirkt weiter. Unsere Gedanken und unser Mitgef√ºhl gelten seiner Familie und seinen Freunden.

Die neue Bundesregierung kann und muss das mit ihrem Neustart der Energiewende unterst√ºtzen, etwa indem sie b√ºrokratische H√ºrden f√ºr neue Infrastruktur abbaut, Steuern und Abgaben auf Strom soweit wie m√∂glich reduziert, die Ausbauplanungen f√ºr Erneuerbare und Netze effizient miteinander verzahnt und eine konsequente Digitalisierung und Flexibilisierung des Energiesystems erm√∂glicht.

An unexpected Excel moment changed my entire conversation with Microsoft‚Äôs Satya Nadella about AI.AI was, of course, at the top of the agenda at our annual hashtag#ExecutiveMeeting in Istanbul ‚Äì and who better to ask about it than the Chairman and CEO of Microsoft himself? Thank you, Satya, for taking the time to talk to us and answer our questions about the enormous platform shift we are currently experiencing.This shift is as big as the internet or the mobile revolution, but it's happening faster than anything we've seen before. And here comes the surprising but powerful analogy to Excel: Excel didn't change business processes through a department, but by empowering individuals to find solutions to problems.Just like Excel, AI is not a technological challenge, but a cultural one. The most powerful technology can only be effective if it is broadly diffused. AI is not just for the tech team. AI will not be a revolution from above. AI will be shaped by everyone who uses it.We also discussed the role of leadership in times of massive change. His message to leaders is: Create clarity, unleash energy, and drive success ‚Äì even in times of great constraints!Thank you, Satya, for the conversation and the energy you brought to our Executive Meeting.

One topic I often get asked about is the impact of hashtag#AI on productivity. While there‚Äôs no one-size-fits-all answer to that question, AI without doubt represents the greatest economic opportunity since the rise of the internet and is already a key driver of productivity across businesses in every industry. At SAP, we‚Äôre seeing the huge difference AI makes both for our customers and within our own business. But when it comes to adopting and getting the most out of AI, there are a number of critical success factors. One key aspect is regulation. Regulation is a must, but we also have to be careful not to overregulate at the expense of innovation. The focus should be on regulating the outcome, not the technology. Another reason companies struggle to realize the value of AI in their organizations is the data quality itself. High-quality data is the foundation for trusted AI, but companies often face the challenge of large data silos and how to bring together unstructured and structured data. In the age of AI, more than ever, having one common semantical data layer for your business data is key to understanding a business holistically, as well as the external trends that impact it.The third key piece is knowledge and change management. The value of AI is clear, but many companies are unsure about how they can best extract it and whether they have the skills they need to realize its potential for their business. Successfully applying AI is much more than simply implementing a piece of technology. The importance of upskilling, leadership, communication, and culture cannot be underestimated in any business transformation journey.In an increasingly unpredictable world, AI plays an important role in helping businesses thrive. Today, it's already driving agility, resilience, and productivity ‚Äì and by focusing on the right regulatory frameworks, data quality, and change management, these benefits are set to increase even further.

Das Telefon war gr√ºn. Die Reaktion gold.Ich habe dieses Jahr auf der Hauptversammlung ein gr√ºnes W√§hlscheibentelefon auf die B√ºhne gestellt.Nicht, weil Retro gerade Trend ist. Sondern weil es einen Punkt macht:Ver√§nderung beginnt da, wo wir uns trauen, alte Muster zu hinterfragen.Und nein ‚Äì ich h√§tte nicht gedacht, dass mich das Ding (und vielleicht auch ein bisschen der Rest meiner Rede) auf Platz 1 im Handelsblatt-Rhetorikranking bringt. Rhetorikcheck Aber wenn schon Ranking, dann nehme ich‚Äôs nat√ºrlich. Mit einem L√§cheln. Und mit einem stillen Gru√ü an alle, die schon mal versucht haben, ein analoges Telefon an Glasfaser anzuschlie√üen.Was ich eigentlich sagen will:Reden auf einer HV sind keine Rechenschaftsberichte mit Mikrofon. Sie sind Momente. Chancen Kunden zu gewinnen und Aktion√§ren zu zeigen, ob man sein Gesch√§ft versteht. Vielleicht sogar ein bisschen B√ºhne f√ºr einen tieferen Sinn.Wenn wir es ernst meinen mit Wandel ‚Äì dann m√ºssen wir auch verst√§ndlich, klar und ehrlich dar√ºber sprechen. Nicht in 57 Bulletpoints, sondern in Geschichten, Bildern, Symbolen. Und ja ‚Äì manchmal auch mit einer Schaufensterpuppe im Blazer.Und offenbar hat das Wirkung gezeigt:Platz 1 im Handelsblatt-Rhetorikranking 2025 ‚Äì vielen Dank an die Jury!Ich nehme das mit einem Augenzwinkern, aber auch mit einem klaren Appell an alle, die auf B√ºhnen stehen:F√ºnf Dinge, die ich gelernt habe: 1.¬†¬†¬†¬†Sprich klar, nicht klug. Ein Gedanke pro Satz reicht v√∂llig. 2.¬†¬†¬†¬†Nutze Bilder, nicht Bulletpoints. Requisiten helfen ‚Äì wenn sie zur Story passen. 3.¬†¬†¬†¬†Zeig Haltung. Wer nur informiert, verliert. Wer ber√ºhrt, bleibt h√§ngen. 4.¬†¬†¬†¬†Vertrau dem Publikum. Die Leute sind kl√ºger als jede Chartfolie. 5.¬†¬†¬†¬†Bleib du selbst. Alles andere wirkt k√ºnstlich ‚Äì und das merkt man.Rhetorik ist kein Beiwerk. Sie ist F√ºhrung in Echtzeit. Und wenn ein gr√ºnes Telefon hilft, diese Botschaft r√ºberzubringen ‚Äì dann nehme ich es auch n√§chstes Jahr wieder mit auf die B√ºhne!Gr√º√üe vom Rednerpult (oder der B√ºhne)Tim

Three whirlwind days in Berlin ‚Äì do follow me around! üå™Ô∏èüêªGermany has everything it takes to upgrade to the operating system for the industry of the future and to do so we don‚Äôt need more plans, we need more execution ‚Äì that was my key message this week in Berlin. For instance, at the "Tag der Industrie‚Äù of BDI - Bundesverband der Deutschen Industrie e.V. where I discussed with other CEOs how a new collaboration between business and politics could look like.Or at the opening of our new capital office in the Telegraphenamt, where we've created a space designed for collaboration and innovation in the heart of Germany's capital, right next to Apple, Google, and others. Do get a glimpse of my eventful 72 hours in Berlin üòâ Markus Krebber, Christian Sewing, Volker Krug, Christin Schack, Ina Karabasz

Germany needs a new operating system! üîÑ Germany's business model must evolve to adapt to new geopolitical realities and global competitive landscapes. We need faster and more profound innovations. Accelerated approval processes. Fewer, more focused regulations. Less bureaucracy. More innovation. This was also at the center of discussion at this year's "Tag der Industrie". For me, two things must go hand in hand: A bold innovation offensive and a clear priority on growth. Germany has a historic opportunity. We still stand on a solid foundation that we can build upon. We have everything it takes to once again assume a leading economic role through digitalization and artificial intelligence. So, we don't have a problem of insight, but one of execution. And this needs to change now!Markus Krebber, Christian Sewing, Volker Krug, Christin Schack, Ina Karabasz, BDI - Bundesverband der Deutschen Industrie e.V.

Germany can‚Äôt do software?! ü§î If you want to build a full-scale, physics-based digital twin of a product, a factory or even an entire city ‚Äì Siemens is the place to go. Gehen Sie gerne ins Restaurant? Dann stellen Sie sich einmal vor, es gibt ein gro√ües Buffet-Restaurant, das jeden Tag f√ºr exakt 100 G√§ste das gleiche Essen vorbereitet. Die Antwort auf dieses Problem hei√üt: Flexibilit√§t. In unserem Restaurant s√§he das dann so aus: Das Restaurant digitalisiert sich und wei√ü jeden Tag in Echtzeit, wie viele G√§ste kommen, und kann dann genau die passende Menge beschaffen und zubereiten. Dadurch werden alle sicher versorgt, kein Essen wird verschwendet, und nicht nur das Restaurant, sondern auch die G√§ste w√ºrden viel Geld sparen, weil das Restaurant g√ºnstigere Preise anbieten kann.Genau √ºber diese Herausforderung haben gestern Philipp Schr√∂der von 1KOMMA5¬∞ und ich in Berlin diskutiert. Hierf√ºr m√ºssen wir gemeinsam mit der Politik den richtigen Rahmen schaffen. Denn Flexibilit√§t entscheidet √ºber das Gelingen der Energiewende.

Some innovations look like high-tech marvels. Others are shaped by hand‚Äîin fire, with skill passed down through generations.X-ray technology has advanced in leaps: faster scans, sharper images, greater reliability. But at the heart of every X-ray tube lies a centuries-old craft that still matters today: glassblowing.In Rudolstadt, Germany, our artisans form the delicate glass components for X-ray tubes by hand. Each piece must withstand extreme heat and pressure, while meeting incredible precision standards. There‚Äôs no automation for this level of craftsmanship‚Äîjust expertise, care, and consistency.Why does it matter? Because the reliability of these components helps bring diagnostic care to more people, in more places‚Äîfrom hospitals to mobile clinics in remote regions. It‚Äôs a reminder that even the most advanced technology depends on people. On craft. On detail.This is what I love about our work: the intersection of deep tradition and modern impact.

These days we celebrate 25 years of E.ON ‚Äì a beautiful and emotional occasion for the E.ON family. Anyone who has been with the Group for any length of time has experienced many ups and downs, political change, crises and volatility in our economic environment, phases of consolidation and reorientation of our businesses and thousands of colleagues in half of Europe who work passionately for our E.ON and its subsidiaries. Bottom line we have learned in 25 years to look ahead and move with the times. This has contributed to the fact that today we are in an excellent position. And consequently, we don't dwell on our history these days but look ahead and take responsibility for the the next chapter of energy. It‚Äôs on us!With our strategic focus on growth, digitization and sustainability we want to be the playmakers of the energy transition. And we value our actions against clear attributes: to be brave, progressive, impactful and reliable. I witness all of that ‚Äì our strategic focus, our work and actions along strong attributes, our positive doer attitude ‚Äì each and every day within our group.Nothing is perfect, but we have the mindset of getting it done as best as possible. Thanks to the whole E.ON familiy for the commitment, enthusiasm and know-how of our employees, we ensure that new energy works. We keep our promise, now and for the future: It‚Äôs on us to make new energy work!hashtag#itsonus hashtag#eon2000

I have three sons. I‚Äôve cheered for their first school day, their last school day, their first job, and their match point on the tennis court.Every milestone fills me with pride ‚Äî not because I had a hand in it, but because they did. I get excited when I watch them take a step on their own. Succeed. Fail. Grow. It‚Äôs their journey. And my role? I support. I listen. I step back, even when it's hard sometimes. Anyone with children probably has the same feelings. And leadership is not that different. Simon Sinek once said: ‚ÄúParenting is the closest thing to leadership‚Äù. Parenting and leadership both are about seeing people clearly ‚Äî their strengths, struggles, potential ‚Äî and it‚Äôs about putting them first.I had the privilege of being mentored by exactly that kind of exceptional leader.‚úîÔ∏è A leader who, above all, was patient with me.‚úîÔ∏è Patient when I made mistakes.‚úîÔ∏è Patient when projects took longer than expected.‚úîÔ∏è Patient with my many ideas ‚Äî even when they didn‚Äôt quite hit the mark.‚úîÔ∏è Today, I try to be that kind of leader myself.And yes, I stumble too. But I keep trying again. Because I can see the value it brings to talents ‚Äî and to us as an organisation.

Not all our breakthroughs in medical technology look like a big machine. Sometimes it‚Äôs a small vial‚Äîfilled with a few teaspoons of blood‚Äîthat carries the potential to change a life.Take multiple sclerosis (MS), a disease that affects nearly 3 million people worldwide. For many, the wait for symptoms to appear, or for imaging to confirm what they already feel, can be full of uncertainty. Now a simple blood test can deliver key insights and help ensure patients get the right care at the right time. I find this quiet breakthrough so powerful.The test targets neurofilament light chain (NfL), a blood-based biomarker now detectable with a diagnostic test. This is the first CE-marked* biomarker for MS. When used together with other clinical, imaging, and laboratory findings, NfL can help predict the risk of MS disease activity in an individual patient with RMS. These earlier insights help clinicians personalize treatment earlier and give the patient something often missing: clarity.It‚Äôs not dramatic on the outside, but the impact is very real. This is the kind of innovation I believe deserves more attention‚Äîthe kind that puts meaningful change in a small vial.*ùòäùòå-0197. ùòïùò∞ùòµ ùò¢ùò∑ùò¢ùò™ùò≠ùò¢ùò£ùò≠ùò¶ ùò™ùòØ ùòµùò©ùò¶ ùòú.ùòö. ùòàùò∑ùò¢ùò™ùò≠ùò¢ùò£ùò™ùò≠ùò™ùòµùò∫ ùò∑ùò¢ùò≥ùò™ùò¶ùò¥ ùò£ùò∫ ùò§ùò∞ùò∂ùòØùòµùò≥ùò∫.

In my article about our ‚ÄúEnergy Playbook‚Äù published last week on Euronews I‚Äôve highlighted a few facts & figures to prove that an affordable energy transition is not just achievable ‚Äî it is essential for Europe‚Äôs energy security and long-term prosperity.  ‚û°Ô∏è 6.6 trillion ‚Ç¨ must be invested into the energy system to achieve net zero emissions by 2050.‚û°Ô∏è Over ‚Ç¨1.5 trillion of energy system costs can be saved by 2050 by reprioritizing the transition, scaling the system based on demand and planning for robust digitized infrastructures. ‚û°Ô∏è The key is electrification as the most cost-efficient abatement option for 80% of the energy transition. ‚û°Ô∏è Electrifying heat and transport will drive EU power demand up by 30% by 2035 which enhances the synergy potential for the infrastructure behind.‚û°Ô∏è The digital enablement of the grid & customers alone can substitute up to 240 GW of backup capacity and save ‚Ç¨40 billion annually by 2050 due tothe integration of flexibility. ‚û°Ô∏è Smart scaling of our energy system in line with actual demand can unlock savings of nearly ‚Ç¨200 billion by 2030. The energy transition game needs a business-like rulebook. Policymakers must act decisively to correct the trajectory. Unser Ziel: nachhaltiges Wachstum erm√∂glichen ‚Äì und das bedeutet die meisten unserer Gesch√§fte so aufzustellen, dass sie eigenst√§ndig am Kapitalmarkt agieren und sich langfristig erfolgreich entwickeln k√∂nnen. Was hei√üt das konkret f√ºr den Konzern? ‚û°Ô∏è EP Group h√§lt bereits 20 % an thyssenkrupp Steel ‚Äì Ziel ist ein 50:50-Joint-Venture. Als eigenst√§ndig b√∂rsennotiertes Unternehmen kann TKMS k√ºnftig flexibler agieren ‚Äì und so auch den Wert der thyssenkrupp AG als Ankeraktion√§r steigern.‚û°Ô∏è Danach planen wir, Minderheitsanteile von thyssenkrupp Materials Services und thyssenkrupp Automotive abzuspalten. Die Vorbereitungen f√ºr ihre Kapitalmarktf√§higkeit laufen bereits.‚û°Ô∏è Bei hashtag#thyssenkrupp Decarbon Technologies beobachten wir den Markt genau. Der Aufschwung wird kommen ‚Äì und wir werden bereit sein. Ich bin √ºberzeugt: Wir gehen den richtigen Weg. Auch wenn er schmerzhaft ist ‚Äì besonders f√ºr ein so traditionsreiches Unternehmen wie thyssenkrupp. Aber es f√ºhrt kein Weg daran vorbei: Wir m√ºssen die Gesch√§fte neu aufstellen, um Zukunft zu schaffen. Mein besonderer Dank gilt Ilse Henne, Volkmar Dinstuhl, Wilfried von Rath, Axel Hamann ‚Äì und nat√ºrlich unserer hashtag#GENERATIONTK in den B√ºros und Werken weltweit. Im Interview mit Jan Dams und Carsten Dierig von der Welt am Sonntag hatte ich die Gelegenheit, unsere Pl√§ne im Detail zu erl√§utern. Vielen Dank f√ºr das gute Gespr√§ch!

The glass is half empty.This mindset of perpetual pessimism has become almost reflexive in Germany - surely also fueled by daily headlines about unproductivity and economic decline.Reading these, it‚Äôs easy to get the impression that Germany‚Äôs best days are behind us.‚ÄØBut as an industry leader, I refuse to see the glass as half empty.Germany has everything we need to thrive: industrial strength, relative stability,¬†technological expertise, and innovative minds. What's missing isn't capability ‚Äì it's conviction. We need to move past this self-defeating narrative and focus on what we always did best: turning challenges into opportunities.And for this, we need a shared mission. No company thrives without a purpose. So, why should a whole economy? We need an economic purpose that unites our nation, focuses our energies, and propels us forward.To me, "Made in Germany" used to be our purpose. It always stood for excellence. Now it's time to make it synonymous with innovation again. This isn't about preserving our industrial heritage; it's about reinventing it for what‚Äôs yet to come. This path forward requires courage, collaboration, and above all, the confidence that we can make it happen.Kudos to Katja Berlin/DIE ZEIT for this powerful yet sobering idea to visualize the current German state of mind!¬†üòâ

Speaking about electrification in a country with domestic gas resources, about an affordable energy transition where purchasing power is limited, and about grid security on the border of an active war ‚Äì none of this is easy. But this is why it‚Äôs necessary. And that is why I‚Äôve just returned from a visit to Romania, one of the countries in which E.ON is one of the top two large grid operators. Done right, electrification and smart grid investments are not just climate actions, they are acts of strategic resilience. Attracting capital to modernize and expand Romania‚Äôs power system is the most effective way to improve energy affordability. As Romania undergoes a political reset and navigates a rough macroeconomic context, being open to investment and reform is key. Romania‚Äôs people are deeply resourceful and that‚Äôs a great asset to steady the course.

By next year, Gen Z employees will represent over a quarter of the total workforce. They hold extraordinary promise, and we have a lot to learn from them, especially from their values of purpose, inclusion and continuous learning. At the same time, they are navigating under intense pressure. Nearly half of Gen Z employees report experiencing frequent anxiety, much of it tied to uncertainty around their career futures. At Allianz, we see this as a call to action. We are building clearer, more inclusive pathways for skilled professions and removing the barriers that prevent young people from reaching their potential. Through our partnership with JOBLINGE, a powerful social initiative, we aim to connect 100,000 young people to the workforce by 2030, including through internships and apprenticeships at Allianz. These opportunities are not just a foot in the door. They are launchpads for long-term success. We are also meeting Gen Z where they are. Our hashtag#MyFirstJob TikTok campaign features real, relatable stories about career experiences and mental health. The goal is to help young people feel seen, heard, and supported. And while this effort starts with the next generation, it does not stop there. Our cross-generational mentoring program encourages employees of all ages to exchange skills, broaden perspectives and grow together. We are also investing in AI-readiness, digital skills and leadership development to ensure lifelong learning is embedded in our culture. Building a workplace ready for the future means starting with people. That means giving them their first chance, believing in their potential and showing them: you belong here and you matter. The future of work is not coming. It is already here. Let us build it together, starting now. hashtag#Allianz

One kind of transformer saves the day in action movies. The kind we build at Siemens Energy does it quietly by bringing power from where it's generated to where it's needed. Last week I met with our hashtag#TeamPurple in Dresden ‚Äì around 250 people working with precision to produce medium power transformers. These aren‚Äôt just heavy pieces of engineering ‚Äì they‚Äôre essential to making our energy systems work. By adjusting voltage levels, they enable electricity to travel efficiently across long distances ‚Äì while supporting grid stability and the resilience of increasingly flexible energy systems. Thanks again for the warm welcome ‚Äì and for everything you‚Äôre doing to keep energy flowing around the world.

Much of what fuels innovation in healthcare stays behind the scenes (or behind the lab). It‚Äôs not always the news of the moment, but it‚Äôs the foundation of who we are and what I find fascinating and worth sharing. I‚Äôm always astonished by how far we‚Äôve come as a team, and excited by the pace at which we‚Äôre changing what will be possible tomorrow. So why not shine a light on some of the overlooked details‚Äîor, better yet, the quiet breakthroughs that make all the difference? Each background picture on my profile has its own story to tell. Yes, as a physicist and a Healthineer, I may be a bit biased. But I think many would agree: there‚Äôs a lot of art in science. And the details are often extraordinary.Take photon-counting CT, for example. To pioneer breakthroughs like this, we now grow crystals‚Äîcadmium telluride, to be exact‚Äîover 12 intense weeks. In nature, the same process would take millions of years. The purest cadmium telluride crystal is the starting point for a quantum leap in computed tomography technology. Years of research, development, and production have led to the creation of pure crystals with electrical properties that have revolutionized CT detector technology.Yes, it‚Äôs technical. But the impact is very human. Every touchpoint matters. Because these carefully grown crystals help deliver sharper insights, earlier answers, and better outcomes for everyone, everywhere, sustainably.This is just one glimpse behind the curtain. What do you think about this one? I‚Äôll be sharing what catches my attention from each background soon!

A big step forward by Werner Ponikwar and the team at thyssenkrupp nucera: together with Fraunhofer IKTS, they‚Äôve opened the first hashtag#SOEC pilot production plant for stacks (electrolysis cells) in Thuringia ‚Äì an important milestone on the path to commercial and industrial-scale deployment of high-temperature electrolysis for decarbonizing heavy industry.The high-temperature hashtag#electrolysis technology SOEC (Solid Oxide Electrolysis Cell) guarantees high corrosion resistance and optimized thermal cycle performance, and ensures high efficiency because less electrical energy is required to split water vapor at high temperatures. The SOEC pilot plant will produce high-performance stacks, the core of next-generation SOEC electrolyzers and the foundation for future automated, industrial-scale production. But that‚Äôs not all: it can also use CO‚ÇÇ as a feedstock, converting it into green synthesis gas together with hashtag#hydrogen. That opens the door to climate-neutral fuels and feedstocks, with real potential for scaling across hard-to-abate sectors.The pilot production also expands thyssenkrupp nucera‚Äôs hydrogen portfolio, with SOEC as a strong complement to their proven AWE technology. And the positive momentum continues: the team has recently been commissioned to conduct Front-End Engineering and Design (hashtag#FEED) study for a large-scale 600 MW water electrolysis project in Europe. The hashtag#greenhydrogen produced will supply customers in the heavy industry sector. Congratulations to everyone involved ‚Äì another important step forward also for hashtag#thyssenkrupp Decarbon Technologies and for building the hydrogen economy of tomorrow.üì∏: Fraunhofer IKTS / thyssenkrupp nucera: Paul-Philipp Braun

Back from Brussels, where talks with EU leaders focused on one thing ‚Äì how to keep Europe competitive in an increasingly complex world.There‚Äôs a clear sense of urgency ‚Äì and at the same time, a willingness to act. What stood out to me was the broad agreement on some key points:1Ô∏è‚É£ Europe must remain attractive for industrial investment. That means speeding up permitting, simplifying regulation, and making funding tools work for real projects on the ground ‚Äì not just in policy papers.2Ô∏è‚É£¬†We need to strengthen transatlantic ties without slipping into a tariff race. The conversation should be about industrial cooperation, not confrontation. Tariffs and retaliatory measures won‚Äôt make us more resilient ‚Äì but coordinated action might.3Ô∏è‚É£¬†On China, the challenge is to rebalance, not to decouple. The goal must be to reduce risk without cutting ourselves off from vital trade and global innovation.4Ô∏è‚É£¬†Europe also needs a more strategic approach to how it supports its partners abroad. Finance aid should go hand in hand with industrial cooperation ‚Äì especially in sectors like energy and infrastructure.5Ô∏è‚É£¬†And finally, we need to make Europe easier to build in. That means aligning rules with impact and simplifying regulation around hydrogen, grid procurement, and offshore wind. This will require a stronger Clean Industrial Deal with more targeted investment.As a company with deep roots in Europe ‚Äì 65,000 people working across the EU ‚Äì we at Siemens Energy are continuing to invest: in technology and talent. In order to maintain this momentum, we need a policy environment that matches the scale and ambition of Europe‚Äôs industrial potential.Thank you President Ursula von der Leyen, President Roberta Metsola, Executive Vice-President St√©phane S√©journ√©, and the representatives from the Directorate-General for Trade for the valuable exchange.üì∏: Dati Bendo

Is there an unexpected upside to hashtag#AI's growing energy hunger? Here's why I believe there is.¬†üëá A single ChatGPT request consumes about 0.0029 kWh of electricity, nearly 10 times that of a Google search. By 2026, data centers could double their current power consumption ‚Äì matching the entire energy needs of Japan, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA). Yet, I see this unprecedented energy demand as a powerful catalyst for change. It's already pushing the boundaries of what we thought possible in clean energy innovation. Fusion energy ‚Äì once a distant dream ‚Äì is now attracting serious investment from tech giants: ‚Ä¢ Microsoft has signed a deal with Helion, targeting fusion power generation by 2028.‚Ä¢ Google is partnering with Kairos Power to deploy small modular reactors (SMRs), starting around 2030.‚Ä¢ Amazon is diversifying into fusion, geothermal, and modular nuclear to secure sustainable energy supplies. And it's not just about producing MORE energy. It's about using it SMARTER: ‚Ä¢ Google already shifts computing loads to times and locations with cleaner energy availability.‚Ä¢ Microsoft's Finnish data centers will soon heat thousands of homes with their waste heat. What we're witnessing is more than just an energy challenge ‚Äì it's a technological revolution that's driving unprecedented innovation in clean energy solutions. And it reminds me: sometimes, the biggest challenges can create the most promising breakthroughs.

The Tideway project sets a benchmark for sustainable urban development that protects communities and revitalizes natural ecosystems. Even with the complexities of large-scale construction, Tideway shows what‚Äôs possible when long-term capital meets long-term vision.At¬†Allianz, we see projects like Tideway as investments, as well as a responsibility we embrace, to drive sustainable growth benefiting societies and life insurance policyholders ‚Äì with security and returns on their savings. As of today, we‚Äôve invested over¬†40 billion¬†euros into infrastructure equity and debt, focusing on the¬†three Ds:‚úÖ Digitalization ‚Äì investing in AI-ready data centers, fiber networks and smart grids‚úÖ Decarbonization ‚Äì from renewables to green hydrogen to electric transport‚úÖ Demographics¬†‚Äì supporting inclusive housing, telemedicine, education, and healthcareThe Thames Tideway Tunnel is further evidence that public-private partnerships can close the growing infrastructure gap while delivering real-world benefits for people and communities. We see it as a model for future infrastructure collaborations that directly address today‚Äôs energy and societal challengesThe infrastructure we invest in today will define the world we live in tomorrow. At Allianz, we‚Äôre ready to build it ‚Äì together with policymakers, industry leaders, and communities.Allianz Global Investors Allianz Investment Management Allianz Lebensversicherungs-AG hashtag#Allianz

Der Hund bleibt der Hund Die Deutsche Telekom versteht sich als wichtigster Partner der Kommunen in Deutschland. Darum bin ich gerne der Einladung zum Kommunalkongress nachgekommen, um einen praktischen Impuls zu setzen: Wie k√∂nnen wir bei der Digitalisierung jetzt schneller vorankommen?Die Voraussetzung ist immer: Infrastruktur. Wir sind und bleiben ‚Äì neudeutsch ‚Äì comitted. Zwei von drei Glasfaseranschl√ºssen bauen wir. Rund 50 Milliarden Euro haben wir in den vergangenen zehn Jahren allein in Deutschland investiert. Und haben damit eine Infrastruktur geschaffen, die w√§hrend Corona den Stresstest bestanden hat.Wir werden weiter bauen. Trotz Kosten, die zum Teil 8x so hoch sind wie in Spanien. 2,5 Millionen Haushalte pro Jahr. Noch ist die Nachfrage nach FTTH relativ gering. Aber sie wird steigen. Und wir werden darum auch immer mehr Wohnungen direkt anschlie√üen.Die Telekom arbeitet kooperativ. √úber 40 Partnerschaften haben wir beim Glasfaserausbau mit Stadtwerken geschlossen. Und wo f√ºr beide Seiten vertretbar mieten wir auch bestehende Infrastruktur an ‚Äì so genannte Dark Fiber.Aber Digitalisierung ist nicht nur Infrastruktur. Sie ist auch, was wir auf den Netzen anbieten. Und die Digitalisierung ist gerade f√ºr die Kommunen ein gro√ües Geschenk. Sie m√ºssen bei knappen Kassen immer mehr Aufgaben bew√§ltigen. Und auch der Frust mancher B√ºrger landet erst im √∂rtlichen Rathaus, bevor er Berlin erreicht. Digitalisierung und KI werden helfen, Kommunen effizienter, aber auch nahbarer zu machen.Zu oft wird aber f√ºr digitale L√∂sungen das Rad immer wieder neu erfunden; anstatt auf bestehende und funktionierende L√∂sungen zur√ºckzugreifen. ‚ÄûDer Hund bleibt der Hund. Ob in Kiel oder Konstanz‚Äú, habe ich dazu gesagt. Also brauche ich auch nicht verschiedene Software-L√∂sungen zum Thema Hundesteuer. Mein praktischer Vorschlag: Google, Amazon und Apple k√∂nne es schon lange, Microsoft mit Githup k√∂nnen es bei Business Software: Software f√ºr alle in einem App-Store bereitstellen. Und das gleiche machen wir jetzt f√ºr Verwaltubgssoftware.Der Bund stellt eine Cloud und den Rahmen bereit, alle Kommunen stellen ihre zertifizierte Software zur Verf√ºgung und die Gemeinde, die digitalisieren will, sucht sich eine schon existierende Software.Die f√∂derale Struktur bleibt erhalten. Wir bei der Deutschen Telekom w√ºrden uns freuen, wenn wir dabei helfen k√∂nnen. Denn digitale Verwaltung sind nicht nur schneller und g√ºnstiger, sondern vor allem bei B√ºrgern und Unternehmen akzeptierter.Oft sitzen Kommunen und Telekom vor Ort in einem Boot: Hohe Erwartungen treffen auf die Realit√§t vor Ort. Mobilfunk ja, aber keinen Mast. Hier ist die Telekom auch auf Kommunen angewiesen, die bei der Standortsuche unterst√ºtzen oder Standorte zur Verf√ºgung stellen.Mein Fazit: Im Netz ruckelt es Dank hoher Investitionen deutlich seltener. Im weiteren Ausbau aber schon. Es ist wichtig, dass wir weiter im Dialog bleiben, gute L√∂sungen finden und diese vor allem: Umsetzen. Was denkt Ihr dar√ºber?

Die Energiewirtschaft steht vor gewaltigen Herausforderungen, aber auch vor gro√üen Chancen durch innovative Konzepte. Nach meinen drei Lieblingsprojekten wurde ich heute beim Panel-Talk mit Bundesumweltminister Carsten Schneider im Rahmen des BDEW Bundesverband der Energie- und Wasserwirtschaft e.V. Kongresses gefragt. Diese drei Innovationen sind ein wichtiger Beitrag zum Neustart der Energiewende:1. Digital Twins: Sie k√∂nnen Netzzust√§nde in Echtzeit abbilden und somit mehr Transparenz √ºber Netzanschlusskapazit√§ten zur Verf√ºgung stellen. Verf√ºgbare Netzkapazit√§ten k√∂nnen so unkompliziert online angefragt werden. Dies erm√∂glicht eine effizientere und schnellere Steuerung von Netzanschlussbegehren. 2. Einspeisesteckdose: In zwei Pilotprojekten in Bayern stellen wir proaktiv Netzkapazit√§t zur Verf√ºgung, zum Beispiel in Form eines neuen Trafos oder Umspannwerkes. Diese freie Kapazit√§t schreiben wir dann in einem diskriminierungsfreien Verfahren aus und k√∂nnen die Ansiedelung von Erneuerbaren Energien und Speichern so teils netzgerecht steuern.3. √úberbauung: Das ist ja ein bekanntes Konzept, das wir jetzt umsetzen. Hinter dem Netzanschlusspunkt vergeben wir mehr Kapazit√§t als Folge einer sinnvollen Kombination aus Wind, PV und Speichern. Das Resultat: wir sparen Anschlussleistung ohne viel Energiemenge zu verlieren. Und wir nutzen bestehende Infrastruktur effizienter aus. Weitere innovative Konzepte wurden an unserem E.ON Stand vorgestellt, gemeinsam mit Bayernwerk MITNETZ STROM Westenergie E.ON One E.ON Deutschland und das E.ON Lab. Zum Beispiel haben die Kollegen dort den Bordsteinlader pr√§sentiert, mit dem E-Autos ganz unkompliziert direkt am Bordstein geladen werden k√∂nnen. Doch all das reicht nicht aus, wenn die Rahmenbedingungen nicht mitziehen. Wir brauchen dringend politische Unterst√ºtzung. Mein Appell an die Bundesregierung: Lassen Sie uns Innovationen in der Energiewirtschaft vorantreiben! Vereinfachen Sie Planungs- und Genehmigungsverfahren drastisch, damit diese zukunftsweisenden Technologien nicht nur Ideen bleiben, sondern m√∂glichst bald Realit√§t werden.

Deutschland steht nicht f√ºr Stillstand ‚Äì im Gegenteil. Millionen Menschen in unserem Land beweisen t√§glich Innovationskraft und Engagement. Doch eine √ºberholte Arbeitskultur bremst dieses Potenzial aus.Mich interessiert: Wie muss sich unsere Arbeitskultur ver√§ndern, damit Mitarbeitende wieder ihr Bestes geben k√∂nnen? Diese Frage habe ich meiner LinkedIn Community gestellt. Die R√ºckmeldungen waren voller wertvoller Impulse:üîπ Vertrauen und psychologische Sicherheit: Mitarbeitende w√ºnschen sich ein Arbeitsumfeld, in dem offener Dialog und das Lernen aus Fehlern selbstverst√§ndlich sind.üîπ Mehr Eigenverantwortung statt l√§hmender B√ºrokratie: Oft bremsen komplizierte Genehmigungsprozesse und ‚ÄûBack-to-back"-Meetings aus. Die Kunst liegt in der Balance: Schnelle, pragmatische Entscheidungswege, die Eigenverantwortung f√∂rdern und zugleich notwendige Governance sicherstellen.üîπ Wertsch√§tzung, die wirklich ankommt: Nicht Lob um des Lobes willen, sondern echte Anerkennung - f√ºr gute Ideen, f√ºr Einsatz, f√ºr Entwicklung.üîπ F√ºhrung, die zuh√∂rt und erkl√§rt: Transparenz in Entscheidungen, Mut zu kritischen Diskussionen, klare Erkl√§rungen des "Warum". So schaffen wir die Basis f√ºr eine neue Arbeitskultur, die Menschen zum Mitgestalten motiviert.Was hei√üt das f√ºr mich?Wenn wir in Deutschland produktiver werden wollen, gibt es viele Hebel ‚Äì von einer Reform des Steuersystems √ºber den Ausbau der Vollzeitarbeit und den Zuzug qualifizierter Arbeitskr√§fte und bis zur konsequenten Nutzung von KI. Vor allem aber brauchen wir einen Kulturwandel. Einen, der B√ºrokratie abbaut und Eigenverantwortung st√§rkt. Einen, der Mitarbeitende durch ehrgeizige Visionen und inspirierenden Erfindergeist dazu motiviert, ein aktiver Teil des Fortschritts zu sein.Meinen vollst√§ndigen ‚ÄûDeep Dive‚Äú zur Arbeitskultur in Deutschland mit Fakten und Einsch√§tzungen gibt es in meinem LinkedIn-Artikel.

We are advancing the next stage of the hydrogen value chain: Together with Uniper, thyssenkrupp Uhde is developing one of the world‚Äôs first demonstration plants for industrial hashtag#ammoniacracking ‚Äì a key technology for the global hydrogen economy that¬†strengthens energy security and the sustainable transformation of energy-intensive industries. Ammonia is a great vector to transport hashtag#hydrogen and already benefits from a well-established global infrastructure. By cracking ammonia back into nitrogen and hydrogen at the point of use, it‚Äôs possible to unlock a cost-efficient and scalable pathway to supply clean hydrogen to industries such as energy, steel, and chemicals ‚Äì exactly where it‚Äôs needed.The plant will be built at Uniper‚Äôs site in Gelsenkirchen and is funded by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Industry, Climate Protection, and Energy of North Rhine-Westphalia. It marks a crucial step toward large-scale implementation and hydrogen import terminals like the one planned in Wilhelmshaven. This success is driven by our hashtag#GENERATIONTK, under the leadership of Nadja H√•kansson. Their deep expertise in ammonia technology and plant engineering makes this project not only technically sound, but also future-proof. Congrats!¬†üëè

Visiting the wind turbine testing facility in √òsterild, Denmark, feels a bit like stepping onto the proving grounds of the wind industry. It was impressive to see your expertise up close.

As they say, all good things must come to an end! This year‚Äôs hashtag#PowerSummit25 marked my final one as President of Eurelectric - a moment to reflect on an extraordinary two and a half years. 1. We were forced to challenge all our assumptions. Almost overnight we could no longer take peace in Europe, cheap energy from Russia and a stable energy transition for granted. Eurelectric found itself at the centre of these shifting realities, stepping up with concrete solutions to the day‚Äôs urgent challenges. 2. We didn‚Äôt just react, we anticipated. Amid all the urgent problem-solving, we kept our eyes on the horizon applying a different lens on infrastructure and energy security.‚ÄØ Our Grids for Speed study showed that a well-developed power grid has an lesser societal cost than an under-invested grid. And our Security of Supply study, launched on the margins of the Munich Security Conference, offered a new holistic way to look at energy security in Europe ‚Äì placing electricity at the heart of Europe‚Äôs strategy. 3. We do well if Europe does well. Throughout, we worked to stay close to EU decision-making ‚Äî not just for the good of our industry, but for Europe‚Äôs broader prosperity and resilience. I would like to extend a special thanks to Kristian Ruby and the passionate team at Eurelectric, and to the two Vice Presidents Markus Rauramo and Georgios Stassis, for all of the great team work. Congratulations to Markus on his appointment as the new President, to Giorgios for another term and to Catherine Fiamma MacGregor for joining the team as Vice President! Working together in the power sector is truly a powerful thing. It‚Äôs been a privilege.

"WHAT'S NEXT?" That‚Äôs the question every graduate faces.Recently, I had a full circle moment at the FAU Erlangen-N√ºrnberg Physics graduation ceremony, reuniting with my former mentor, G√ºnter Ries. Took me right back to when I was sitting there at FAU, head full of questions (and physics formulas üòÖ), wondering about my next steps. To all the fresh physics grads out there: üëâ It's not just about E=mc¬≤ üëâ It's not just about quantum mechanics üëâ It's about developing a MINDSETBecause physics teaches you to: üß† Think differently üí° Solve the impossible üöÄ Divide the relevant from the irrelevant So, wherever you're heading, remember: Every great journey starts with that same question - "What's next?"

Did you know that I was a footballer? To be honest, at some point I realised I wasn't talented enough to make a career out of it. But football still has a place in my heart. Both teams built up great performance recently with different strategies. At the end, PSG formed on top of it a star team - being before ‚Äûonly‚Äú a team of stars. And they were more ready in the moment of truth. All this we can transfer to our business:üí° It's not enough to hire a lot of top talent. We need to build a star team to turn potential into performance. This is how we will win our ‚ÄúChampions League‚Äù by outperforming our peers üòâ I would love to hear your thoughts on this question: What else can we do to outperform? Are there any parallels with sport?

Never assume loud means strong and quiet means weak.I used to think the loudest voice was the strongest. But over time, I noticed something different.The people who made the biggest impact didn‚Äôt raise their voices‚Äîthey listened, thought carefully, and spoke with intention. And when they did, people leaned in. Not because they were loud, but because they were clear, calm, and meaningful.We often mistake noise for confidence and silence or calmness for uncertainty. Some of the strongest voices on your team may be the quietest. Make space for them. Listen to them. Give them your trust and offer them psychological safety to speak up.The same goes for data. Especially in today‚Äôs VUCA world, it‚Äôs often the subtle, qualitative, so-called weak signals that can trigger meaningful trends ‚Äì and not the noisy strong data. To spot the meaningful weak signals, we also need a culture of trust‚Äîwhere people feel psychologically safe to share insights, speak up, even when they argue with weak signals. How are you dealing with this subject? Please share your thoughts in the comments below.

The world has always faced times of uncertainty. Ours is no different ‚Äì but what stands out today is that uncertainty cuts across every domain: geopolitics, economy, security, climate, and society.It‚Äôs in this context that we‚Äôre preparing for the next ONS Conference in 2026, under the theme of Courage. In my role as Head of the Strategy Committee, I‚Äôm enCouraged by this choice.Courage means putting your heart into something difficult. It‚Äôs about leading through complexity and choosing action even when the outcome is uncertain.Energy will be one of the central elements we need to address ‚Äì sometimes as part of the problem, more often as a key to the solution. That‚Äôs why ONS 2026 will be more cross-cutting than ever ‚Äì because the challenges we face can‚Äôt be tackled in silos.At ONS 2026, we want to channel the courage it takes to face difficult truths, embrace new technologies, and make decisions that will help shape the next era of energy.I‚Äôm very much looking forward to the conversations ahead.

This is good news for patients and physicians everywhere in the world, especially in underserved regions: The World Health Assembly, the decision-making body of the World Health Organization, approved a resolution to strengthen medical imaging capacity. ü©ªüöÄIn a nutshell: This resolution addresses the issue of global equity in access to imaging, recognizing that medical imaging is vital for the diagnosis and treatment of numerous diseases, injuries and other health conditions. Thus, it urges the WHO member states "to promote appropriate and continued access to quality, safe, affordable and cost-effective medical imaging capacity, by implementing appropriate policies, strategies, programmes, norms and standards".While the decisions of the World Health Assembly are not legally binding, they carry significant political and strategic influence. We at Siemens Healthineers welcome this decision wholeheartedly and with great confidence in its added value for patients. We stand ready to support our customers and partners in its implementation. Its essence precisely captures the purpose of our company that drives us every day: We pioneer breakthroughs in healthcare ‚Äì for everyone, everywhere, sustainably.hashtag#WHA78

Vor 30 Jahren wurde aus der Deutschen Bundespost Telekom die Deutsche Telekom AG. Beharrlichkeit hat uns in den vergangen drei Jahrzehnten zur wertvollsten Marke Europas und zur wertvollsten TelCo Marke der Welt gemacht. Diese Beharrlichkeit legen wir auch beim Thema hashtag#Nachhaltigkeit an den Tag. Seit Beginn haben wir den Anspruch, nachhaltig zu wirtschaften ‚Äì und zwar aus √úberzeugung, weil es auch wirtschaftlich sinnvoll ist. Unser Auftrag ist es, die Telekom als erfolgreiches, nachhaltiges Unternehmen zu f√ºhren, immer im Zusammenspiel von √ñkonomie, √ñkologie und Gesellschaft.  Daher verfolgen wir weiterhin unsere ehrgeizigen Klimaziele. Bis 2040 streben wir Netto-Null-Emissionen entlang unserer gesamten Wertsch√∂pfungskette an. Ein gro√üer Meilenstein zur gr√ºnen Telko ist bereits in Sicht: Wir sind auf Kurs zur hashtag#Klimaneutralit√§t im eigenen Betrieb f√ºr 2025. Unser Erfolg beruht darauf, dass wir als globales Unternehmen Dinge bewerten und diskutieren, bevor wir sie umsetzen. Doch in der digitalen Welt wird es immer schwieriger, Sachverhalte zu beurteilen. Die zunehmende Verbreitung von Desinformation im Netz hat daran einen Anteil. Als Deutsche Telekom arbeiten wir mit vielen Partnern und gemeinn√ºtzigen Organisationen an der St√§rkung eines kompetenten Umgangs mit digitalen Medien. So setzen wir uns schon im f√ºnften Jahr im Rahmen unserer Initiative ‚ÄûGegen Hass im Netz‚Äú f√ºr bewussten Umgang und gegen Ausgrenzung oder Hate Speech ein. Auch unsere Mitarbeitenden st√§rken mit ihrem Einsatz den gesellschaftlichen Zusammenhalt. So haben Telekom-Mitarbeitende im Jahr 2024 mehr als 200.000 Freiwilligenstunden f√ºr ehrenamtliches Engagement geleistet. Wirtschaftlich und gesellschaftlich sind wir als hashtag#Marke und als Unternehmen etabliert. Erfolg ist bei uns aber kein Selbstzweck. Er basiert auf einer Kultur, die Ehrgeiz, Neugierde, Vielfalt, Respekt und Integrit√§t ernst nimmt. Diese Kultur und unser Wertesystem sind unsere Leitplanken. Unser CR-Bericht, der heute erschienen ist, verdeutlicht all das. Und er zeigt vor allem eines: Wer die Zukunft gestalten will, hat keine Angst vor Ver√§nderung. Darin liegt die Kraft eines Unternehmens, das nach 30 Jahren sagt: Das Beste kommt noch. Mit 30 geht es doch erst richtig los! hashtag#Telekom hashtag#CR hashtag#GCR hashtag#corporateresponsibility hashtag#engagement hashtag#gegenhassimnetz hashtag#CRBericht hashtag#LinkedInDachNews

The Economist‚Äôs latest cover story is titled ‚ÄúThe remarkable rise of Poland‚Äù. Having just returned from Warsaw, I want to echo that sentiment.In the 90s, Poland‚Äôs energy mix was nearly synonymous with coal. A lot has changed since then. As of April 2025, coal accounted for less than half of the country‚Äôs electricity generation ‚Äì a first in its history. By 2030, wind and solar are expected to produce more than half of Poland's electricity. Gas remains a central pillar ‚Äì ensuring reliability as renewables scale ‚Äì and nuclear is being considered as a serious part of the long-term mix.This isn‚Äôt just a national story. As Europe‚Äôs fifth-largest energy market, Poland plays a key role in building a more integrated and resilient European energy system.Last week, I had the chance to meet with government leaders, customers and partners in Poland to talk about the path ahead ‚Äì and how we can help shape it. From modernizing infrastructure to enabling cleaner generation, we‚Äôre proud to be contributing.And above all, thank you to our incredible hashtag#TeamPurple in Poland. Hearing how your work is driving this transformation was a real highlight.Dziƒôkujƒô ‚Äì and keep it up.Siemens Energy Grzegorz Nalezyty

Shadowing the CEO of Siemens?! üëÄüß≠Johannes Gr√∂schel from Siemens Mobility just got two days of an inside look at what a CEO's day-to-day really entails - from strategy sessions and meeting customers to media recordings, and everything in between.I have to say, Johannes, you kept up the pace remarkably well‚Ä¶üòâ Impressed by your ability to jump right in, ask insightful questions, and contribute meaningful ideas. hashtag#TeamSiemens

üò± Only 21% of employees worldwide were engaged at work in 2024 (Gallup). That‚Äôs not just a number ‚Äî it‚Äôs a wake-up call for leaders everywhere.Leaders need to self-reflect and to train! And exactly that‚Äôs what we do at our Talanx Executive Campus at WHU ‚Äì Otto Beisheim School of Management in D√ºsseldorf. I recently joined a group of colleagues from across Talanx Group in one of the sessions under the motto: ‚ÄúCulture is strategy.‚ÄùFact is, there are as many leadership styles as there are roads to Rome ‚Äî but there are some basic truths to all of them. And the destination is the same: Creating a hashtag#PerformanceCulture where people engage and thrive. Here‚Äôs what resonated with me:üîπ Culture is strategy: Culture drives performance and is hard to imitate. Alignment on common values is key in legacy organisations. Values must be clear, and consistently lived every day. Leadership starts with yourself - be curious and reflect honestly.üîπ Psychological safety and trust: You have two ears and one mouth ‚Äì listen more than you speak and listen to understand. Have a positive attitude towards people, give them autonomy. But responsibility and accountability should go together, too. The most important words of leadership: Thank you! üîπ Networked leadership: In today‚Äôs complex world, formal power isn‚Äôt enough. Listen to weak signals everywhere. Informal power by expertise or friendship must be considered as well. Get excellent people around you to leverage yourself in order to outperform.üîπ Confidence: Positive comes from positive üòâThank you to Prof. Dr. Martin Hoegl, Matthias M√∂lleney, Yuval Kalish for your insights, and thanks to Raha Anssari, Katharina Piening and Sarah Wiegmann for organising the event. And of course, thanks to all participants for the inspiring exchange!I firmly believe that culture is strategy ‚Äî and it fuels performance. I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts on this subject in the comments below!
