In the last 8 months, I've had conversations in the Ruhr region, Germany, and beyond with various stakeholders including employees, politicians, and investors. Today, at thyssenkrupp's 25th Annual General Meeting, I continued this dialogue alongside Klaus Keysberg, Oliver Burkhard, Ilse Henne, Volkmar Dinstuhl, and Siegfried Russwurm, discussing our strengths and weaknesses openly with shareholders. It must be possible to clearly voice the fact that we at thyssenkrupp cannot continue the way we have up to now. Some will find that hard to accept. It also creates friction, as has been clearly evident again in recent days. But to ignore the fact that the company cannot go on as usual would be irresponsible. And that is why it is indispensable to talk about this issue truthfully. üìà: Our mission is clear: we must transform thyssenkrupp for profitable growth. We possess the necessary ingredients - a global influence, exceptional employees, and cutting-edge technologies. We now need to better convert our technical expertise into economic success. üí∞ Financially, we've seen positive cash flow and slight operational improvements in 2022/23, with rising stock recommendations. Despite a net loss, we're paying dividends, maintaining continuity. Our goals for 2024/25 are ambitious but achievable, focusing on enhancing business performance through our performance program APEX. üîç Portfolio-wise, we successfully listed nucera and are now focusing on the future of thyssenkrupp Steel and thyssenkrupp Marine Systems. Our commitment to decarbonization and partnerships, like the potential joint venture with EPH, is strong. We‚Äôre also exploring Marine Systems' independence, backed by government support. üå± Leading the green transformation, we prioritize climate-friendly technologies. Our Decarbon Technologies segment is at the forefront, with initiatives like thyssenkrupp rothe erde‚Äôs slewing bearings for wind turbines, and thyssenkrupp nucera as well as thyssenkrupp Uhde shaping European hydrogen economy. Our thyssenkrupp Polysius team is transforming cement production to reduce CO2 emissions. But that's not all: our teams at thyssenkrupp Automotive with products for the mobility of tomorrow and thyssenkrupp Materials Services with digital solutions for sustainable supply chains are also enabling the green transformation in their fields. ü§ù My sincere thanks to hashtag#GENERATIONTK for your relentless efforts. We're more than just technical experts; we're a team driven to score and win. It's time to get on the field, attack, and score big! We want to unleash the strengths that thyssenkrupp boasts, leverage the potential of our technologies and market them successfully. We are doing this on behalf of you, our owners. To increase the value of your investments and in the certainty that we are acting in the interests of our employees and in line with the importance of our company for the region and the world.

Yesterday's CEO Alliance meeting in Lund, Sweden, proved once again how innovative we can be in Europe when we think big together! To kick off the meeting, we visited the European Spallation Source. It is one of the largest and most powerful proton accelerator based neutron sources ever built ‚Äì a pan-European project involving 13 European nations. ¬†With this spirit, we then moved on to the meeting agenda that included formulating our expectations of the European Commission and the Green Deal: Hold the Line! A united and innovative Europe is capable of great things!

Individuals are increasingly prioritizing environmentally conscious behaviors in their daily lives. What some may not be aware of: this change is also driven by the economy. The chemical industry, for example, is taking responsibility and showing a keen interest in reducing #plastic waste.This shift is not just an obligation to preserve the environment, nature, and climate. It is also an economic necessity. Waste ‚Äì and particularly used plastic ‚Äì needs to be seen as a valuable raw material. It mustn't be simply thrown away but should serve as a starting point to produce new products. Products that are needed to make our everyday lives more sustainable.That's why the plastics industry is pushing for a circular economy. At Covestro, we pursue a long-term vision: to become #FullyCircular throughout the company. This means that all our management decisions are geared towards this goal. We are exploring alternative raw materials, investing in renewable energy, developing new recycling technologies, and partnering with other stakeholders to create an effective circular value chain.The #CircularEconomy must become a global guiding principle. To get there, we need support from policymakers. They must set the direction, create the right conditions, and provide the incentives for businesses and consumers to adopt circular economy principles. #ChemicalRecycling, for example, is as a promising new technology that needs to be enhanced.But that's still not all: to truly make a difference, we need an open and constructive discourse on plastics, their role in our everyday lives, their relevance for our sustainable future ‚Äì and their #FullyCircular transformation.The many comments on my previous post on the topic show that there is a great interest in this discourse and a thirst for information. I'm looking forward to continuing to contribute to this conversation, exchanging ideas, and providing insights.#RethinkIndustry #PlasticsIndustry

At the Telekom Management Team Meeting, I spoke to our 800 executives of Deutsche Telekom about radical transparency. Plato's allegory of the cave helped me. We at Deutsche Telekom also sometimes sit in our "magenta cave". Because we hide realities. Because we are not transparent in our feedback. Or because we don't know what's happening elsewhere in the Group - no wonder, with such a large organisation. That's why it's important to me that each of us leaves the cave. This gives us a different view of the world, new experiences and new insights. But we also need to return to our cave and share this information and our knowledge. In short: be transparent. That is our duty, our responsibility. Then we can also make the right decisions.¬†¬†In addition to my colleagues of the Board of Management, I invited many guests to openly discuss transparency and the use of artificial intelligence. A personal highlight was the talk with Mike Sievert and Meredith Whittaker. Their Signal Foundation has developed a messenger for secure private communication. Signal does not monitor conversations and data. The inputs on artificial intelligence from Sebastian Thrun, Henning Beck and Mona Sloane, Ph.D. were also exciting. We often have a tendency not to do things out of fear and caution. Instead, we should integrate new technologies and develop products further in order to utilise all the possibilities. I am convinced that we should all use AI and (learn to) use it responsibly. We must not sit back and relax when it comes to these developments, but must remain constantly vigilant. This is the only way we can bring the future and our strategy - to become the leading digital telco - together.¬†Fabian Riaz was a great musical finale to the long day. In 2018, he not only turned customers into his fans, but also the TV viewers of Voice of Germany. That shows: We have many hidden talents, including many we don't yet know about üòâA big thank you to everyone involved for making TMTM 2024 such an experience once again.#Telekom #telekomwall #transparency #leading #tmtm

Mit unseren 800 F√ºhrungskr√§ften der Deutsche Telekom habe ich beim Telekom Management Team Meeting √ºber radikale Transparenz gesprochen. Dabei half mir das H√∂hlengleichnis von Platon. Auch wir in der Telekom sitzen manchmal in unserer ‚ÄûMagenta H√∂hle‚Äú. Weil wir Realit√§ten ausblenden. Weil wir bei unserem Feedback nicht transparent sind. Oder weil wir nicht wissen, was an anderen Stellen im Konzern passiert ‚Äì kein Wunder, bei so einer gro√üen Organisation. Deswegen ist es mir wichtig, dass jeder von uns die H√∂hle verl√§sst. Dadurch bekommen wir einen anderen Blick auf die Welt, machen neue Erfahrungen und gewinnen neue Erkenntnisse. Wir m√ºssen aber auch in unsere H√∂hle zur√ºckkehren und diese Informationen und unser Wissen teilen. Kurz: transparent sein. Das ist unsere Pflicht, unsere Verantwortung. Dann k√∂nnen wir auch die richtigen Entscheidungen treffen.  Neben meinen Vorstandskolleg*innen habe ich viele G√§ste eingeladen, um offen √ºber Transparenz und den Einsatz von K√ºnstlicher Intelligenz zu diskutieren. Ein pers√∂nliches Highlight war der Talk mit Mike Sievert und Meredith Whittaker. Ihre Signal-Stiftung hat einen Messenger f√ºr die sichere private Kommunikation entwickelt. Signal √ºberwacht keine Unterhaltungen und Daten. Spannend waren auch die Inputs zu K√ºnstlicher Intelligenz von Sebastian Thrun, Henning Beck und Mona Sloane, Ph.D.. Wir unterliegen oft einer Tendenz, Dinge nicht zu tun, aus Angst, aus Vorsicht. Stattdessen sollten wir neue Technologien integrieren und Produkte weiterentwickeln, um alle M√∂glichkeiten auszusch√∂pfen. Ich bin √ºberzeugt: Jeder von uns sollte KI anwenden und verantwortungsbewusst mit ihr umgehen (lernen). Wir d√ºrfen uns bei diesen Entwicklungen nicht zur√ºcklehnen, sondern m√ºssen st√§ndig aufmerksam bleiben. Nur so k√∂nnen wir die Zukunft und unsere Strategie ‚Äì f√ºhrende digitale Telko zu werden ‚Äì zusammenzubringen. Ein toller musikalischer Abschluss des langen Tages war Fabian Riaz. 2018 machte er nicht nur Kunden zu seinen Fans, sondern auch die TV-Zuschauer bei Voice of Germany. Das zeigt: Wir haben viele verborgene Talente, auch viele, von denen wir noch nichts wissen.¬†üòâEin herzliches Dankesch√∂n an alle Beteiligten, die das TMTM auch 2024 wieder zu einem solchen Erlebnis gemacht haben.hashtag#Telekom hashtag#telekomwall hashtag#transparency hashtag#leading hashtag#tmtm

How do we generate power when the sun does not shine and the wind does not blow? How can we store energy more efficiently? And how can we do more with less? These were just some of the questions we touched upon in yesterday's visit to Europe's largest research infrastructure for renewable energies at the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT). Here, students, companies, and scientists are researching energy generation, storage, and supply options of the future. I am very proud that we at Siemens Energy have partnered up with the Research Center to study and simulate the energy system by means of real-world laboratories. What is being built here is incredibly important, as it combines the two fundamentals that drive innovation: technology and people. It is estimated that 35% of all emissions savings needed to reach net zero by 2050 will come from technologies not yet on the market. Inspiring and encouraging the next generation to be part of engineering solutions is therefore not just something to be hopeful about, but absolutely necessary if we want to make the energy transition a success.  It was also a pleasure to spend the afternoon with our Team Purple in Karlsruhe yesterday. Thank you to everyone who took the time to join the Town Hall ‚Äì it was great to see you all in person and I appreciated the open discussion.

Deutschland fehlt ein Gesamtkonzept f√ºr einen wettbewerbsf√§higen Strompreis. Eine Strukturreform des Strommarktes muss her.Unser Grundproblem ist, dass wir nicht ausreichend Strom haben, um den Strompreis zu senken. Hinzu kommen strukturelle Herausforderungen: Der Netzausbau hinkt hinterher und ist relativ teuer. Die geplante Anpassung von Geb√ºhren und Entgelten f√ºhrt nicht zu einer erhofften Entlastung.Was wir brauchen, ist eine Strukturreform des Strommarktes. Wir m√ºssen den Netzausbau st√§rker zu einer hoheitlichen Aufgabe machen. Dann k√∂nnen wir das riesige, dringend notwendige Investitionsvolumen tats√§chlich stemmen ‚Äì und zwar abgesichert. Au√üerdem m√ºssen wir das Stromangebot erh√∂hen, um die Preise zu senken. Da fehlt es uns derzeit vor allem an grundlastf√§hige Energieformen, denn der dringend ben√∂tigte Zubau von Gaskraftwerken hinkt hinterher.#Energiewende

Deutschland hat ein Kapazit√§tsproblem. Aber die L√∂sung kann nicht ernsthaft der Ausstieg aus dem Kohleausstieg bis 2030 sein. Anstatt dessen ist es dringend geboten, perspektivisch einen technologieoffenen Kapazit√§tsmarkt zu entwickeln, der so liquide und berechenbar wie m√∂glich ist, massive Investitionen in Speichertechnologie anreizt und Flexibilit√§tspotentiale auf Nachfrageseite voll aussch√∂pft. Es geht hier um den Schutz vor erheblichen Versorgungsl√ºcken und nicht um ‚ÄûHartz4 f√ºr Kraftwerke‚Äú. Sigmar Gabriels wortgewordener Sargnagel hat lange gehalten, muss der neuen Energierealit√§t jetzt aber weichen.Deutschland hat ohne ein Gegensteuern auch ein Problem mit seinen Systemkosten. Der Netzausbau auf allen Spannungsebenen muss deshalb massiv forciert werden, verbunden mit einer Digitalisierungsoffensive. Es m√ºssen lokale Flexibilit√§ts-M√§rkte aufgebaut werden. Und der Ausbau der Erneuerbaren muss regional gesteuert werden. Deutschland hat zudem ebenso ein Problem, wenn die Wahrung der Energieinteressen nicht als eine der dringendsten Kernaufgaben der deutschen Au√üen-, Entwicklungs- und Sicherheitspolitik begriffen wird. Die Bundesregierung muss die Frage beantworten, wer unsere Partnerl√§nder sein k√∂nnen. Gerade im globalen S√ºden m√ºssen wir viel st√§rker unter energiestrategischen Aspekten auftreten. Und andere Aspekte m√ºssen dahinter zur√ºcktreten. Das waren Punkte, die mir vergangene Woche bei meinen vielen Gespr√§chen mit Journalisten besonders wichtig waren.

This week, I sat down with Richard Edelman, the leading authority on trust in institutions and in society, for a conversation with our global employee base about how we can do our part as Allianz to address the growing polarization that is undermining the effectiveness of democracies around the world. ¬†The developments we see, currently here in Germany but also around the world, reveal a deficit of trust resulting from people‚Äôs existential fears and lack of optimism about the future and their disappointment in how leaders are addressing their concerns. We answered questions from employees about why trust is so important for customers, which measures can be taken to regain trust between society and non-radical political leaders, how we as Allianz can leverage partnerships for action, and how trust can succeed in a competition for attention and truth. ¬†It was a candid and wide-ranging discussion, and at the end, Richard and I summarized the dialogue in just four words: ‚ÄúListen. Think. Act. Deliver.‚Äù ¬†Allianz will work to protect the freedoms that our people and customers value by mitigating the root causes of polarization and developing solutions that address the issues that are relevant to people. Business leaders are not elected leaders, and we know the limits of our scope, but the private sector can bring know-how, experience, and a customer and execution mindset to solve problems in ways that the public sector cannot. ¬†This is why the path forward will be forged by partnerships ‚Äì and alliances ‚Äì that founded on the principles of optimism and inclusion and guided by the compass of trust. ¬†Thank you again to Richard and the colleagues who participated in the conversation both live and online. ¬†Please find here Allianz's statement on recent developments in Germany and the growing polarization around the world: https://lnkd.in/dPBPKzDb#EdelmanTrustBarometer #Trust #Allianz

This seems paradoxical‚ÄØbut these are the facts. How is it possible and how can we turn the trend around?¬†¬†It is possible because on the one hand, the awareness for #CircularEconomy has risen in the past years. Companies and organizations have implemented goals and visions ‚Äì as did Covestro in 2020. We understand that the linear economy is at an impasse and that we need to transition to a circular model.¬†¬†But these shiny visions and goals are like a big vessel taking off. Circular solutions take time to develop. Plus, we must not forget that circular products need markets with consumers able and willing to pay (extra) for alternatives that tend to be more expensive, at least in the beginning.‚ÄØ¬†¬†At the same time, consumption has been on steady rise: In just the past six years humankind has consumed nearly as much as during the entire 20th century ‚Äì according to the Circularity Gap Report 2024.¬†¬†So, how do we turn this trend around? The Report suggests three levers which I consider sensible and tangible:¬†¬†1. Establish policies and legal frameworks ‚Äì incentivize circular practices¬†2. Get the economics right ‚Äì create conducive market environments for circular materials¬†3. Build circular expertise and skills ‚Äì as individuals and corporations¬†¬†And I would add a fourth point: Prompt people to reflect on our ways of living in an affluent society and explain why it is worth changing our consumption patterns.¬†¬†¬†At Covestro, we are doing our part by systematically transforming our production towards circularity: using clean energy and alternative (e.g., bio-based) raw materials, improving recyclability, and recycling, and building partnerships that tie the aforementioned together.¬†¬†We must tackle this major #CircularEconomy project with courage. Then we have the chance to create prosperity that is not based on ever-increasing resource consumption and pollution. I am confident that we will turn the trend around, together. #FullyCircular Circle Economy Foundation

This is one of the most widely spread misconceptions about #plastic. How do they arise? Mostly, they are driven by ideologies, bias, and false information. This is not surprising as we're living in a world where fake news are on the rise and social polarization makes consensus-oriented dialogue difficult.#EducationDay reminds us that education can help counter these challenges, fostering a fact-based worldview that promotes social unity and constructive discourse. To get there, we must better explain why education is relevant for all ‚Äì for any individual and for society as a whole. And it must be communicated in a way that resonates with the public, that whets the appetite.Science-oriented organizations and institutions can play a crucial role here: demonstrate the concrete value of research and science, exemplify the technological and societal progress emerging from it and highlight the importance of science education. For the sake of a fact-based, rational view on the world to foster the openness and togetherness we need so much.#InternationalDayOfEducation

The green transformation is one of the key tasks of our time. Its shaping requires a collective effort.¬†Joint action by industry, politics, science, NGOs and consumers is essential - across national borders. thyssenkrupp is part of this collaborative solution. We are driving the decarbonization of industry with our innovative future technologies. From our thyssenkrupp rothe erde slewing bearings in onshore and offshore wind turbines to our pioneering work in shaping the hydrogen economy through the teams of thyssenkrupp nucera and thyssenkrupp Uhde. Beyond individual technologies, we're transforming entire industries: revolutionizing plant engineering in the chemical and cement sectors, digitizing supply chains, and facilitating the mobility revolution.¬†¬†At the same time, green steel offers a huge lever for reducing CO2 emissions. It's crucial to highlight this: Accelerating the expansion of renewable energy is imperative to bring down energy costs to a competitive level.¬†The expansion of the electricity grid and hydrogen infrastructure also plays a decisive role in this, which we must create together with a framework set by politicians.Finding answers to these questions is essential. For hashtag#thyssenkrupp, Germany and Europe. Joint solutions always start with an exchange. I am therefore pleased to be part of this year's Handelsblatt Energy Summit in Berlin. Special thanks to Leo Birnbaum! The joint dialog on how the energy transition can be approached competitively was very enriching. I am confident that we all will succeed together! hashtag#HBEnergiecopyright: Handelsblatt Energie-Gipfel

We must not stand idly by and watch the rise of right-wing populism and polarization. Any form of social intolerance is attacking our democracy and our prosperity, which we must protect at all costs. I am a member of a global team of more than 150 nationalities at Siemens Energy. We are dependent on an open and inclusive society for our employees, customers and investors.¬†All major challenges, such as climate change or the flow of migration because of wealth disparities, are global. A return to nation-state thinking would be fatal ‚Äì especially in a year when more than half the world's population will take to the polls. I am convinced the vast majority in Germany, Europe and other countries see a real threat to our democracies. Europe is a guarantor of peace, stability, prosperity and the rule of law. We have nothing to gain from isolationism and xenophobia.¬†I was very encouraged to see the amount of people taking a stand both on the street and online over the weekend in Germany. But this cannot stop here. We must continue to say loud and clear: hatred and exclusion have no place in our country.¬†#takeastand #niewiederistjetzt

An alle, die teilgenommen haben: Es macht mich sehr stolz, ein Teil von hashtag#TeamHealthineers zu sein, das die Werte von Siemens Healthineers und die unserer hashtag#Demokratie so offen, klar und √ºberzeugend vertritt. Wir stehen ùêÖ√úùêë¬†Weltoffenheit, Toleranz, Respekt und Hilfsbereitschaft gegen√ºber allen Menschen ‚Äì unabh√§ngig von Hautfarbe, Kultur und Herkunft. Daher wenden wir uns mit aller Entschiedenheit ùêÜùêÑùêÜùêÑùêç Intoleranz, Rassismus oder politischen Extremismus jeder Art. √úber Grenzen, Kulturen und Nationen hinweg vereint unser Team in 75 L√§ndern ein gemeinsames Ziel: dass die Gesundheitsversorgung weltweit jeden Tag besser wird und mehr Menschen Zugang zu moderner Versorgung haben.

I was deeply moved by how many people took to the streets in Germany to demonstrate for our fundamental values in recent days. And I know many Siemens colleagues joined the marches. It is right and proper that we take a stand for a free and open society and speak out against right-wing extremism. I find talk of expelling people from Germany very worrying. It‚Äôs cynical and inhuman. I reject ‚Äì we at Siemens reject ‚Äì extremism, racism and discrimination in the strongest possible terms. We at Siemens ‚Äì more than 320,000 people from almost every country on earth ‚Äì stand for tolerance, openness and respect as well as diversity and inclusion ‚Äì fundamental humanitarian values enshrined in the German constitution. The beliefs of right-wing populists contradict these values. Right-wing extremism harms Germany and is a threat to its prosperity. This prosperity is based on progress and innovation, on openness and the exchange of ideas, on diversity and constancy ‚Äì and above all on creative and dedicated people. People who come here and want to contribute to society. This is the key to our success. This is why Germany is the third largest economy in the world.   There is no question that we are currently facing major challenges; economically, geopolitically and when it comes to climate change. There are no simple, easy answers. What‚Äôs clear is that we can only overcome these challenges together. A divided nation will gamble away the future.   Our social contract is based on freedom, peace and solidarity. This is what made Germany strong and resilient in recent decades, what brought us prosperity and raised our stature in the world. It is right and proper that we as a society now stand together and resolutely speaks out for our values.#NeverAgain #ForDiversity #Together #TeamSiemens

Es hat mich sehr bewegt, wie viele Menschen in diesen Tagen f√ºr unsere Grundwerte demonstriert haben. Ich wei√ü, darunter waren auch viele Kolleginnen und Kollegen von Siemens. Es ist gut und wichtig, dass wir uns f√ºr ein offenes, freies Deutschland einsetzen und uns klar gegen Rechtsextremismus stellen. Ich bin sehr besorgt √ºber die √úberlegungen, Menschen aus Deutschland zu vertreiben. Ich halte das f√ºr zynisch und menschenverachtend. Extremismus, Rassismus und Diskriminierung lehne ich, lehnen wir bei Siemens aufs Sch√§rfste ab. Wir bei Siemens ‚Äì √ºber 320.000 Menschen, die in fast allen L√§ndern dieser Welt zu Hause sind und ebenso viele Nationen repr√§sentieren ‚Äì stehen f√ºr Respekt, Toleranz, Offenheit sowie Vielfalt und Teilhabe ‚Äì Grundwerte der Menschlichkeit, wie sie auch die Verfassung der Bundesrepublik Deutschland ausdr√ºckt. Die Haltung der Rechtspopulisten widerspricht allen diesen Grundwerten. Rechtsextremismus schadet unserem Land und gef√§hrdet unseren Wohlstand. Unser Wohlstand gr√ºndet sich auf Fortschritt und Innovation, auf Austausch und Offenheit, Vielfalt und Verl√§sslichkeit ‚Äì und vor allem auf kreative und engagierte Menschen. Auch Menschen, die zu uns kommen und sich und ihre F√§higkeiten einbringen wollen. Auch deshalb ist Deutschland die drittgr√∂√üte Volkswirtschaft der Welt. Wir stehen derzeit vor gro√üen Herausforderungen, keine Frage. Wirtschaftlich, geopolitisch, der Klimawandel. Einfache, vor allem bequeme Antworten, gibt es hier nicht. F√ºr uns ist aber klar: Wir meistern diese Herausforderungen nur gemeinsam. Als gespaltenes Land verspielen wir unsere Zukunft. Unser Zusammenleben gr√ºndet sich auf Freiheit, Frieden und Solidarit√§t. Das hat Deutschland in den vergangenen Jahrzehnten stark und widerstandsf√§hig gemacht und hohes Ansehen in der ganzen Welt gebracht. Es ist wichtig und ermutigend, dass wir als Gesellschaft nun gemeinsam aufstehen und entschlossen f√ºr unsere Werte eintreten. hashtag#NieWiederIstJetzt hashtag#f√ºrVielfalt hashtag#TeamSiemens

As the snow starts to spread across Europe, it‚Äôs now that our heating transition really begins to warm up! Whether it‚Äôs households, businesses or municipalities, heating, decarbonised heating, comes into stark focus when the temperature drops and the jumpers come out. Last week I had the pleasure of visiting Queen‚Äôs Medical Centre in Nottingham, one of the UK‚Äôs largest hospitals and home to an ambitious partnership where E.ON will support QMC‚Äôs ambition to become Net Zero by 2038. A crucial part of that? Building and supplying a new heating and cooling network powered by heat pumps and backed up with flexible storage. The project demonstrates an exciting dynamic between public and private sector partnership and shows what can really be done if we have the right instruments in place. Municipalities and public sector buildings face their own unique decarbonisation challenges, but with that also comes opportunities: I‚Äôm excited to see the progress of this particular project! The heating transition is clearly not the easiest but a crucial part of the decarbonisation. So we at E.ON  don‚Äôt shy away from taking the bull by the horns. According to the European Environment Agency, the buildings sector accounts for 35% of energy related emissions in the EU1 - if in Europe we fail to tackle this head on then we also fail to meet our Net Zero target.¬†#energytransition #heatingtransition

Attending this week‚Äôs World Economic Forum (WEF) was once again a worthwhile experience for me, as I had the opportunity to engage with leaders across various sectors and viewpoints from various perspectives. What I experienced was a spirit of pragmatic optimism and determination to work together to solve the major challenges of our times, from climate change to digital advancement. But the atmosphere in Davos was also influenced by the reality increasing detachment between political leaders and the people who elect them. These issues have an intrinsic connection with the findings of the just-released Allianz Risk Barometer 2024, which sheds light on critical risks impacting businesses around the world. The growing divide between the political elite and their citizens emerges as the number one risk to modern society, posing a risk to global stability and further diminishing trust in governments. Business growth relies on political stability. Business leaders are not elected officials, but our organizations play a pivotal role in addressing polarization and enabling economic stabilization. And, regarding progress, the 2024 Edelman Trust Barometer indicates that business is most trusted to integrate innovations into society ‚Äì at a time when people are more likely to embrace an innovation if they are confident it will lead to a better future.The theme of this year‚Äôs WEF was aptly ‚Äúrebuilding trust.‚Äù In my view, this starts with leaders being transparent and honest about the scale of the challenges we face, both economically and in terms of the costs and lifestyle changes required for necessary transformations. From decarbonization to responsible AI to inflation and pension reform, today‚Äôs global challenges are opportunities if public and private leaders collaborate on practical solutions that improve the quality of life for all citizens. I believe that the discussions at WEF over the past week have reinforced the urgency for a collaborative, solution-oriented approach. But we must come down from the top of the mountain and bring that spirit back into action - in our boardrooms, workplaces, and communities, showing people that we listen and care about their concerns.At Allianz, we know that we alone cannot solve all the world's problems. This is why we champion collaboration and partnerships to enable collective action. We are confident that the solutions to managing today‚Äôs risks also present opportunities for discovery, innovation, and investment. Our chances of restoring public trust are significantly improved when we work together.I am eager to hear your key takeaways from this year‚Äôs WEF and learn how your organization is helping to restore trust in your community? We‚Äôre in this together. ¬†#WEF2024 #Allianz

Das Denken und Handeln auf der Grundlage von #Fakten ist von entscheidender Bedeutung f√ºr den Erhalt unserer Demokratie, f√ºr ein friedliches Miteinander und f√ºr die erfolgreiche Transformation in eine nachhaltige Welt.¬†#ZukunftBrauchtWahrheit WirtschaftsWoche Handelsblatt Solutions by HANDELSBLATT MEDIA GROUP

A busy week at the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting in Davos has come to an end. Four things stood out to me from my meetings with politicians, industry experts, and business leaders:‚û°Ô∏è This year will be crucial regarding developments in geopolitics. The recent elections in Taiwan, the upcoming EU elections, and the race for the White House all define our future alliances, trade relationships, and policies. While this puts a lot of focus on 2024, we must ensure that we do not lose sight of our long-term goals. ‚û°Ô∏è¬†Because the fight against climate change is the central task of our time. Just last year, the cost of natural disasters because of climate change amounted to 250 billion euros. 66% of respondents to the WEF‚Äôs recently published Global Risk Report named extreme weather the greatest risk society faces today. The success of the energy transition is primarily a question of implementation. It requires the right technologies, political will, and social acceptance. ‚û°Ô∏è No matter where you looked at Davos, the topic of Artificial Intelligence was ever-present. I fully believe that people working in unison with AI have the potential to revolutionize industries, improve efficiencies, and enhance our quality of lifet, if its immense potential is embedded in a framework of values. It is important to keep in mind that today, data centers consume four to five percent of global energy consumption. With AI being implemented into our daily lives, there are estimates that consumption will rise to 30 percent in the next few years. Which brings me to my last point:‚û°Ô∏è The importance of the grid is increasingly being recognized. However, there is growing concern that it could become a bottleneck in our transition towards a more digital and electrified world. As the demand for reliable, efficient, and sustainable power intensifies, the potential for grid constraints also rises. It is imperative that we not only maintain and upgrade our grids but also innovate and invest in solutions that expand their capacity. This is key to preventing infrastructure failures, managing the surge in demand effectively, and facilitating a successful transition towards a more sustainable future.I would be interested to know: for those following the happenings in Davos, what do you think were the most important issues being discussed?¬†#WEF24 #Davos #EnergyTransition #ArtificialIntelligence

As I sit on the train ride home from #Davos, I would like to share a few ‚Äì or rather a lot by the look of things üòâ ‚Äì reflections from a week of meaningful and actionable exchanges and encounters and what they mean for us at Siemens Healthineers. #wef24

Yes, we do live in turbulent times.  But we have a choice on how to deal with the challenges we face.  We can look the other way and pretend that post-fascist ideas are not, in fact, nihilistic, destructive, inhumane. We can give up on hope, embrace cynicism, even take the view that human life is somehow dispensable. We can vote dangerous populists into power that have been on the rise across Europe. We know where that leads. It‚Äôs happened before.  Or we choose to convert our uneasiness about tomorrow into focused energy to solve the complex issues of our time. We can choose togetherness and cooperation to breathe life into our democracies. We can try to put ourselves in other people‚Äôs shoes. We can uphold the fact that inclusion trumps exclusion. Not only because we need all hands on deck ‚Äì but because we subscribe to the fundamental idea that all our accomplishments are meaningless without our humanity.  It‚Äôs important we make a deliberate choice. Because if we don‚Äôt, the ones who thrive on fear will shape our world. We can‚Äôt let that happen.Siemens GamesaSiemens Energy

This is what really matters for your career. I often read that it is important to have a clear career goal and to take the suitable training to outperform successfully. On the one hand, that‚Äôs a good point.On the other hand: I am also impressed by people who don‚Äôt have straight CVs, who take detours in their careers and outperform. Why? Because they show curiosity and thus a growth mindset. In my opinion, rigid career plans are often not compatible with the unforeseen challenges of the VUCA world. We can only address them with a growth and performance mindset. Therefore, stay curious, seize the opportunities for personal growth that may present themselves even far from your original career plans and outperform. Metaphorically speaking: If your career was a tree, then form branches. As a young person, I didn't wake up in the morning and said: I want to be an insurance manager. I rather dreamed of being a football star. But along the way, I happened to meet people who worked in the insurance industry, and I wanted to work with and learn from them. My career developed from there by being curious, especially about people that I worked with and about leadership.Do you have any examples of how unexpected development opportunities have enriched your career and your life?I look forward to your comments.hashtag#TogetherTalanxhashtag#PerformanceCulture

Trust is foundational to the effectiveness of institutions and to democracy. Public trust strengthens our social fabric, providing greater flexibility and capacity to address complex systemic challenges, like climate change. Unfortunately, in recent years we‚Äôve seen a rise in polarization and social fragmentation around the world. Declining public trust poses a threat to democratic principles, economic stability, and to our collective confidence in the future. ¬†This is the reason why the theme of ‚Äúrebuilding trust‚Äù at next week‚Äôs World Economic Forum Annual Meeting is particularly timely and urgent. This year‚Äôs event serves as a pivotal platform for leaders from government, business, and civil society to come together, not just to talk but to explore the actions needed to restore trust across various dimensions in an effective and timely way. Private sector leaders play a key role in being constructive partners with government leaders and policymakers.¬†We also play a role through our own cross-collaboration and by building trust through our own example. Trust is earned by developing free market solutions to meet consumer and societal needs, through our sustainable operations and healthy workplaces, and, ultimately, by serving as stabilizing economic forces in our business communities.¬†¬†I‚Äôm looking forward to joining forces with fellow leaders at the World Economic Forum‚Äôs annual meeting. At Allianz, we believe in the transformative power of partnerships to drive positive change, regardless of the challenges we face. I‚Äôll be bringing this collaborative mindset to Davos, along with a spirit of pragmatic optimism. The charge is clear: Together, we must work to restore trust and shape a world that is more sustainable, healthy and secure.¬†#WEF2024 #Allianz

Der Wohlstand Deutschlands h√§ngt mit davon ab, wie innovativ wir als Unternehmen und Volkswirtschaft sind. Dazu brauchen wir gute Bildung und die kl√ºgsten K√∂pfe aus aller Welt. Unser Wohlstand h√§ngt auch davon ab, wie offen andere L√§nder f√ºr unsere Innovationen und Produkte sind und umgekehrt. Wer dies infrage stellt, schadet aus meiner Sicht nicht nur dem gesellschaftlichen Zusammenhalt, sondern auch dem Wohlstand und Wohlergehen der Gesellschaft. Innovation hat dabei auch mit Vielfalt zu tun. Denn nur, wenn wir die verschiedenen Sichtweisen zusammenbringen, finden wir die besten L√∂sungen. F√ºr mich hat Vielfalt darum immer auch eine unternehmerische Dimension. Sie ist nicht nur ein Wert, den ich teile. Sondern sie bringt auch bessere Leistung. Vielfalt muss dabei immer enthalten: Die Regeln des demokratischen Rechtsstaats akzeptieren und danach handeln. Das gilt f√ºr alle. Bei der Deutschen Telekom haben Hass, Hetze, Antisemitismus und Rassismus keinen Platz. Wir sind froh, dass bei der Telekom die unterschiedlichsten Menschen zusammenkommen und da sind f√ºr unsere Kundinnen und Kunden. Damit w√§chst nicht nur unser Unternehmen. Sondern jeder einzelne w√§chst √ºber sich selbst hinaus.Bei der Telekom arbeiten viele Menschen mit Migrationshintergrund. Sie tun viel f√ºr unser Unternehmen. Und sie tun viel f√ºr unser Land. Sie geh√∂ren zu uns.

Visiting our Siemens Healthineers teams in Palo Alto, California brings unique experiences and insights each time. My most recent trip offered the special chance to not only interact with my colleagues from Varian and Ultrasound, but also with some very special guests from Nova Scotia, Canada: Premier Tim Houston, Karen Oldfield, Dr. Matthew Clarke, and Scott McKenna. I learned more about how they and the dedicated professionals at Nova Scotia Health Authority have been working diligently to improve healthcare across their province, where rates of chronic diseases ‚Äî including #cancer ‚Äî are among the highest in Canada. Varian and Novia Scotia Health have long partnered on advancing the provincial cancer care program, and I'm very glad that we are building on those efforts through a new 10-year multi-disciplinary oncology collaboration to transform cancer into a manageable chronic disease.Specifically, we will contribute our proprietary software and know-how to help unify patient data across the health system and provide overall cancer operations support. We will provide the latest in #radiationtherapy treatment systems that leverage #AI and help improve precision and speed during patient treatment. We will also establish a new office in Halifax in the first half of 2024, providing a minimum of 60 jobs in Nova Scotia over the 10 years of the partnership. At this site, Varian will work closely with Nova Scotia Health to innovate in digital imaging. It was an honor to spend time with the Nova Scotia team and equally an honor that they have entrusted us with helping transform cancer care for their communities.

An unexpected shift? "Misinformation and Disinformation" is the #1 short-term global risk according to the World Economic Forum. Here's why I think it should not come as a surprise.The foundation has been laid for a long time. A major driver is the process of societal disintegration, fueled by inequality, seclusion, and extremism.Falsehoods spread rapidly in societies already weakened politically and economically, making people more susceptible to false or misleading information and supposedly simple solution that promise stability amidst rising uncertainties.This increasing insecurity and polarization combined with novel new technological capabilities through #AI is especially alarming looking at upcoming political elections in 2024. According to a recent YouGov survey, the proliferation of misleading audio and video deepfakes and political propaganda are the top concerns Americans have about AI (linked in comments).Misinformation and disinformation, particularly during elections, can severely undermine the legitimacy of newly elected governments, leading to political instability, violence, and even terrorism. This makes them a threat to democracy and a hindrance to a sustainable future.Solutions exist and must take effect quickly:‚ñ™¬†Governments are intensifying their fight against fake news and conspiracy theories, imposing stronger sanctions on the deliberate spread of misinformation, and launching initiatives to raise awareness.‚ñ™ Fact-based discourse is being promoted to counter increasing polarization, with media and independent fact checkers taking a stand against fake news and conspiracy theories.‚ñ™ Finally, the private sector is also taking a stronger stand against fake news, demonstrating that combating misinformation and disinformation is a collective responsibility.All of us must be on guard and foster critical thinking and rationality as the best remedy against manipulation and division. For this, we need to promote education and science. But that‚Äôs another story‚Ä¶What are you doing against misinformation and disinformation?

Loved my conversation with Ashley Smith on stage at CES to share what is possible today. Big thank you to Ashley and Varian. This is technology that helps to create a world without fear of cancer.¬†#CES #CES2024 #AI #TransformTheEverdayAshley Smith Bernd Montag Arthur Kaindl

hashtag#Buchempfehlung ‚Äì Was k√∂nnen wir aus Erz√§hlungen wie Matrix, Harry Potter und Herr der Ringe und anderen B√ºchern und Filmen √ºber den gesellschaftlichen Umgang mit hashtag#Rassismus, hashtag#Antisemitismus oder der hashtag#Klimaerw√§rmung lernen? In ‚ÄûErz√§hlende Affen‚Äú gehen die Autoren Samira El Ouassil und Friedemann Karig der Frage auf den Grund, wie Narrative ‚Äì also verfestigte Erz√§hlmuster ‚Äì unsere Wahrnehmung beeinflussen und damit auch gesellschaftliches Handeln.Als sehr bedenklich empfinde ich die Beobachtung, dass bestimmte Narrative tiefgreifende Probleme wie die Klimakrise eher versch√§rfen anstatt zu helfen, zu wissenschaftsbasierten L√∂sungen zu kommen. So gehen die Autoren auf ein g√§ngiges Narrativ ein, dass es unm√∂glich sei, zugleich √∂konomische und √∂kologische Ziele zu erreichen. Durch die fortw√§hrende Wiederholung in der entsprechenden Berichterstattung wird das Narrativ als objektiv und faktisch ‚Äûwahr‚Äú empfunden. Meiner Meinung nach ist √∂konomischer Erfolg langfristig nur dann m√∂glich, wenn er mit √∂kologisch verantwortungsbewusstem Handeln in Einklang steht. ‚ÄûErz√§hlende Affen‚Äú erinnert uns daran, dass Erz√§hlungen nicht allein deshalb wahr sind, nur weil sie fortw√§hrend wiederholt werden; gleichzeitig ist das Buch eine Aufforderung, neue Narrative zu schaffen, um beispielsweise den angeblichen Gegensatz zwischen Wirtschaftlichkeit und hashtag#Nachhaltigkeit aufzul√∂sen und zu widerlegen. Kennen Sie gelungene Narrative f√ºr unsere Zeit mit ihren vielf√§ltigen Herausforderungen?

Anfang Januar ‚Äì die Zeit der W√ºnsche und guten Vors√§tze. Mein Wunsch? Mehr Einsatz f√ºr Natur und Umwelt. Denn das Institut der deutschen Wirtschaft hat k√ºrzlich gewarnt: Trotz eines Anstiegs der Recyclingquote hat sich die Menge des nicht wiederverwerteten Kunststoffs zwischen 2011 und 2021 EU-weit um 3,7 Kilogramm pro Kopf erh√∂ht.H√∂chste Zeit also, f√ºr eine sachliche und faktenbasierte Diskussion √ºber #Recycling. Danke Philipp Krohn f√ºr die nuancierte Darstellung in der Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung.Mechanisches Recycling ist eine bew√§hrte Technologie, die bereits in gro√üem Umfang eingesetzt wird. Es ist energieeffizient und erm√∂glicht die Wiederverwendung vieler Kunststoffprodukte wie PET-Flaschen. Allerdings kommt das Verfahren bei komplexen Kunststoffarten und stark verschmutztem Plastikm√ºll an seine Grenzen und kann die Qualit√§t des recycelten Materials beeintr√§chtigen ‚Äì Stichwort Downcycling.Chemisches Recycling erm√∂glicht es, Kunststoffe auf molekularer Ebene zu zerlegen. Kunststoffe, die bisher als nicht recycelbar galten, k√∂nnen in hochwertige Rohstoffe umgewandelt werden. Diese Rezyklate und ihre fossilen Pendants sind chemisch identisch und haben eine gleichbleibende, hohe Qualit√§t. Das Verfahren hat also gro√ües Potential, ist jedoch weitaus weniger entwickelt und entsprechend kosten- und energieintensiv.Um es ganz klar zu sagen: Chemisches Recycling steht nicht in Konkurrenz zum mechanischen Recycling. Es setzt vielmehr da an, wo mechanisches Recycling nicht mehr greift. Indem wir beide Technologien f√∂rdern und optimieren, k√∂nnen wir k√ºnftig ein breiteres Spektrum an Kunststoffen im Kreislauf f√ºhren, fossile Ressourcen schonen und Abfall vermeiden. Damit das klappt, m√ºssen wir alle ‚Äì Industrie, Politik und Gesellschaft ‚Äì #Technologieoffenheit leben ‚Äì als guten Vorsatz f√ºr 2024.

I consider myself an optimist by nature, which may sound counter-intuitive for my line of work. But my career in the risk management-based insurance industry has strengthened my belief and confidence in the ability of determined individuals to find solutions to even the world‚Äôs most entrenched problems. Having an optimistic perspective is not a matter of feeling lucky. Optimism, in my view, stems from confidence in expertise and a proactive approach to challenges, with a focus on seeking innovative solutions. In a compelling Vox article, Hannah Ritchie, a researcher at the University of Oxford, emphasizes that we need optimists who believe that the future can be shaped by the decisions we make today. I couldn‚Äôt agree more. ¬†There are many optimist changemakers amongst us today ‚Äì such as those innovating solutions to reduce our environmental impact, feed a growing population, and reduce health risks. Their optimistic mindset encourages collaboration, recognizing that complex problems require collective efforts for effective solutions. ¬†How can we cultivate a more optimistic outlook? One effective approach is to look beyond negative headlines and focus on reliable data that highlights positive developments amid challenges. Here are just a few exciting developments we saw in the past year: ¬†1. Global flow of capital has shifted towards clean energy with investments in renewables outpacing those in fossil fuels. We at Allianz are proud to own over 100 wind and solar farms, contributing to this transformative shift.2. Led by new solar power, the world added renewable energy at breakneck speed in 2023. By 2025, renewable power is expected to become the primary global electricity source, achieving 91% of global electricity access, a significant increase from 84% in 2010.3.¬†Child mortality is decreasing. The rate at which children died before age 5 was estimated to have dropped from 3.6% in 2021 down to 3.5% in 2022. While this is still too high, it is the lowest global number ever estimated.4. Women CEOs in Fortune 500 companies reached an all-time high at 10.6% in 2023, with 53 women leading major firms, and the percentage of women on Fortune 500 boards increased from 9.6% in 1995 to 30.4% in 2022.¬†These achievements signal a strategic shift towards a more sustainable, resilient, equitable and interconnected world. While there‚Äôs no denying these are challenging times, I remain optimistic about the future, anticipating continued innovative momentum in 2024. As we welcome the new year, I encourage you to embrace a spirit of optimism into 2024. Every positive step we take collectively contributes to a brighter and more hopeful future for everyone. To that end, I am curious to know what positive news has recently bolstered your optimism, so please share in the comments. Together, let‚Äôs build a coalition of pragmatic optimists.¬†¬†¬†Wishing you a safe and #HappyNewYear!¬†#BetterTogether #¬≠¬≠¬≠¬≠¬≠¬≠DemocraciesDeliver #Allianz

Almost three quarters of global greenhouse gas emissions come directly or indirectly from energy consumption. It is crucial that we transition from fossil resources to renewable sources in order to achieve climate neutrality. However, it is not enough to simply switch to renewables. We must also focus on using our energy more efficiently, particularly in buildings which account for a significant portion of energy consumption and CO‚ÇÇ emissions. At Covestro, we are already working on developing efficient insulating materials, such as polyurethane foam, which has the lowest thermal conductivity. Additionally, we are able to produce components for this foam in a climate neutral way. BUT: political impetus is necessary to drive these changes forward. The recent agreement of the EU institutions on the directive for more energy efficiency in buildings is a step in the right direction, but by far not enough to achieve the EU's climate targets. It is now up to the German government to implement these targets with determination and ambition.I got the chance to dive deep into this topic and share my points of view together with Christian Noll from the Deutsche Unternehmensinitiative Energieeffizienz e. V. (DENEFF). Appreciate your time, Christian!Read the interview here: https://lnkd.in/e_RXeaHa #Energy #CircularEconomy #ClimateNeutrality

Als Optimist glaube ich, wir sollten von 2024 in Deutschland und Europa nicht zu viel erwarten. Und gerade darin liegt die Chance. Klingt widerspr√ºchlich? Dann will ich anhand von drei Thesen erkl√§ren, wie wir dieses Jahr zu einem guten machen k√∂nnen.Erstens: REALISMUS macht uns handlungsf√§hig.2020 und 2021 waren von der Corona Krise gepr√§gt, 2022 von Russlands Einmarsch in die Ukraine, 2023 eskalierte der Nahost-Konflikt. Zugleich zeigten sich schon 2023 rezessive Tendenzen, und der abrupte Zinsanstieg wirkt weiter nach. Dass wir also auch 2024 irgendeine Krise erleben, ist wahrscheinlich. Doch es wird weitergehen. Und Krisenbew√§ltigung funktioniert am besten mit k√ºhlem Kopf und einer realistischen Erwartungshaltung.Zweitens: EHRLICHKEIT ist die wichtigste Pr√§misse.Die latente Unzufriedenheit der Bev√∂lkerung wird nicht √ºber Nacht verschwinden, weil strukturelle Probleme wie die B√ºrokratie nicht durch Sonntagsreden gel√∂st werden. Und auch in punkto Wirtschaft und Energie muss man ehrlich sein: Die Abkehr von russischem Gas hat die Beschaffung von Strom und Gas strukturell verteuert. Und die Alternative ‚Äì noch schneller, noch mehr Erneuerbare ‚Äì kommt nicht zum Nulltarif. Denn nicht zuletzt der so dringend ben√∂tigte Netzausbau ist durch B√ºrokratie erschwert und wurde durch den sprunghaften Anstieg der Kapitalkosten verteuert. Auf der anderen Seite erh√∂ht ein Tempoverlust beim Ausbau dieser Infrastruktur die Systemkosten f√ºr die Volkswirtschaft. Zur Ehrlichkeit geh√∂rt also: Das einfache, positive Narrativ eines vergleichsweisen schmerzlosen √úbergangs, ohne die Gefahr von Wohlstandsverlusten, sondern im Gegenteil, mit dem Gewinn von Wettbewerbsf√§higkeit, in eine neue Welt billiger und nachhaltiger Energie, ist Geschichte. Manches davon hat die Politik schlicht nicht in der Hand, egal welche Parteien die Regierung stellen. Kommuniziert sie dies ehrlich, kann sie Vertrauen zur√ºckgewinnen. Drittens: PRAGMATISCH wird es vielleicht nicht perfekt, aber sicher mal besser. 100% L√∂sungen kann und muss es nicht geben, auch 2024 nicht. Once upon a time in an era brimming with the promise of a new millennium, Mark Steil, a dedicated chemist, found himself at a crossroads of history. His world in the early 2000s was slowly awaking to the idea of a shift from a linear system of take, make, and waste, to a more circular, sustainable one.¬†On a brisk Christmas Eve, under the soft glow of Y2K lights, Mark's curiosity led him to find a time machine. His mind, teeming with questions about the environmental trajectory, compelled him to embark on a journey through time.¬†Fueled by this spirit, he traveled to the 1980s. There, amidst a booming economy, he witnessed firsthand the signs of a looming triple crisis: escalating climate change, diminishing livelihoods, and environmental degradation. This era's unsustainable growth and reliance on fossil resources stood in stark contrast to the emerging sustainable practices.¬†With insights from the past, Mark propelled himself to 2023. There, he found a world actively striving towards a #CircularEconomy, yet still wrestling with the legacies of past decades ‚Äì continuing struggles with waste management and carbon emissions, but also notable advancements in sustainable practices and technologies.¬†¬†His journey through time complete, Mark returned to the early 2000s, a period rich with potential for change. The challenges of the sustainability transformation, he understood, were not insurmountable barriers but opportunities for creativity and progress.¬†This understanding fueled his determination¬†to contribute actively to shaping a sustainable path forward together with his valued like-minded colleagues and partners.¬†And so, he lived busily but happily ever after and wishes everyone a season of joy and a future filled with sustainable endeavors.

Towards the end of 2023, we convened with the top 500 leaders of thyssenkrupp in Essen. Last week, over two days, Klaus Keysberg, Oliver Burkhard, Siegfried Russwurm, and I engaged in intensive discussions, brainstorming ways to propel thyssenkrupp forward. Equally important was listening ‚Äì gaining valuable insights from the perspectives of our customers and investors. The expectations for us and thyssenkrupp, both internally and externally, are clear: We must contribute to the future ‚Äì as an attractive employer, a competent partner, and a sound investment. As a world-class brand with cutting-edge technologies and innovative solutions, I am confident that we will succeed! hashtag#thyssenkrupp is an enabler and driver of the green transformation. We will not only successfully decarbonize our own activities but also assist our customers in their decarbonization efforts with our unique products and services. This is already being demonstrated today. I extend my gratitude to Lukas G√∂bel from thyssenkrupp Materials Services, Karsten Kroos from thyssenkrupp Automotive, and Lucretia L√∂scher from thyssenkrupp Uhde for their insights and sustainable examples from their business units. This was very enlightening and motivating. At the same time, we acknowledge that our performance is not yet where it needs to be. Our primary goal is to achieve the mid-term targets we communicated to the capital markets in December 2021. I am convinced that our performance program APEX will be a success story and an important lever in supporting this goal and our transformation. The APEX effect is already evident across all our segments today. A big thank you to Cetin Nazikkol, Christian Hiersemann, Dr. Christian Vinck, Patrick Buchmann, Thore Lohmann, Stephan Wolke, and Dr. Adrian Seeger for the updates on this. I would also like to personally thank Karl Schmedders, Kai Jannek, and Rob Theunissen for the inspiring impulses, and Dr. Janin Schwartau and Thies Eisele for the excellent moderation. What a fantastic event ‚Äì I am already looking forward to the next one. The goals and experiences of the past two days have a radiant effect ‚Äì on the entire hashtag#leadershipteam and all thyssenkrupp employees worldwide. Thank you to the entire hashtag#GENERATIONTK for your tireless efforts this year; without you, all this would not be possible. I look forward to driving the hashtag#transformation of thyssenkrupp at full speed ahead with you next year. Until then, I wish all employees and everyone a relaxing Christmas with their loved ones and a great start to 2024, where we again keep pushing boundaries and pioneering the future.

Last week I was particularly pleased to see the agreement on electricity market design in Brussels. It was the proof that the EU has taken good care of one of its most precious assets, the internal electricity market.¬†¬†Elsewhere, I must say that I am disappointed reading news from Brussels last week. In particular, the EU Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive as agreed last week appears to be another example of additional bureaucracy. And not only for large companies, because nearly all smaller companies are suppliers of large companies and will be forced by them to report under the CS3D. The resulting reporting liability is disproportionate.¬†¬†The EU announced its willingness to reduce the reporting burden for companies by 25%. I am pretty sure that this Directive is not going to help. I really hope that the promised reduction of bureaucracy will become a clear commitment of the European institutions and that it will materialize as soon as possible in real life. We often say ‚ÄúJetzt machen‚Äù, just do it!¬†¬†Another example of increasing bureaucracy? Take the AI Act. It‚Äôs fundamentally naive to think that we can achieve leadership in a cutting-edge technology by leading on its regulation. This will not work, especially when the tech is already developing elsewhere ‚Äì which is the case of AI.¬†¬†¬†Don‚Äôt get me wrong: it is certainly right to ensure a responsible use of AI and the risk-based approach is also to be welcomed. However, good intentions don‚Äôt necessarily mean good results. I am missing a focus on the opportunities of the technology. I am missing an approach how to make much more data easily available. I am missing the understanding that AI will be indispensable for a modern society. I am missing an acknowledgement that innovation is our source of wealth ‚Äì and not regulation. And I fear that the AI Act will lead the technology to develop outside Europe.¬†#bureaucracy #CS3D #euaiact

Personally, a couple of months ago ‚Äì when Germany and France were struggling to find a compromise on the details of 2-ways contracts for differences ‚Äì I was thinking that an agreement on electricity market design was out of reach.Now, we do have a deal. We don‚Äôt know all the details and maybe it is not the perfect deal, but it is for sure much better than any other outcome we could have imagined one year ago, when many politicians and Governments were thinking that electricity markets were broken and that the ‚Äúmerit order‚Äù was an anomaly of the market design. I have said it many times in Brussels: the internal electricity market has saved Europe during the crisis.So today we can congratulate the Members of the EU Parliament and the Member States for this agreement, and of course the Spanish EU-Presidency for facilitating it. Now, it will be up to the Member States and National Regulators to ensure the detailed implementation, engaging consumers in the energy transition and accelerating investments in clean technologies and infrastructures, which are the missing link of the energy transition. #energytransition #marketdesign

It‚Äôs never outdated to have a corporate purpose. Here's why.In my opinion, a corporate purpose can still be useful today - if it is strong and authentic!Studies show that a corporate purpose is a crucial element for success. They also show that many people don't just want to work to earn a living. They want to make a difference. In the Talanx Group, it was not the Executive Board that decided on a corporate purpose. To make it as strong and authentic as possible, in 2019 we placed its development in the hands of over 4,000 Talanx Group employees from all over the world. The corporate purpose they developed felt so right! 'Together we take care of the unexpected and foster entrepreneurship' is what we truly believe in. We all collaborate in a transparent and highly engaged manner for the benefit of our customers.Are we perfect? No, we are on a journey together. Here are some ways we can continue to foster collaboration to make a difference and drive success:üëâ Foster an environment where ideas, feedback and speak up are welcome. üëâ Break down silos: Work together across departments and teams.üëâ Embrace technology: Use tools and platforms for collaboration.üëâ Recognise and celebrate successful collaboration.Let‚Äôs continue to collaborate and outperform ‚Äì together! What do you think about a corporate purpose? Do you have any further ideas on how to encourage collaboration? I look forward to your comments.hashtag#TogetherTalanxhashtag#Collaborationhashtag#PerformanceCulture

The ‚Ç¨5 billion counter-guarantee scheme that the European Investment Bank (EIB) just pledged to support European wind turbine manufacturers is a good start. The world stands at a pivotal point on the journey to #netzero. Investing in ClimateTech solutions is essential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change. A recent report from Allianz Economic Research throws a light on the current investment gaps facing European ClimateTech start-ups, threatening an innovation lag behind the U.S. and China. Strong partnerships between public and private investors are key to reversing this course and improving the competitiveness of Europe‚Äôs ClimateTech industry. Policymakers can help to establish a unified EU platform, streamline bureaucracy, and update regulation. Closer collaboration is also needed between investors and universities, to build robust research ecosystems, catalyse innovation and fast-track ClimateTech innovation hubs. ¬†Although our report focuses on Europe, the ClimateTech race is global. The economic opportunity in the net-zero transformation is enormous and progress from around the world continues to impress me, from rapid advances in making renewable energy accessible and affordable to groundbreaking policies that are helping communities adapt to living with climate risks. This is a decisive moment for policymakers, industry players, investors, and scientific institutions. And making net-zero targets tangible by 2030 will require the willingness to partner across all areas ‚Äì without delay. ¬†¬†Dive into our ClimateTech report to learn more: https://lnkd.in/dZKpqTk2 ¬†#AllianzOnClimate #ClimateTech #Allianz

Die "Kosmos-Vortr√§ge von 1827/28" von Alexander von Humboldt waren f√ºr damalige Zuh√∂rer ein bisschen wie Wikipedia ‚Äì nur ohne Internet. In der zu seiner Zeit beliebten Vortragsreihe wagte Humboldt eine ganzheitliche Beschreibung der Welt. Seine Erkenntnisse richtete er aber nicht an einen elit√§ren Kreis von Wissenschaftlern. Stattdessen hatte er ein breites Publikum jenseits des Elfenbeinturms im Sinn, f√ºr das er seine Forschungsreisen und Einblicke unterhaltsam, mit vielen Querverweisen und in zahlreiche Anekdoten verpackte.Was lernen wir heute noch daraus? Dass wir √ºber die Grenzen unserer eigenen Disziplinen und Komfortzonen hinausdenken m√ºssen, wenn wir das gro√üe Ganze verstehen wollen. Und dass wir hashtag#Wissen teilen m√ºssen, damit es m√∂glichst vielen Menschen n√ºtzt. Das gilt vor allem in der hashtag#Medizin, die st√§ndig neue Erkenntnisse hervorbringt ‚Äì mehr als ein einzelner Mensch behalten kann. In hoch entwickelten hashtag#Gesundheitswesen arbeiten Expertinnen und Experten, die √ºber enormes Fachwissen in ihrer (jeweiligen) Disziplin verf√ºgen, sich aus dieser Position heraus aber schwerer tun, das Gesamtbild zu sehen. Zum Gl√ºck haben wir heute die technologischen Hilfsmittel zur Hand, die uns beim Vernetzen von Menschen und Wissen unterst√ºtzen.

Europe‚Äôs energy transition is dependent on a smart and flexible system, maximising efficiency and giving consumers choice ‚Äì but this is not possible without a proper smart meter rollout.First let‚Äôs start with the (partially!) good news. As Eurelectric‚Äôs recent Power Barometer shows, EU penetration rate of smart meters is increasing, standing at 56% on average across Member States. The rollout has been particularly successful in both Southern Europe and Scandinavia, where a near 100% rollout has been achieved in a number of countries. Consumers there will be able to benefit from more innovative products, potentially bringing bills down whilst participating more effectively in the smart energy system that must be everyone‚Äôs future.Now let‚Äôs move onto the bad news: Germany and much of Central and Eastern Europe is seriously lagging behind. A penetration rate of less than 1% puts Germany pretty much at the bottom of the pile ‚Äì not a new development but also not an excuse. We talk the talk on the energy transition but on this crucial topic we are failing to walk the talk. It‚Äôs about time to just do it! More here: https://lnkd.in/eFjCadWc #energytransition #powerbarometer23

Yesterday was my last day at hashtag#COP28, another enriching experience filled with insightful discussions and forward-thinking ideas. I had the privilege of participating in two panel discussions that highlighted key issues in our journey towards a sustainable future. This morning, I joined a panel at the German Pavilion hosted by ICC Germany & Federation of German Industries (BDI) e.V., focusing on "Enabling the Future: Insights from Business Leaders into Climate and Clean Energy Technology". It was an honor to share the stage with esteemed colleagues like Dr. Uwe Lauber from MAN Energy Solutions, Victoria Ossadnik of E.ON, and Helmut von Struve from Siemens, with the moderation led by Holger L√∂sch of BDI - Bundesverband der Deutschen Industrie e.V.Our conversation revolved around the pressing need to transition from fossil fuels to renewable energy. The consensus was clear: the technologies we need are already here, and they have the potential to make a significant impact on climate change. At thyssenkrupp, we're committed to this transition, not just in our operations but also by helping our customers achieve their climate goals. Our thyssenkrupp Decarbon Technologies segment serves as a solid proof of our commitment to sustainability, focusing on innovations in wind power, the cement industry, green hydrogen, and green ammonia. In the afternoon, the discussion at the second panel, moderated by Rich Lesser of Boston Consulting Group (BCG), with Pedro Pizarro from Edison International, centered on "Enabling the Energy Transition: Infrastructure, Incentives, and Regulatory Frameworks." We reiterated the need for a market-based ecosystem where green products become the norm. Building the necessary generation capacity, transport routes, and energy partnerships to move away from fossil fuels is a monumental task, one that requires supportive policies and incentives from governments. At hashtag#thyssenkrupp, we're already taking bold steps in this direction. Our hydrogen-ready direct reduction plant in Duisburg, Germany, is a pioneering project in industrial decarbonization. It's projects like these that underscore our commitment to the green transformation. To achieve a truly green economy, collaboration between industries, governments, and communities is vital. Let's continue to work together for a sustainable and prosperous future.

The recent State of the Energy Union report demonstrated well the extent of Europe‚Äôs response to the unprecedented energy crisis of the past 2 years, but: There is so much more to be done! We need speed and scale!Eurelectric‚Äôs Power Barometer findings show that between now and 2050 the electrification rate must triple across society, powering our homes, transport and industry with clean, green, homegrown electricity which on the one hand implies a further expansion of renewables.On the other hand this cannot be achieved without the expansion of our grids. Here I can speak from personal experience: to meet the EU‚Äôs 2030 goals E.ON alone will have to make 8 million connections at the DSO level, that‚Äôs 1 connection every 7 seconds. That requires a significant step up from previous years. The Power Barometer shows: We are not yet on track!To supercharge our grid growth a number of things are needed. First and foremost, attractive regulatory and market conditions that attract capital, but also an expansion of skill base and workforce. Europe is facing a shortage of technical people and the need for skilled technicians will only grow in the coming years. Both industry and the public sector must work together to open up the pathways and encourage more technically qualified people.I truly believe this is one of the most exciting sectors to work in, one that is at the very centre of tackling the climate crisis. Simply put, without the workforce in place the energy transition will not happen. More here: https://lnkd.in/d8psQmVc #powerbarometer23 #energytransition

As the CEO of thyssenkrupp, I had the privilege of participating in the Cross-industry CEO Roundtable on Private Sector Decarbonization by Roland Berger at hashtag#COP28 yesterday in Dubai. The event, hosted in the UNFCCC Pavilion within the COP Blue Zone, was a remarkable gathering of minds and ambitions. Our discussion, driven by the shared commitment to hashtag#ActForImpact, brought together business leaders from key sectors to reflect on our journey towards aligning with the Paris Agreement. Engaging with esteemed panelists such as Dame Susan Rice of the Global Ethical Finance Initiative (GEFI), Driss Berraho from ACWA Power, Francois Dao of EDF Renewables Middle East and moderator Stefan Schaible was enriching. Together, we delved into the structural impediments and challenges that impede the private sector's transition to net-zero emissions. A highlight of the event was Martin Hoyer's presentation of the "Global Carbon Restructuring Plan." This ambitious initiative charts a course for decarbonizing the world‚Äôs top 1,000 CO2-emitting assets, a crucial step towards our sustainable future. The insights and experiences shared have only strengthened my belief in our collective ability to foster a greener, more sustainable industrial future. Each sector needs its own solution, replacing carbon-intensive processes with clean technologies, developing sustainable supply chains and new infrastructure. I firmly believe creating alliances within each sector is the surest way to build the confidence needed to deliver large-scale decarbonization projects. Only by working together, can we move faster and act bolder. In my view, previous COPs have not made sufficient progress in cutting global emissions. Often the lowest common denominator prevailed. Now is the time to be pragmatic and move from theory to reality to drive change. I believe, we need a new form of cooperation between the public sector, corporates, and finance to create climate neutral industrial ecosystems. This must be a COP of action. A hashtag#COP where we all feel and live the spirit of close collaboration.
Congrats, Neha, on your new career! The story, emotion and graphics are excellent. üòÄ

hashtag#COP28 brings into global focus a widely acknowledged truth: a growing commitment from global leaders and industry is necessary to forge international, sustainable partnerships. This collaborative approach is crucial in combating climate change through renewable energy, hydrogen, and its derivatives. thyssenkrupp is at the forefront, not just offering key technologies for the energy transition, but also developing climate-friendly technologies to replace hashtag#CO2-intensive production processes. In support of this dynamic movement and to achieve significant progress in decarbonizing industry, we hosted a dialogue today with several decarbonization enablers. Our objective? To power the hashtag#greentransformation! During the event, we were not only able to discuss all the important topics relating to COP28, but also achieve success in the further development of our Green Industrial Powerhouse. thyssenkrupp Decarbon Technologies has signed today two projects with Fujairah Cement Industries (FCI) and Gulf Biopolymers Industries Ltd (Gulf Biopolymers), both based in the United Arab Emirates. The partnerships are aimed at decarbonizing energy intensive cement production and building up biopolymer production capacity in the MENA region. The plant will be the first large biopolymer plant in the MENA region.¬†thyssenkrupp has bundled key technologies for the decarbonization of the industry in its new segment Decarbon Technologies. Announcing these milestone projects during COP28 is proof for the strategic importance of this green industrial powerhouse. Read more about it: https://lnkd.in/e878p6Ev I extend my thanks to Prof. Dr. Christopher Hebling for his enlightening keynote. Furthermore, the panel discussion featuring Paul Bodnar, Alicia Eastman, James Mnyupe, CA(SA)(Nam), CFA, CFP, and Roland Kaeppner, expertly moderated by Frank Wouters, was extraordinarily insightful. Exchanges like today's are pivotal in aligning us towards a unified response to fulfill the long-term objectives of the Paris Agreement. We at thyssenkrupp want to act quickly, boldly and in a networked manner. That's why platforms like hashtag#COP28 are so important. We need to intensify collaboration in our industry and beyond. Creating alliances is the surest way to build the necessary confidence to act faster and bolder when it comes to decarbonization. thyssenkrupp is fully committed to the green transformation. By building a green industrial powerhouse of interconnecting technologies, we turn from being part of the climate change problem to becoming an integral part of the solution. Today, I attended a panel discussion organized by Siemens and the International Chamber of Commerce, along with other leading industry representatives. It was a pleasure to be back in Brussels once again this week for an exciting few days of policymaker and industry dialogues.  The competitiveness struggle is real and we need to talk about it! It is good that the EU-COM now spends serious time to listen to industry. Yesterday I joined the Clean Transition Dialogue organised by the European Commission and Executive Vice President Maro≈° ≈†efƒçoviƒç, this time with energy intensive industries. To foster industrial competitiveness can only be done in a true European framework. Now we need to continue to talk about how the costs and benefits of the transition are fairly distributed between industry and society. A difficult discussion but a necessary one!  In her opening remarks President Ursula von der Leyen said ‚Äúthe real long-term solution to bring prices down is to keep investing in home-grown clean energy‚Äù and this is of course true. But perhaps if I could make one addition to that it would be ‚Äú...and our grid infrastructure‚Äù. We cannot achieve this transition without it. The costs of action on grid infrastructure will be great but the cost of inaction will be even greater. The Grid Action Plan announced this week was a welcome step on this road, I look forward to working with our industry, regulators and consumers on its implementation.  On Wednesday I also had the pleasure of meeting Minister Tinne Van der Straeten and would like to thank her and Eurelectric colleagues for sharing thoughts ahead of the Belgian EU Presidency in the first half of 2024, and the emphasis on energy sovereignty. Next year will be a busy one for the electoral calendar but work must not stop. We count on the Belgian Presidency to drive the implementation needed now in our sector, whilst laying the groundwork for ambitious but achievable 2040 targets. Combating climate change and transitioning to a low-carbon economy depends on the greening of global trade. This is a momentous time of transformation in global trade, requiring major shifts in decarbonizing shipping infrastructure and collaborative efforts to stimulate innovation and facilitate the flow and accessibility of green goods. The speed and success of the global green trade transformation calls for international cooperation, a multilateral approach, and coherent policy action. ¬†The Financial sector has a significant role to play in partnering with policymakers to progress green trade, from investing in sustainable technology and transportation infrastructure, to making trade finance criteria more inclusive and supportive of sustainability over time, especially in emerging markets.¬†¬†¬†¬†A recent report by our economic research team at Allianz Trade explores the current state of green trade, shining light on existing barriers and actions needed to accelerate growth. ¬†¬†I encourage you to read more here: https://lnkd.in/exizX6dg ¬†#AllianzOnClimate #Allianz

Ahead of hashtag#COP28, the EU Council has called for global action to triple renewable energy capacity. That sounds like a lot (and it is), but there is no other way ‚Äì especially considering the performance of nationally determined contributions (NDCs) that are at the heart of the Paris Agreement. NDCs to date would achieve an emissions reduction by 2030 that is only a fraction of what we need to comply with the 1.5¬∞C limit. In other words, we‚Äôre far off. And to triple renewable energy capacity, we will need more wind energy.With the commencement of COP28 today, I wish my hashtag#TeamPurple colleagues and all delegations attending productive days in Dubai. hashtag#COP28UAE hashtag#COP hashtag#MoreWindNow hashtag#WindEnergy hashtag#RenewableEnergy

At this point in time however, we have not yet seen the required scale-up of the hydrogen economy necessary for the energy transition. In this article, I want to share my thoughts on why this is the case and discuss how we can unlock hydrogen‚Äôs full potential: ‚¨áÔ∏è#hydrogen #energytransition #decarbonization
