Gestern Hauptversammlung bei der Deutschen Telekom. Oder auch: Zeugnistag. Wir haben uns Kritik - aber auch Lob - unserer Aktion√§rinnen und Aktion√§re gestellt. Sch√∂n, dass so viele bei uns in Bonn vor Ort waren. So voll war es lange nicht mehr.Mein Thema: Nachhaltigkeit. Denn nachhaltig entwickeln wir bei der Telekom unser Gesch√§ft. Das zeigt sich auch in der Aktie. Die Gesamtrendite im vergangenen Jahr: 18,6 Prozent. Ein gutes Ergebnis auch im Vergleich zum DAX, der im selben Zeitraum mit 12,4 Prozent im Minus lag. 70 Cent pro Aktie sch√ºtten wir als Dividende aus - steuerfrei.Wirtschaftlicher Erfolg ist die Basis daf√ºr, dass wir auch unsere gesellschaftliche Verantwortung wahrnehmen k√∂nnen. Bis 2025 wollen wir klimaneutral sein, bis 2040 sogar entlang unserer gesamten Wertsch√∂pfungskette: Von der Produktion von Endger√§ten bis zum Stromverbrauch bei den Kundinnen und Kunden. Zugleich helfen wir, wenn wir gebraucht werden. Zuletzt beim Erdbeben in der T√ºrkei und Syrien. Oder wir unterst√ºtzen Benachteiligte mit speziellen Rabatten. 2,3 Milliarden Euro war unser gesellschaftliches Engagement im vergangenen Jahr wert.Eine weitere gute Nachricht war: Wir haben die Mehrheit an der T-Mobile US erreicht. Am wertvollsten Telekommunikationsunternehmen der Welt. Seit 2013 haben wir den Wert f√ºr die Telekom um √ºber 70 Milliarden Euro gesteigert. Und: Wir investieren weiter. 25 bis 30 Millionen Haushalte f√ºr FTTH wollen wir bis 2030 in Deutschland bauen. Danke an alle, die zum Erfolg der Hauptversammlung beigetragen haben. Insbesondere an alle Aktion√§rinnen und Aktion√§re f√ºr den wichtigen, kritischen Dialog. Danke auch an meine KollegInnen im Vorstand f√ºr ein gutes Jahr 2022 Birgit Bohle Dominique Leroy Claudia Nemat Srini Gopalan  Christian Illek Thorsten Langheim Adel Al-Saleh

An estimated 1% of the world‚Äôs population is on the autism spectrum. I just recently met with the members of our Autism Inclusion Network and we talked about the fact that there is no one way to be neurodiverse. Every difference is an opportunity, a new way of thinking, something to learn from. We‚Äôre better and stronger when we‚Äôre different.Our colleagues on the spectrum significantly contribute to what we do at SAP ‚Äì in every Board area and across our product portfolio. Through our Autism at Work program, we've also seen that a more #inclusive working environment also leads to improved management skills and greater empathy in teams.With the SAP Autism Inclusion Pledge, we want to help candidates on the spectrum break through preconceptions and stereotypes. We want to encourage more organizations to hire based on the unique strengths and skillsets every individual offers. #NeurodiversityMatters #LifeAtSAP

Climate change is not a future problem - it's here and now. This is why we must take action today. That‚Äôs the key message from the latest IPCC report which highlights that there are already effective and accessible ways to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to #climatechange. One of these pathways is investing in clean energy infrastructure, which not only reduces emissions but also brings wider health and economic benefits. It‚Äôs inspiring to see Allianz investing in He Dreiht, one of Germany‚Äôs largest offshore wind farms. He Dreiht is set to start operations by the end of 2025, and will provide clean energy to 1.1 million households upon completion.As the IPCC report makes clear, we must act urgently to cut emissions and shift our energy grid towards renewable sources to limit global warming to 1.5¬∞C. Our first direct investment into offshore wind in Germany is a crucial step to achieving #netzero. At Allianz, we are committed to driving the renewable energy transition by collaborating with other infrastructure investors and utilizing blended finance to multiple investment impact. Read more about our investment in the offshore wind park He Dreiht here: https://lnkd.in/eJKCH62m #Allianz #Sustainability #EnergyTransition #ImpactInvesting

Taking a clear position - My interview marathon in these weeks Security of supply, energy affordability, climate protection and the sustainable transformation of the energy supply are rightly among the top issues in the public eye. We at E.ON have clear messages on this, not only on our own behalf to represent our interests, but out of our responsibility to the economy and society. One thing is clear: E.ON is part of the solution on the path to transforming energy systems. That is why I repeatedly go public with our positions and make it clear where and what E.ON stands for and what we believe is the right thing to do - in Germany and Europe. In the last few days I have given a number of interviews. I will briefly report on three of them to give you an insight into this part of my "job description". At the beginning of March, I was a guest of the BBC World News television station and spoke there primarily about the issues that are important for Europe's security of supply and competitiveness: a modern market design and the massive expansion of the energy infrastructure, but also a non-bureaucratic approach to building a European hydrogen economy. So that the USA with its Inflation Reduction Act does not completely leave us behind in the international competition for capital and investments.¬† On the day of our successful annual press conference, I spoke live with Bloomberg. I explained our strong annual results compared to the turbulent business environment, but above all I outlined our growth and investment plans. Despite the turmoil in the European energy markets, we have achieved a 2022 result that is both above the previous year's level and above our own forecasts. Now we are expanding our investment programme to a total of 33 billion euros by 2027 on a solid financial and balance sheet foundation. This underpins our claim to be the driver and shaper of an accelerated energy transition in Europe.¬† Both interviews were exciting for me but also critical. The same was true for my Interview with the Handelsblatt which now is also published. My interview partners from the Handelsblatt, with whom I spoke last week, were also critical. The upcoming phase-out of nuclear energy was the main topic here. I made it clear here once again that we respect the political decisions to phase out nuclear power and will implement them professionally - even though our nuclear power plants have made a valuable contribution to security of supply and climate protection. We are now looking ahead. Because with our grids and customer solutions we have a very clear growth project: the energy transition in Europe!¬†And we are also moving forward in the media. Because one thing is clear: communication is the repetition of messages. #energytransition

Die nachhaltige Transformation unserer Industrie ist ein Langstreckenlauf verschiedener Generationen. Deshalb brauchen wir neben innovativen Technologien motivierte und engagierte Talente ‚Äì und zwar heute und in 30 Jahren.Das Talentlabor des German Chemical Industry Association VCI ist eine gro√üartige Initiative, die solche Talente vernetzt, f√∂rdert und entwickelt. Gestern hatte ich das Vergn√ºgen, die derzeitigen Mitglieder des Talentlabors kennenzulernen und meine √úberzeugung zu best√§tigen: Talententwicklung ist ein wichtiger Schl√ºssel f√ºr unsere erfolgreiche #Transformation zu mehr Nachhaltigkeit und Klimaneutralit√§t.Es freut mich, dass das Talentlabor ein fester Bestandteil der VCI-Mitarbeiterentwicklung geworden ist. Vielen Dank f√ºr den bereichernden Austausch, Anne Armbruster, Isabell Esterhaus, Ulrich Hartung, Lukas K√∂lln, Laura Lischinski, Heinrich Nachtsheim, Dr. Denis Pahlke, Lara Panning und Florian Ritz!

‚ÄúCrisis and transformation management‚Äù ‚Äì that is what I spoke about at yesterday‚Äôs meeting on environmental and energy policy of the Wirtschaftsrat der CDU e.V., an association of Germany‚Äôs Christian Democrats. As a world-leading manufacturer of hashtag#wind turbines, we at Siemens Gamesa ‚Äì together with the entire hashtag#European wind industry ‚Äì are managing the damage that was done years ago when the market for wind energy massively declined. Back then, Russian gas was the easiest option for policymakers and industry alike. As a result, suppliers in the wind industry went out of business, skilled people moved to other industries, and many thousands of people lost their jobs. More than one year into Germany's Zeitenwende (‚Äúturn of the times‚Äù), the wind of change is coming from all directions: initiatives, new acts, laws from Berlin, Brussels, Washington, and around the world. Calling the targets for wind expansion ‚Äúambitious‚Äù is an understatement. Within a few years, we need to pull off what we haven‚Äôt been able to do in previous decades. At Siemens Gamesa, we welcome this challenge. And we are transforming our business to transform our hashtag#energy systems.  But I also made the point yesterday that Europe‚Äôs wind industry needs more than ambitious targets. We need fundamental ‚Äì and above all swift and decisive ‚Äì change to be able to grow fast and deliver the wind turbines we need. Policy and decision makers on the European, national, and regional levels have more work to do. Among other tasks, they need to:  ‚û°  massively increase investments in manufacturing capacities and key infrastructure; ‚û°  accelerate permitting (around 80 gigawatts of wind energy projects are currently stuck in approval procedures across Europe ‚Äì a big number compared with the 204 gigawatts of installed capacity);  ‚û°  implement the indexation of revenues defined in auctions for renewable energies to compensate for inflation; and ‚û°  avoid negative bidding, i.e. avoid expecting winning developers to pay for the right develop wind projects ‚Äì a cost which is passed onto the supply chain and end consumers. The European wind industry is determined to do everything it can to achieve the targets of wind expansion. And we want to ensure that wind projects in Europe are also made in Europe. That is why we have no more time to lose. We have to get things done, and we have to get them done now. hashtag#MoreWindNow hashtag#WindEnergy hashtag#EnergySovereignty hashtag#EnergyPolicy hashtag#EnergyTransition hashtag#OffshoreWind hashtag#OnshoreWind

Democracy is being challenged worldwide. This is clear from both the news headlines and research data. For the first time in more than two decades the world counts more closed autocracies than liberal democracies, as highlighted by V-Dem Institute Democracy Report 2023. This correlates with a decline in government trust; according to the 2023 Edelman Trust Barometer, trust in governments has decreased by a percentage point over the last year, to just 50% of people worldwide ‚Äì compared to 59% trust in NGOs and 62% trust in businesses.¬†¬†Democracy remains the best system available to humanity for unleashing our potential, promoting international peace and security, growing prosperity, and upholding human dignity, particularly in times of uncertainty and rapid change. The responsibility of preserving democracy does not fall solely on governments as the private sector also plays an important role as one of the world‚Äôs most trusted institutions. ¬†Fortunately, there are many ways in which businesses can help to promote democratic values. At Allianz, we aim to support one of the key pillars of democracy, namely a stable and growing middle class by protecting our customers against economic shocks and helping them secure their financial future. We achieve this by helping businesses to grow and protect their assets, promoting financial literacy and by providing individuals with the tools they need to make sound financial decisions, enabling them to face the future with confidence. Additionally, we aim to be a model for institutional change by advocating for diversity, equity, and inclusion, not only because it enhances our organization‚Äôs strength, but because it creates opportunities for everyone to succeed. ¬†Protecting democracy requires action from all of us. Businesses have an opportunity to support governments in reaffirming democratic principles and leading us toward a fairer, more secure and thriving society.¬†#Allianz #FinancialLiteracy #DemocraciesDeliver

Startschuss zum industriepolitischen Neuanfang oder weitere Sonntagsreden? Mein Fazit zum Parlamentarischen Abend des German Chemical Industry Association VCI.Seit langem habe ich wieder das Gef√ºhl, dass wir alle ‚Äì Wirtschaft, Politik und Gesellschaft ‚Äì an einem Strang ziehen. Die Forderungen nach verbesserten Rahmenbedingungen sind in den K√∂pfen der relevanten Personen angekommen. Die Politik hat verstanden: Deutschland braucht dringend ein Update. Mehr Fachkr√§fte sowie moderne Infrastruktur f√ºr erneuerbare Energie und Digitalisierung ‚Äì und am aller wichtigsten: viel weniger B√ºrokratie f√ºr viel mehr Tempo.Auf dem Parlamentarischen Abend sp√ºrte ich einen starken Konsens dar√ºber, wie dringend wir den industriepolitischen Neuanfang brauchen. Und das stimmt mich optimistisch. Der Tatendrang ist da, jetzt m√ºssen Industrie und Politik gemeinsam den Reset-Knopf dr√ºcken.

In addition to my post yesterday here are some impressions. Start-ups will fail if founders don‚Äôt empower their employees. This is the second key message I would like to share with you from my recent discussion with Carsten Maschmeyer, a start-up investor and judge of the German TV investment show "Die H√∂hle der L√∂wen".Our insights were: üëâ Founders of start-ups are emotionally very involved. Therefore, it is often not easy for them to delegate tasks. üëâ As the start-up grows, it‚Äôs crucial to establish hierarchies and to empower employees to take responsibility. üëâ Founders from start-ups can learn a lot from large companies: The willingness of education in hashtag#leadership, in time management, in hashtag#delegation and in active listening is a must. Thanks, Carsten, for joining me in my video format "Expect the Unexpected" and talking about start-up culture!What can leaders in large corporations on the other hand learn from founders in start-ups? I look forward to your comments. hashtag#TogetherTalanx hashtag#startup hashtag#DHDL

A full but fulfilling day in Brussels today. We launched Eurelectric‚Äôs study on the electricity market design fit for net zero, with a solid set of proposals just in time for the deliberations in Parliament and Council. I am grateful for the excellent exchange with representatives of the EU Commission, especially with the commissioner Kadri Simson, EU Parliament, ACER and the Swedish Presidency and upcoming Spanish Presidencies of the Council of the EU.¬†We have to join forces, industry, policy makers and society to make sure the electricity market framework delivers on the massive investment challenge already this decade. This is the right way. We must speed up the rollout of renewables and grids to power the necessary electrification of the system, empower consumers to benefit from cheaper renewable energy and ensuring security of supply in a changing energy system, that requires digital tools and flexibility. ¬†It is encouraging that the EU Commission‚Äôs proposal didn‚Äôt throw out the rulebook and recognizes the need to preserve the integrated single market for electricity. I would argue we need a deeper EU market and we count on Parliament and Council to keep this golden thread in the further deliberations on this important file.¬†Please find the Market Design Study and additional material here:¬†https://lnkd.in/dn3Zww3j #MarketdesignImage copyright: DAVID PLAS PHOTOGRAPHY

Our partnership with ScottishPower Renewables is a great example of what is possible when commitment to the common cause of hashtag#RenewableEnergy systems is unwavering. That is especially true in the difficult economic environment in which the entire European wind industry finds itself. And it is all the more reason to underscore today‚Äôs announcement that we at Siemens Gamesa will be supplying 95 units of our flagship offshore wind turbines, the SG 14-236 DD, to build the world‚Äôs second largest offshore wind park off England‚Äôs east coast. Congratulations to hashtag#TeamSiemensGamesa for making this great milestone possible. The East Anglia 3 wind power project will generate a capacity of 1.4 gigawatts brought to shore by Siemens Energy technology. Once completed, it will provide clean electricity to 1.3 million homes in the United Kingdom. This is an important step on the country‚Äôs path toward decarbonization. But it‚Äôs only a step. If the UK government wants to meet its targets for clean, secure, and affordable electricity by 2030, it needs to use wind energy as the strong lever it is. It needs to support the supply chains that are necessary for projects like East Anglia 3. Today we launched the EnergySphere as a central Hub for the energy transition in the heart of Berlin. A place that links the historical roots of our manufacturing sites with the on-site capability of taking innovative ideas and making them a reality. Why is this special? Because 45% of the technologies we expect to take us to net zero by 2050 are not ready for today‚Äôs market. Many are still in the prototype phase and need to be scaled up and implemented. What is required are places where innovative solutions can be developed in close collaboration between business, politics, and society. ‚û°Ô∏è Enter the EnergySphere Berlin: https://lnkd.in/ebv6-iN9. Thank you to the 200+ customers and investors who joined us on the tour of our Corporate-, Innovation- & Clean Energy Center today, as well as our Electrolyzer & Gas Turbine Manufacturing sites. I am especially proud of our Education House, where we can train our team to turn conventional products into new solutions and am looking forward to connecting Siemens Energy experts, partners, customers, and startups to energize society.  #energy #innovation #technology

Start-ups will fail if good leadership is missing.Every company once started as a start-up. And all of them face great challenges as they grow. Why? Leadership has to change. Especially in fast-growing companies. With a small team, you can talk every day. If the company gets bigger - and that is the goal - then it doesn't work anymore.What has to change? That's what I wanted to talk about and that's why I invited one of the best experts on the start-up scene to "Expect the Unexpected". In the video format, I exchange ideas with renowned scientists and thought leaders.Carsten Maschmeyer is invested in 140 start-ups in Europe and the US and is a judge on the TV investment show ‚ÄúDie H√∂hle der L√∂wen‚Äù. In the US, the comparable show is called "Shark Tank".It was really exciting to work out the similarities and differences in the topic of leadership in start-ups and large corporations. Because when start-ups grow, they face exactly the same challenges as large companies.What do you think: What can corporates learn from start-ups in the area of leadership and what can start-ups learn from large companies? hashtag#leadership hashtag#start-up hashtag#dhdl

When you ask people what concerns them these days, one issue is mentioned the most by individuals around the world: inflation. According to the survey ‚ÄúWhat worries the world‚Äù, conducted by the market research provider Ipsos, inflation has remained the top global concern for 11 consecutive months. Households worldwide face the rising cost of living and decreased purchasing power. ¬†At Allianz, we are in the business of protecting people and businesses from unexpected shocks, including economic ones. We believe that insurers are in a unique position to serve as a safety net in times of economic volatility. We have the ability to help mitigate the effects of inflation for both consumers and the wider economy. ¬†There are several management actions insurers can take to respond to inflation, beginning with customer communication, and including product innovation, investment in technology and digitalization, strategic partnerships, and diversification of investments. At Allianz, we have added inflation clauses to policies, worked with customers to update their sum insured data, and applied external inflation benchmarks where possible. Allianz Global Corporate & Specialty (AGCS) works with clients and brokers to update asset values and ensure clients have appropriate cover that is accurately priced. Incorporating an indexation feature in insurance policies, for instance, ensures that the policy benefits keep up with the rising costs of living and inflation. On the investment side, we‚Äôve increased allocations to inflation-linked bonds, providing additional protection in case inflation persists.¬†While we can‚Äôt control inflation, we can help cushion its blow by putting customer needs at the forefront and helping to secure their future by preserving their assets. ¬†Learn more about our approach here: ¬†https://lnkd.in/e-yvjZmy #AllianzOnCostofLiving #Inflation

Data can be both beautiful and brutal, as the new IPCC report makes clear. If we continue as before, our chances of achieving our climate goal are 'very low.' Despite this bleak reality, I am confident that we can turn things around.¬†We already know exactly what needs to be done. We know that we need to prioritize renewable energies and alternative raw materials, and we have a clear understanding of how much and where to source them. We know that until enough renewable energies and resources are available, we need to continue improving efficiency. And we know how to do that too. We also know that chemistry plays a crucial role in this #transformation. Because not only can we drastically reduce our own emissions, but also those of downstream supply chains that fuel almost all industries. And let's not forget that without chemistry there are no wind turbines, no solar panels, no electric cars, or building insulation.¬†I'm proud of our industry for maintaining the focus on sustainability, even in the face of immense challenges like the pandemic and Russian war. We have a huge responsibility, and¬†we¬†take it on.¬†If we speed up the expansion of renewable energies and open ourselves to new technologies and alternative raw materials. The #IPCCReport is both, a¬†scientific¬†wake-up call, and a call-to-action¬†to establish the policies that turn knowing into doing.#FullyCircular #IPCC

Yesterday the IPCC finalized its sixth Assessment Report on the current state of our climate. One question that has to be asked is: How many more climate reports will it take to recognize that we need immediate action instead of ideological debates? Climate change affects every corner of the world, and the science has never been clearer that every choice and every action to mitigate global warming counts. Whether you see the glass half-full or half-empty, what counts today is that you support the necessary solutions. Right now, to make the energy transition a success, we need to: expand renewables, strengthen electricity grids, drive efficiency improvements and decarbonization, prepare conventional power infrastructure for energy transition, and secure supply chains and minerals. Everything else is secondary. #IPCC #climatechange #climatereport

It is time to act! The new assessment report of the IPCC makes this more than clear. All efforts to achieve the energy transition must be significantly accelerated, which is especially true for planning and approval processes. E.ON is going ahead and plans to invest 33 billion euros in the energy infrastructure by 2027. This underpins our status as a pan-European company and the sustainable platform for the green energy transition in Europe. #netzero #sustainability #energytransition

A true story: How I learned first-hand that leaders need to empower their employees.When I was 30 years old, my boss gave me an opportunity I will never forget. It was a Friday evening, my boss had guests at home. So he entrusted me with running a major merger and acquisition project over the weekend. His hashtag#empowerment motivated me to put all my energy into making this project a success. This experience of hashtag#trust has greatly shaped my journey as a hashtag#leader. I often hear or read questions as: Isn't it my job as a leader to tell staff what to do? Isn‚Äôt it my job to tell them how to do it? In my eyes, the answer is: No. Our job as a leader is to empower our colleagues to make decisions on their own and develop their skills. Handing over decisions, delegating hashtag#responsibility and trusting employees - even in a world where there is often talk of new hashtag#leadership, there are still many fears associated with this. In my experience, it is important that we work on our relationships with people. In this way, we create an environment of psychological safety and trust, which is a prerequisite for top performance.What are your experiences on this topic?hashtag#TogetherTalanx

I have just returned from my visit to China, where during a busy week, I finally had the opportunity to meet our fantastic Siemens Energy team in person. The proposal for the #NetZeroIndustryAct, aka Europe's answer to the US Inflation Reduction Act is here. But will it bring long-awaited relief and planning security to the EU industry? I believe it can if all parties embrace and stick to their roles.¬†Our fast-moving and increasingly fragile world needs a strong industry as much as it needs a capable state. While our industry must continue to develop and deploy innovative technologies for the global sustainability transformation, the state must establish a reliable framework that allows the solutions to flourish. With a capable state determining the rules of the game ‚Äì but not the moves ‚Äì, Europe will be able to leave high energy costs, bureaucracy, and over-regulation behind and become a hub for the global green economy. In other words: the state's role must be the referee, not schoolmaster.

One in two people with cancer are afraid to tell their employers for fear of the impact it might have on their jobs. The #WorkingWithCancer pledge aims to support people with cancer in navigating their journey to recovery and making them feel safe in the workplace.¬†We are proud to join the Working with Cancer initiative and sign this pledge to underline our commitment to a supportive culture at work for people with cancer.¬†From awareness campaigns, cancer screening, and return-to-work programs to sharing colleagues' own stories of the impact of living with cancer, there are so many ways to drive awareness, provide support, and break the stigma around cancer.

At SAP, we fully support the objective of the EU Data Act to create a common regulatory framework for the data economy. Expanding data usage not only drives productivity and growth, but also helps us tackle #ClimateChange at scale. Reaching the full potential of a #DataEconomy, however, would require some changes to the current legislative proposal:1Ô∏è‚É£ Trade secrets must be protected if data sharing is made mandatory under the Data Act. In principle, B2B data sharing should be done on a voluntary basis and this is where Catena-X Automotive Network can serve as a strong best practice.2Ô∏è‚É£  Currently, it's unclear who will be obliged to share what kind of data with whom, which could lead to situations where, for example, businesses are forced to share highly confidential business data with competitors, which of course raises liability issues as well.3Ô∏è‚É£  Cloud switching provisions do not reflect the complexity and realities of the SaaS market: deadlines for cloud switching (e.g. 30 days, max. 6 months) are unrealistic in complex IT landscapes; fixed-term cloud contracts that are beneficial for providers and customers should not be questioned.Data use and sharing has the potential to positively impact our lives and our planet in many different ways, and I firmly believe changes such as the proposals above can help turn this potential into a reality.

This graphic makes my chemist heart skip a beat. Looking back, I'm amazed to see how many technological inventions were enabled by chemistry ‚Äì some more obviously than others. From the development of Penicillin in the 1900s to the very screen you're reading this on right now, chemistry has had a significant impact on almost every aspect of our lives that we cherish every day.¬†But looking into the future, the graphic also quietly demonstrates why the chemical industry's ongoing sustainability transformation is so important. We have to decouple our production from the use of fossils to reduce our impact on the environment. A #FullyCircular chemical industry will create a sustainable foundation for all downstream industries and pave the way for many more technological breakthroughs, advancing our lives and those of future generations.Hat tip to Our World in Data for the insightful graphic!  https://lnkd.in/eP5_ykN7

Out of the comfort zone is my motto for 2023. Especially in successful times, as we are currently experiencing at Deutsche Telekom, it is important to avoid complacency and to remain open to new #impulses. That's why I regularly visit the tech hubs of the world. Last week, my management team went to #Finland with the goal of gaining #inspiration, discussing strategic issues together and growing together as a team. Besides snow and double-digit sub-zero temperatures, we met great personalities and innovative companies. If you had to sum up Finnish culture and attitude in one word, it would be "SISU". It is probably best described as "inner strength", meaning determination, perseverance in difficult situations, tenacity and willpower. One example is the start-up Telehaptics #ai #work #management #people by founder Johannes V√§√§n√§nen, which wants to enable blind people to see contours and outlines again with the help of haptic impulses on the skin. With Nokia, we discussed how we can further advance the topic of ORAN. And we learned from the presentations on the latest brand transformation how important a common identity and vision is, especially for the culture of a company. I was also very impressed by the Finnish telecommunications company Elisa. The Veli-Matti Mattila did an internship at Telekom in D√ºsseldorf in 1980. And in the past 21 years as CEO, he has built a very innovative telco that has great expertise in artificial intelligence (AI), automation and data analytics. These skills are not only used to improve internal processes, but are also sold as a service to other companies or telcos around the world. Lapland (S√°pmi) offers one of the most impressive natural landscapes in the world. The S√°mi live in harmony with nature and wildlife under harsh, arctic conditions. For visitors, however, various amenities such as sauna, warm room temperatures and flexible mobility are maintained. It made me realize once again that we are all challenged and must work harder to find intelligent solutions to the #climate crisis. This applies to companies like Telekom and to every individual. And that will also have to involve making sacrifices!

Siemens Healthineers is built on a strong foundation, our common purpose: "We pioneer breakthroughs in #healthcare ‚Äì for everyone, everywhere." This is the foundation and engine of everything we do. Today, we have boldly laid another strong foundation: for our new #innovation center in #Bengaluru, the "Silicon Valley" of #India. This center is our company's #responsibility made reality, towards our customers, their patients, and society as a whole. It will be housed in a new state-of-the-art campus that combines our existing R&D center and an ultra-modern medical imaging factory. With one in two of our software engineers working in Bengaluru, our team in India has played an increasingly critical role in the development of sophisticated software and artificial intelligence for years. Many thanks for this incredible build-up work and passion! With the new campus, we are now opening the next chapter to continue our success story in India: With a total value of 160 million euros, it is one of our biggest investments worldwide and the largest we so far have made in India, which plays an important role as a growth market for our company. In the near future, around 5,500 of our almost 7,000 employees in India will be working on the new campus.We utilize our technologies and solutions to take on the major challenges facing healthcare across the globe. For example, half of the world's population lacks adequate access to medical care, the number of chronically ill people is rising around the globe, and there is a shortage of skilled medical professionals. I am convinced that innovative technologies have a decisive role to play in overcoming these challenges. And that‚Äôs why we build this campus. It will help us to advance the #digitalization of healthcare all over the world, while also providing even better service for the needs of emerging countries. I wish success, happiness and health to all the people working on this building today and to those who will fill it with life and ideas. May they always stand on a strong foundation.

One of my favorite quotes:It is natural for a man who does not understand the workings of a machine to imagine that a shaving that has fallen into it by chance and is interfering with its action and tossing about in it is its most important part. The man who does not understand the construction of the machine cannot conceive that the small connecting cogwheel which revolves quietly is one of the most essential parts of the machine, and not the shaving which merely harms and hinders the working.- Leo Tolstoy in ‚ÄúWar and Peace‚Äù

Which low-carbon pathways can lead us to net zero? This is the question we asked ourselves this week at CERAWeek. The reality is that there is no one-size-fits-all solution. Each country faces different challenges, requiring a diverse approach of multiple technologies to drive the energy transition forward. One element is crucial: the need for a more robust grid is crucial to manage the increasing share of renewables and growing electrification.¬†The challenge of rebuilding the grid in certain places where it is insufficient and extending it in other areas to better connect regions and communities can‚Äôt be overestimated. ‚¨áÔ∏è Challenges however, that are outweighed by the huge opportunity of unleashing the potential of affordable and clean energy. To quote Felipe Bayon from the panel discussion: ‚ÄúWithout transmission, there is no transition.‚Äù ‚ö°hashtag#netzero hashtag#energytransition hashtag#ceraweek

Embracing equity is not a nice-to-have, it's an absolute necessity.We can only achieve the global sustainability transformation if we allow, accept, and embrace ideas regardless of gender and background ‚Äì we need all hands on deck if we are to create a truly sustainable future for ourselves and future generations. That's why I believe it's our responsibility as leaders to #EmbraceEquity. I'm proud of my colleagues at Covestro, who not only share this belief, but are taking a variety of effective steps to make our organization more diverse, equitable, and inclusive every day.#IWD2023 #InternationalWomensDay

#InternationalWomensDay serves as an annual reminder to champion gender equality, but, to transform gender equality into reality, we need to take action every day.¬†A recent survey conducted by Allianz emphasizes the urgency of this need, revealing the financial barriers women are still facing in 2023. Early data from the soon-to-be-released survey confirms that, despite progress in many areas, structural barriers still prevent many women from making bold, fulfilling career choices that could lead to greater financial security. ¬†This global challenge is too big for any one organization or individual to tackle alone. It requires collective action. At Allianz, we are committed to being a model for institutional change on this issue. We prioritize gender #diversity in our leadership roles and workforce at large, and continue to make progress on addressing gender-related pay, pension and protection gaps. And, to help women grow their hard-earned money, we promote financial literacy education programs to inform smart financial decision-making. Our strategy embeds Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion across the whole business, placing employees, customers, and stakeholders at the center of change. I am proud to say that this is reflected in our status as an EDGE Access-certified insurer, and also being included in the top five most gender equitable companies of the Equileap Global Gender Equality Report 2023. ¬†We‚Äôre proud of these achievements, but we also do not lose sight of the work still needed today, and the days ahead, on the road to #EmbraceEquity. ¬†#Allianz #FinancialLiteracy #IWD2023

Today, the long-term success of a company is not only measured by financial indicators like the increase in sales or profits. Guided by our purpose ‚Äì ‚ÄúWe Secure your Future‚Äù ‚Äì sustainability is fundamental to the way we do business and the cornerstone of our success. Our new Sustainability Report, published today, reflects the work done across Allianz in 2022, in cooperation with our many partners, that helps build, grow, and protect more resilient lives, businesses, and economies.I am particularly proud of four aspects: ‚û° Operational progress toward net-zero ‚Äì We‚Äôve set ambitious new commitments for our own operations, including a reinforced target of reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions arising from Allianz activities in over 70 markets to #netzero by 2030, with an aim to reach the 2050 goal earlier than originally planned. ‚û° Our business strategies to deliver climate solutions, such as adjusting our thermal coal investment and underwriting strategy to be more inclusive of low-carbon energy efforts.‚û° Education and job training, especially for the most vulnerable members of society. Through various initiatives such as the #MoveNow Training Series and Social Impact Fund, we help provide education and job training to vulnerable members of society, with a focus on preparing youth and people with disabilities for employment in a transitioning economy. ‚û° Leadership and commitment to diversity, equity and inclusion ‚Äì we believe that a thriving work environment is one that is welcoming and inclusive. I am also proud of Allianz being a #Valuable500 Iconic Leader company and part of the United Nations Women‚Äôs Empowerment Principles charter. I‚Äôm grateful to Allianz employees across the globe who work hard and are dedicated to managing our business sustainably. Their contributions, including the development of this report, are deeply appreciated. This mural has a history. Plaksha University was being incubated at Nagarro in its early days, and Ken Singer was visiting from the University of California, Berkeley. He‚Äôs incredibly creative and energetic and he suggested that people are most happy and productive when they can personalise their surroundings. So in that entire office, we just offered up all our walls to the teams to do with them what they liked. The results were extraordinary! So, not only is this mural creative, the process by which it came into being was also creative.

It‚Äôs a question of trust.hashtag#bigdata, hashtag#smartdata and hashtag#artificialintelligence like hashtag#chatgpt are on everyone's lips. But how do you identify information that is strong and reliable enough for making good business decisions? Do we as leaders prefer to rely on figures provided by people who have advised us well in the past? Potentially information from people who have reached a certain hierarchical level or a certain age? Should we listen to the strong signals of today or attend more to the weak qualitative signals that could potentially have a major effect in the future?One thing is clear: especially in a hashtag#vucaworld that is increasingly characterised by a polycrisis, traditional predictions based on strong signals provided by big and smart data often prove to be wrong. Weak signals are becoming more and more important. As leaders, we need a maximally broad picture to make the right decisions. That‚Äôs why ‚Äì above all ‚Äì a culture of hashtag#trust is needed within a company. Only then will employees have the courage to express an opinion and put forward arguments even on the basis of weak signals that could trigger a meaningful trend ‚Äì regardless of their role or age.What‚Äôs your take on this subject? I look forward to receiving your thoughts. In the carousel below, I‚Äôve put together further information for you on the issue of weak signals. hashtag#TogetherTalanx

Today marks one year since Putin began his ruthless war against hashtag#Ukraine ‚Äì a war that flies in the very face of international law. What was unthinkable after all the decades of hard work to establish a peaceful European order with Russia all the sudden became a reality: a major armed conflict whose effects would be felt throughout the world. But what Putin and his cronies didn‚Äôt expect is that we would stand together with such resolve and solidarity with the Ukrainian people. It was a wake-up call, and if anything, it has brought us closer together. Today, in remembrance of those who have lost their lives, I stand in solidarity with the victims‚Äô families, who for years to come will be plagued by the question: What if? What if Russia had never invaded? What if my friend, my child, or my better half were still here to see another day? As a father and husband, this is a question I never want to have to ask myself. May this war come to a swift end so that we can focus our energies, together, on issues that unite us.

We approach the one-year mark of the most severe challenge to global security in decades. The brutal invasion of Ukraine has shaken foundational democratic principles to their core and brought into focus a factor that we had previously taken for granted: the availability of energy. Over the past weekend, the Munich Security Conference has proven a timely opportunity to take stock of the political, business, and social security landscape. I want to use the space here to share some of the essential discussion points of the last few days in Munich. ‚¨áÔ∏è#MSC2023¬†#security¬†#innovation

The Munich Security Conference is far more than a forum for pure debate. It is also an important venue for initiating concrete action. Here, we took an important step yesterday. Under the leadership of the Munich Security Conference, Breakthrough Energy ‚Äì represented by Bill Gates ‚Äì and Siemens Energy, we discussed concrete options to deploy clean energy technologies within 12 to 24 months that will help reduce Europe's dependence on natural gas. On site, the three start-ups Malta Inc, Rondo Energy, ecoworks clearly showed that technological solutions exist. The issue is implementation ‚Äì and this from a political, economic and financial point of view. The Energy Resilience Leadership Group, formed yesterday, aims to overcome this. And work on solutions to spread these technologies. The fact that the event was attended by EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, Vice Chancellor Robert Habeck, European Investment Bank President Werner Hoyer and around 20 CEOs from leading industrial companies shows that the urgency has been recognized. Together, we will now work on concrete solutions that will help CleanTech technologies achieve a breakthrough. We want to and will be measured against this. I look forward to the next steps.hashtag#MSC2023 hashtag#security hashtag#innovation hashtag#energyresilience Picture credits: MSC / Johannes Krey

Energy has become the No. 1 security factor in the world. This makes innovative technologies all the more necessary, not only in the energy sector. That is why we kicked off this year‚Äôs Munich Security Conference by discussing the importance of innovation.  ‚¨áÔ∏èWe require much faster implementation of inventions in the public sector to scale up clean energy innovation. Why? Because innovation is achieved through implementation! 40% of the technologies we expect to take us to net zero by 2050 are still in prototype or not yet known at all. That is why we need to help each other across market sectors to identify and scale up energy innovations by removing regulatory roadblocks. Europe has this potential, and it is now down to us in business, policy, and academia to use it.  hashtag#MSC2023 hashtag#security hashtag#innovation

Together with RWE, Daniel Reinhardt and hashtag#TeamSiemensGamesa have spent the last three years installing the Kaskasi project, a turning point in long-term, sustainable offshore wind power. But the magnitude of hashtag#Kaskasi is small compared to Germany‚Äôs offshore wind energy ambitions: 30 gigawatts by 2030. Because we need to close the gap between political ambitions and actual installation permits.We need hashtag#MoreWindNow. "Pandemic. War. Financial market turmoil. These crises are changing a lot of things. How can insurers win in the process?"This central question is discussed by experts from the insurance industry at the event SZ Versicherungstag, hosted by Judith Wittwer Herter and Herbert Fromme.I had the honour of giving the dinner speech last night. Many thanks to the organisers for the invitation!I would like to share some key points from my talk with you: üëâ The world is facing a polycrisis. Crises no longer follow one another but take place simultaneously and intensify. Forecasts are becoming more and more difficult as a result. üëâ Smart data based on big data are no longer sufficient as strong signals for control mechanisms in complex systems such as companies. üëâ In the New Normal, the recognition of "weak signals" - ambiguous, qualitative and intuitive signals - is therefore becoming increasingly important. With our hashtag#culture of hashtag#trust, our decentralized structure, and a focus on a relative performance to the market we at hashtag#Talanx Group have laid the right foundation for the detection of weak signals. I‚Äôm looking forward to pursuing this path further.hashtag#TogetherTalanx

Heute in Cuxhaven hat eine steife Brise gezeigt, wie viel hashtag#Energie im Wind steckt. In unserem Siemens Gamesa Werk f√ºr Offshore-Maschinenh√§user durfte ich Bundeswirtschafts- und Klimaschutzminister Robert Habeck zeigen, wie wir diese Energie einfangen und f√ºr Millionen von Menschen zur Verf√ºgung stellen k√∂nnen.  Vor und w√§hrend des Rundgangs durch unsere Fertigung haben wir uns √ºber die gro√üe Aufgabe unterhalten, die uns mit dem Ausbau der hashtag#Windenergie bevorsteht. Vor einigen Jahren h√§tten wir die hashtag#Energiewende im gem√ºtlichen Dauerlauf umsetzen k√∂nnen. Doch wir haben wertvolle Zeit verloren, w√§hrend die Strecke vor uns dieselbe geblieben ist. Deshalb m√ºssen wir jetzt zum Sprint anziehen. Denn in weniger als zehn Jahren m√ºssen wir sowohl hashtag#Onshore als auch hashtag#Offshore noch einmal die gleiche Leistung installieren wie seit Beginn der Energiewende in den 1990er Jahren.  Wir k√∂nnen unsere Ziele im Kampf gegen die hashtag#Klimakrise nur dann erreichen, wenn Politik und die Herstellerinnen von Windenergieanlagen an einem Strang ziehen. Today in Cuxhaven, Germany, the weather demonstrated the potential of hashtag#WindEnergy. At our Siemens Gamesa plant for offshore nacelles, I met with Germany‚Äôs Minister of Economic Affairs and Climate Action Robert Habeck and showed him how we can capture this limitless source of energy. How we can make it available to millions of people.  Before and while touring our manufacturing facility, we talked about the task of massively expanding wind energy. A few years ago, we could have implemented the hashtag#EnergyTransition at a leisurely pace. But we‚Äôve lost valuable time ‚Äì and the way ahead has not gotten any shorter. That‚Äôs why we have to speed it up now. Because in less than ten years, we will have to install the same amount of power in Germany, both hashtag#onshore and hashtag#offshore, that we‚Äôve installed since the 1990s.  We can only solve our hashtag#ClimateCrisis if politicians and wind turbine manufacturers work closely together. In concrete terms:  We now need to move very quickly from targets to implementation. Yesterday, the German cabinet took an important step toward accelerating wind expansion. That step must now be adopted by the Bundestag and implemented by the federal states. We also need the commitment of the federal states to the area targets for onshore wind.  We need to create investment security for urgently needed capacities by turning targets into orders. Only a small portion of offshore projects is in the hands of developers, even fewer projects are in our order books. But investment decisions have to be made now ‚Äì not only by us but also by suppliers, and for the installation of wind turbines, by ports and ships. An additional challenge is the enormous expansion planned for the end of this decade. A more even distribution of volumes with our European neighbors would be helpful.  Robert Habeck has already set a lot in motion. And he has done so at a time that no government could have predicted. I am very grateful for his visit today. And for discussing the challenges facing the industry. We have no more time to lose, everyone must be aware of that. We will win the fight against hashtag#ClimateChange and for hashtag#EnergySovereignty only when business, politics, and society work hand in glove. hashtag#MoreWindNow

When central banks raise interest rates, it creates ripple effects throughout the global economy. A recent Allianz Economic Research report helps quantify the significance of recent and upcoming rate hikes in the Eurozone and beyond, including the impact on government debt burdens.  I share the view that strong inflation dynamics will continue to put pressure on the European Central Bank and other central banks to keep interest rates elevated, in order to slow the rate of inflation.  So, what does this mean in terms of real impact on peoples‚Äô lives? The answer is not simple. Elevated interest rates can affect individuals and businesses in different ways. This report from Allianz Research helps to raise awareness of the issue and explores the potential consequences that rate hikes may have on individuals and businesses alike. For example, commercial businesses that rely on debt funding may face some hardship. Many people may face further increases in their cost of living, while others may actually benefit from higher interest earnings on their savings accounts. Regardless of one‚Äôs financial circumstance, uncertainty abounds. And, in uncertain times, there can be a tendency to overestimate short-term impacts and underestimate the long-term effect. While current economic conditions may require a temporary tightening of the belt, for instance, it‚Äôs important to also not lose sight of long-term financial goals.  The future starts with financial literacy. I encourage you to explore the insight that Allianz Economic Research publishes regularly, designed to help individuals, businesses and investors better understand the economic issues impacting their financial decisions. It is a helpful perspective on navigating through these uncertain times. Read the full research report here: https://lnkd.in/eqGGNYbJ  hashtag#Allianz hashtag#ECB hashtag#financialliteracy

Siemens Gamesa just reached a new milestone in global wind turbine sales: 5 GW of 5.X onshore wind platforms. Despite many hurdles, the platform is on its way to becoming the hashtag#WindIndustry benchmark.  Over 150 wind turbines are now installed, and there will be roughly 1,000 when all 5 GW of installations are complete. These wind turbines will power over four million homes and help avoid over 13 million tons of CO2 emissions a year, benefitting the communities where we operate around the world both economically and environmentally. However, this achievement didn‚Äôt come easy.  We faced exceptional circumstances, ranging from the wind turbine‚Äôs development and production, to a global pandemic which led to severe supply chain constraints, rising inflation and shipping costs. Yet our teams navigated these challenges and developed an even more mature product in the process. Our engineers, for example, worked hard behind the scenes to make this the company‚Äôs fastest-selling hashtag#onshore wind turbine technology in operation today.  If the demand for onshore wind and the 5.X platform is as large as we expect, then we need to push for continued installations. We must continue advocating for hashtag#WindNow ‚Äì for a greener future.  Read more about the 5.X platform and our next steps below. https://lnkd.in/dsV7Bfy5 hashtag#OnshoreWind hashtag#EnergyCrisis hashtag#EnergyIndependence hashtag#EnergySecurity hashtag#EnergyTransition hashtag#EnergyPolicy hashtag#GreenEnergy hashtag#RenewableEnergy hashtag#WindIndustry hashtag#ClimateChange

At this week‚Äôs World Economic Forum in Davos, the mood was sober but purposeful.¬†Leaders, advocates, and experts from across sectors were focused less on debate and more on collaborative action, working together to solve the entrenched environmental, economic, and social challenges facing our post-Covid, war-torn new world order.  In a chat with Richard Quest, CNN's foremost international business correspondent, I was asked to choose my ‚Äúbiggest worry‚Äù on the ‚ÄúWorry Board.‚Äù It was a difficult question for me to answer because I am not a¬†worrier by nature. In fact, contrary to worry, what I experienced at Davos this week was pragmatic optimism and determination. Discussions rightfully focused on accelerating implementation ‚Äì through collective action ‚Äì of existing solutions that we already know can reduce the effects of climate change, energy insecurity, and social polarization. Watch the full CNN conversation here: https://lnkd.in/dnNVK32J  hashtag#Allianz hashtag#WEF23 hashtag#DemocraciesDeliver

The ‚ÄúCoalition of Trade Ministers on Climate‚Äù was launched yesterday during the World Economic Forum‚Äôs Annual Meeting. It will be instrumental in bringing about the policies and collaboration we need to create a truly green economy. By bringing ministers from countries around the world together, the Coalition stands a real chance of increasing international cooperation in the fight against climate change.I look forward to seeing the results of this cooperation. Because one thing is clear: Climate change and economic stability are not merely local issues. They are global in nature and therefore require global collaboration. For the wind industry specifically, we need more collaboration around energy, trade and industrial polices. There were many extremely important topics discussed at #WEF23. I cannot and should not try to give a summary of everything here. Therefore here's a short summary of what I personally found noteworthy, what I learnt, and what it means for Siemens Healthineers and for global #healthcare.

Impacts of hashtag#climatechange are evident worldwide, and the need to accelerate the transition to hashtag#netzero is clearer than ever. Capital to fund that clean energy transition is¬†available, but the challenge now is ensuring it reaches the regions and economies that need it the most.  Collaboration is vital, and the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting is the right place to foster cooperation. Yesterday I had the honor to join a panel on Climate Finance in Davos ‚Äì moderated by Richard Quest, CNN's foremost international business correspondent. It was a pleasure to engage in a thought-provoking dialogue with Kristalina Georgieva, Patrick Khulekani Dlamini, and Bill Winters about how to finance climate technologies and infrastructure projects that reduce emissions. Immediate action is needed. There are three changes that will help to accelerate speed: 1. tangible deadlines2. simplification of processes, and3. adaption of solutions that already exist.  In vulnerable, hard-hit regions financing climate projects is also dependent on¬†public lenders and governments opening their doors to collaboration.¬†Governments alone can‚Äôt finance the high demand, but they can prioritize climate considerations in policymaking and work with finance partners on long-term development plans. The financial models exist. The¬†political will must catch up. Watch the panel session recording here: https://lnkd.in/eQyks5y9 hashtag#Allianz hashtag#WEF23 hashtag#DemocraciesDeliver

The theme dominating the World Economic Forum in Davos this week: ‚ÄúCooperation in a fragmented world.‚Äù Around 2,700 participants from politics, business and society have come together as global challenges call for global leadership. The first verdict of the past days: the theme is fitting. There is indeed a great willingness to cooperate among the various interest groups. Everyone is aware of the urgency to act. This is particularly true in the context of the energy transition, which is finally being seen not only as a challenge but also as an opportunity. 50 billion U.S. dollars in investment requirements by 2030 speak a clear language for this.  In the many discussion rounds, however, it also became clear that we will only achieve energy security if we make the energy system of the future affordable, reliable and sustainable. Sustainability is and must be at the center of an overarching concept of energy resilience ‚Äì and we can only achieve this together.  Very positive highlight: The EU ‚Äì especially in the person of Ursula von der Leyen ‚Äì as well as other regions have made a strong commitment to further accelerate the energy transition and the cleantech sector. The industry stands ready. However, it must also be a matter of giving special support to economic sectors that are not healthy, such as wind power. Only if we jointly address the framework conditions and improve auction mechanisms, for example, will we be able to remain competitive in an inflationary environment at present. Also high on the agenda is making mineral supply chains resilient. After all, they are a fundamental prerequisite for accelerating the energy transition. My conclusion these days is: much can be done, some has already been achieved, but much more work is needed. In this sense, the World Economic Forum was a good springboard to move some of the issues forward. hashtag#WEF hashtag#WEF23 hashtag#Davos Siemens Energy

If there‚Äôs one priority that‚Äôs top of mind for business leaders right now, it‚Äôs resilience. Resilience in times of cyber threats and business interruptions, alongside macroeconomic challenges like inflation and the energy crisis.  The 12th annual Allianz Risk Barometer 2023 released this week provides insight into how business models are vulnerable to sudden shocks and change, with cybersecurity being the top business concern for the second year running. High-speed digitalization positively reshapes our world in many ways, but it also has dramatically increased business digital vulnerabilities, such as IT outages, ransomware attacks, or data breaches. Ensuring digital resilience ‚Äì both protection and recovery from cyber incidents ‚Äì must be one of the top priorities on every boardroom‚Äôs agenda.  The energy crisis, natural catastrophes, and climate change are also considered top 10 risks in this year‚Äôs Allianz Risk Barometer ‚Äì a clear reminder that risk priorities are intrinsically linked to the health of our planet and driving sustainability. Especially given the economic fallout from the energy crisis, the findings affirm how investments in diverse renewable energy sources can help make companies more resilient and efficient. Companies that focus on hashtag#sustainableaction also solve many of their other challenges at the same time.  Check out the top 10 risks in the video below, and find more information on our risk barometer here: https://lnkd.in/e9wGxTh3hashtag#ARB2023

New Siemens Gamesa white paper: U.S. policymakers and industry have a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to build a future in which the United States reaches its hashtag#ClimateTargets. And that‚Äôs significant, because the world can‚Äôt curb climate change without the United States. Of course, policymakers reached a major milestone with their landmark legislation last year. But there‚Äôs much more to be done to capitalize on this opportunity to create hashtag#GreenJobs, bring about hashtag#EconomicOpportunity and, ultimately, reduce the United States‚Äô hashtag#CarbonEmissions. Wind energy is indispensable for that ‚Äì something we‚Äôve emphasized in our latest white paper, ‚ÄúScaling up the American wind industry,‚Äù linked below. But what will it take? Here are a few highlights from the paper: üî∑  There needs to be hashtag#clarification on the rules related to prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements, U.S. domestic content requirements, and U.S. wind-turbine manufacturing incentives. Only then can we drive sustainability and growth in U.S. supply chains.üî∑  We need to have hashtag#InflationCompensationMechanisms in contracts with offshore wind developers ‚Äì including the indexing of material, transport, and labor costs. Because as is so often the case, manufacturers in the wind industry bear the brunt of unforeseen costs resulting from inflation.üî∑  We need to address the growing wind hashtag#WorkforceGap. There is already a shortage of qualified workers in the wind industry, and an expanding U.S. wind market driven by recent federal incentives will only exacerbate the problem. More attention needs to be paid to attracting and training the wind-industry workforce. üî∑  And there needs to be a build-out of new hashtag#TransmissionInfrastructure and clean-energy projects at an unprecedented scale. And for that, project developers will need greater certainty on permitting timelines. But it‚Äôs not only about what government can do. We, the wind industry, also have a lot of work to do. That includes rebalancing the existing cost-sharing structure across stakeholders who are behind the build-out of the industry. This would help tackle the unequal distribution of risk between developers and manufacturers, which in the wind industry is unlike anything seen in other industries. The United States has the potential to create a true clean-energy economy, and we at Siemens Gamesa are fully committed to helping make it happen. hashtag#wef23 hashtag#OffshoreWind hashtag#EnergySecurity hashtag#EnergyTransition hashtag#EnergyPolicy hashtag#GreenEnergy hashtag#RenewableEnergy World Economic Forum, Global Wind Energy Council (GWEC), International Energy Agency (IEA) https://bit.ly/3H2d8QN

Human society operates on trust. Trust is needed to help solve today‚Äôs multiple challenges, from fragile food and energy supplies, to the soaring cost of living and the burdens of climate change. On an institutional and societal level, trust can be earned through transparency, open discussions, partnerships, and collaboration ‚Äî and most important, action. That‚Äôs why I have high expectations for this year‚Äôs World Economic Forum in Davos. The event‚Äôs motto ‚Äì ‚Äúcooperation in a fragmented world‚Äù ‚Äì is extremely fitting. This is our chance to bring together government, business, and civil society to deliver outcomes that reinforce people‚Äôs trust in institutions, leading to a more open, secure, and promising future.My long-term wish list of outcomes for Davos includes specific solutions for the following challenges, swipe to see them.hashtag#Allianz hashtag#WEF23

‚úîÔ∏è 2022 ends with good news for hashtag#WindEnergy: Earlier this week, the EU‚Äôs energy ministers agreed on emergency rules to accelerate the permitting of renewable projects. We at Siemens Gamesa welcome the leadership of the European institutions and EU member states. But time and again, the European hashtag#wind industry has proven that it can get the job done. We are ready to turn installation targets into reality. The issue is that projects get stuck in different permitting stages. These long permit-granting processes result in a mismatch between the targeted renewable volumes and reality. We all need to work closely together: international institutions, governments, non-governmental organizations ‚Äì and members of the entire value chain of renewables (including developers, off takers, original equipment manufacturers, suppliers of components, etc.). Because installed wind energy will help reduce energy bills, create sustainable jobs, foster entrepreneurship, and incentivize further technological breakthroughs. What will follow this week‚Äôs agreement? ‚öñÔ∏è The emergency measures on permitting will be in force for 18 months. In a few weeks from now, the EU member states and the European parliament will begin negotiations on a final text of the revised renewables directive. Because we all need a strong European wind industry. üëèüèª To quote the President of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen: ‚ÄúSupporting the clean transition is the right thing to do, if you are doing it right. In a transparent manner. In a spirit of cooperation. And in a way that ensures a level playing field. It should be a race against time. Not against each other‚Äù. üôåüèª That‚Äôs the spirit we need going forward. That is how 2023 can become the year of renewables. Let‚Äôs seize this opportunity, this moment of hashtag#WindNow. There is ‚Äúunprecedented momentum for hashtag#renewables,‚Äù according to the International Energy Agency (IEA)‚Äôs ‚ÄúRenewables 2022‚Äù report. They claim that from 2022-2027, ‚Äúrenewables are seen growing by almost 2,400 GW, equal to the entire installed power capacity of China today ‚Äì an 85% acceleration from the previous five years.‚Äù Here‚Äôs the issue: According to the report, by the end of that period hashtag#onshore wind is only expected to break its annual installation record set in 2020. That‚Äôs much too slow, and it‚Äôs a result of lengthy hashtag#permitting processes and a lack of improvement to grid hashtag#infrastructures. When it comes to Europe and hashtag#offshore wind, the challenges aren‚Äôt any fewer: Europe‚Äôs share of overall installed offshore capacity is expected to decline from 50% in 2021 to 30% in 2027.  That aside, there is much to be optimistic about in the IEA‚Äôs report, but it also only confirms what the European wind industry has been asking hashtag#policymakers for, namely: ‚ñ™ simplified and faster permitting processes, which have to apply to both new and pending projects;‚ñ™ grid investments and transparent grid-access rules; and‚ñ™ an overall European industrial policy that creates the right framework conditions.  I highly recommend you read the report. A pressing topic at the recent hashtag#COP27 climate negotiations in Egypt was ‚Äúloss and damages‚Äù or how wealthy nations have a responsibility to help poorer countries cope with the effects of climate change. Government policy plays an important role, but so does the private sector. Often there is a misconception that private capital is not available to fund the development needed to make vulnerable countries more climate resilient. In fact, there‚Äôs plenty of untapped private capital ‚Äì and expertise ‚Äì available. And many institutional investors want to invest their capital into green economy projects in emerging markets. The issue is not capital availability, it‚Äôs risk and how to manage it. To bring more attention to this issue, I recently collaborated with Makhtar Diop, Managing Director at IFC - International Finance Corporation, on a feature that explores the climate project opportunities in emerging markets. One example of this is the Allianz- and IFC-funded program, ‚ÄòManaged Co-Lending Portfolio Platform One Planet‚Äô, which connected global institutional investors and enabled up to $3 billion of new financing for climate projects in countries that need them the most. It is our hope that this project and similar ones, such as the Emerging Market Climate Action Fund, will serve as a guide for private capital mobilization at scale in emerging and developing markets. Sincere thanks to¬†Context Newsroom¬†for the opportunity to shine a light on this topic and make the path to hashtag#netzero a little brighter. Here are our takeaways. https://lnkd.in/edFXAJiyhashtag#Allianz hashtag#AllianzOnClimate

There is no better image to illustrate this post than my last photo as CEO of hashtag#SiemensSpain at the historic Christmas Concert. A snapshot, in which I am surrounded by customers, partners, colleagues and friends to lead the last notes of the melody of this farewell message.Farewells are never easy. Even more so if you have spent the last 21 years living, building, and experiencing the values of a company. Today Im closing an important chapter in my career. Today is my last day at Siemens.Since 2018 when I accepted the position of CEO of Siemens in hashtag#Spain, I have made the maxim "If you can imagine it, you can create it " my own. Therefore, my goal has always been the same: to contribute from Siemens for the country to move forward and become stronger.We have managed to make our country one of the centers of cybersecurity for Siemens; we have incorporated Spanish talent with strategic acquisitions to strengthen our digital portfolio such as FORAN and, more recently, Innovation Strategies, S.L.; and we have actively promoted strategic projects for the economy such as the naval PERTE, the electric vehicle, among others. All of this brings us closer to the decarbonization of the economy and what we at hashtag#Siemens call a Spain 5.0, more digital, sustainable and people centered. It has not been easy. It has been a complex and tough stage. The COVID turned everything upside down. And, since then, the vulnerability of our way of life has become more visible.However, the difficulties have also brought out the best in us: solidarity, resilience, and the ability to reinvent ourselves and work together to move forward.The passionate commitment from my colleagues, my board and our partners has been constant. Without that, our impact would not have been possible. It has been an immense honor of serving this exceptional team for the past years.More in the comments...

Leaders are facing a big challenge: we find ourselves in a kind of echo chamber when we only hear the same voices in the company. How do we get out of it? The answer is: Speak up and active listening! I was delighted to talk to the wonderful Megan Reitz in "Expect the Unexpected" about this topic, which is very close to my personal heart. Megan is one of the world's leading management thinkers and an absolute authority on her subject: feedback culture. For us, feedback is a crucial part of our corporate culture, consisting of collaboration, engagement and transparency - and the basis of all this is trust. To help us improve, we invited Megan to our Executive Meeting this year, because feedback culture has a high priority for us. Thanks a lot Megan, it was great to discuss with you. How do we create an environment where everyone feels the psychological safety to raise their hand and say: I have something to contribute. Or, often more importantly: I have another idea.Thanks to Dr. Thomas Ramge. Especially for the fantastic first question that immediately got us into the discussion: What was the harshest feedback you ever got?It was a very intense conversation that once again made me very aware: It is the special challenge for a person in a position of perceived power to listen and to make it easier for people in the company to express their opinion and to openly disagree.Only this will lead us to the best solutionsand makes us successful in the long term. And that is precisely why it is important to me. hashtag#together hashtag#expecttheunexpected hashtag#hdi hashtag#Leadership hashtag#feedback Wolfgang Jenewein

What will it take to ‚Äúweather the storms‚Äù in an era defined by climate change and the increasing costs of extreme damage? As we begin to move out of the 2022 hurricane season and take stock of its impact, it is worth reflecting on longer-term implications and the role of our industry in managing them.  The insurance industry has a direct view into the devastating consequences of hurricanes and other extreme weather events, such as floods, which are likely to increase in frequency and severity with climate change. As a result, we must play a central role in climate change mitigation, adaptation and resilience ‚Äì not just because it makes good business sense, but because it makes the world more livable for everyone. At Allianz, we take this responsibility seriously. First, we constantly work to develop new products and services to respond to climate change. Our Allianz Climate Change Risk Solutions, for instance, quantify changes in expected damages to our insurance and investment portfolios due to physical climate change impacts. This helps inform how we support our customers in building resilience and our own long-term investment decisions, thereby lowering risk over time.  Second, we collaborate with experts in academia. Our annual Allianz Climate Research Risk Award, for example, identifies research that advances better understanding of and adapt to climate change.  Third, we support public private partnerships, such as via the UK Build Back Better Scheme. These partnerships aim to cover high-risk areas with affordable premiums via pool solutions, which also enable investments in resiliency measures.  We can‚Äôt hold back the storms, but we can fortify our resilience to them. Through innovation, collaboration, and economies of scale, we can rebuild our world in a new and more sustainable image. Full Allianz Climate Research Risk Award here: https://lnkd.in/eZVZzHJyhashtag#Allianz hashtag#COP27 hashtag#AllianzonClimate

The energy transitions of the past were catalyzed by major economic and geopolitical challenges. The world is at another such inflection point.‚ÄúRecover Together, Recover Stronger‚Äù is this year‚Äôs theme at the hashtag#G20 summit in Bali, Indonesia. On the heels of hashtag#COP27, and in a year fraught with climate-related catastrophes, geopolitical confrontations, and geo-economic disasters, the G20 members have set three very clear priorities on their agenda ‚Äì one of which is the sustainable energy transition. Rightly so. Because accelerating the transition toward greener energy systems, especially through wind power, is as much a challenge as it is an opportunity: an opportunity to work together in stabilizing supply chains. And a chance to foster global trade agreements that create jobs, usher in a new era of economic opportunity, create a more sustainable and livable world, and ensure energy security.  hashtag#OffshoreWind hashtag#OnshoreWind hashtag#EnergyCrisis hashtag#EnergyIndependence hashtag#EnergySecurity hashtag#EnergyTransition hashtag#EnergyPolicy hashtag#GreenEnergy hashtag#RenewableEnergy

This week I had the honor of giving the opening address at the Handelsblatt Insurance Summit and the pleasure of chatting with Christian Schnell, financial correspondent at Handelsblatt. We had an engaging conversation about the current challenges facing society, the economy and the insurance sector in Germany. I believe that trust is the fuel that keeps us moving forward. It is the basis for driving innovation and progress with bold decisions. Yet, according to the Edelman Trust Barometer, 6 out of 10 people confirm that mistrust has become normal in Germany. This is very concerning, and also comes at a time when we face energy supply shortages and the worst inflation rates in 40 years ‚Äì a great strain is placed on many people.  And yet, we cannot expect government to solve all problems. Societies are more stable when they can count on business to deliver as promised. Sustainable business models help earn social trust.¬†At Allianz, this means looking beyond just corporate success ‚Äì organizational health is just as important in the long term as financial results are in the short term. Our strong customer focus and engaging talented employees all over the globe is crucial. That‚Äôs why, even in a very turbulent environment, we continue to be the world's most trusted insurance company across all stakeholders. A key measure of investment performance is how we help normalize trust.  Markets and societies are based on trust. Companies and politicians must come together to deliver concrete, tangible results, not just numbers and slogans. We must focus on solutions not division, expertise not superficiality, and action not promises.  hashtag#DemocraciesDeliver

Permitting is one of the challenges we in the wind industry have been facing. It can take up to a decade to approve wind projects ‚Äì much too slow if we‚Äôre going to meet the EU‚Äôs very ambitious and important target of ramping up wind energy to 510 GW by 2030, up from today‚Äôs 190 GW. Speeding up permitting is therefore essential. This week, the European Commission took an important step in the right direction: not only for the wind industry, but for Europe‚Äôs sustainable future and energy security. The Commission‚Äôs proposal under the leadership of President Ursula von der Leyen will bring relief to an industry that is encountering many hurdles in the current geopolitical and economic crisis. We at Siemens Gamesa are in full support of the proposal, because it will help accelerate the transition to a greener energy system. And it can give us the momentum we need to solve the energy crisis.Those who act swiftly, with resolve and determination, are the ones who will shape the future.  https://lnkd.in/d3gEYUnR  hashtag#OffshoreWind hashtag#OnshoreWind hashtag#EnergyCrisis hashtag#EnergyIndependence hashtag#EnergySecurity hashtag#EnergyTransition hashtag#EnergyPolicy hashtag#GreenEnergy hashtag#RenewableEnergy hashtag#COP27
