Our third quarter results, published today, make an important fact very clear: customers are asking for support and solutions to navigate the harsh realities of today. And we are delivering what they need.  This simple formula has resulted in excellent performance in our revenues, operating profit and net income that places our full-year outlook well within reach. And our balance sheet and our capital management capabilities allow Allianz to stand before a changing economic landscape with confidence.  Behind this outcome is Allianz‚Äôs strong state of corporate health, which is the foundation of financial and operational success. Our performance in areas such as customer net promoter scores, brand health, employee engagement, sustainability ratings and stakeholder trust represent non-financial measures of success that also translate reliably into competitive and financial advantage over time. Here are underlying fundamentals that matter: ‚û° Our Group customer dNPS results, which measure our customers‚Äô likelihood to recommend us to others and are linked to better business outcomes, overachieved our company targets this year.  ‚û° Allianz‚Äôs global brand is again the highest-ranked insurance brand in the world according to Interbrand, and the 11th fastest growing brand of all sectors; today our Allianz brand is worth more than $18 billion, having increased by more than $3.5 billion in the past year alone.  ‚û° A healthy and engaged workforce is among the most powerful competitive advantages that our company can have. Our recent annual Allianz Engagement Survey confirmed this conviction with feedback from more than 112,000 colleagues across the world. We achieved our best results to date, with our industry-leading scores on IMIX (Inclusive Meritocracy) and WWI+ (Work Well) indices at an all-time high.  ‚û° The Dow Jones Sustainability Index again recognized us as a sustainable insurer with a very strong 89/100 rating amid a strengthening competitive set and ever higher standards. All of these factors reflect an overall strong state of stakeholder trust, which is earned every day by our hard-working Allianz colleagues. As we celebrate the earnings results announced today and look ahead to achieving our operating target by year end, it will be how we work as a team, how we serve our customers, and how we invest in our people that will determine our success.  More information on our Q3 results can be found here: https://lnkd.in/eb6aJt8Nhashtag#AllianzFinancialResults hashtag#FinancialResults hashtag#Q32022 hashtag#Q3Results

Rituals embed culture. One ritual at Nagarro is our leadership conflux (conflux: Latin for¬†‚Äúwhere rivers merge‚Äù).¬†The conflux has no theme, no topics, no working sessions, no breakout groups, no team-building exercises, no target-setting, not even any opening or closing speeches. The conflux gives everyone 10 minutes to speak to the group, whenever they want, on any subject at all. Some people even recite poetry or do some standup. Just humans being humans. The only hard rule is the 10 minutes.The participants come from all over the world and may be meeting after a year or more. Some may even be all-new, perhaps having joined us via an acquisition.¬†So you may think the conflux might be erratic, arbitrary and directionless. It is none of that. It flows like a poem. The speakers riff off what went before, they adapt in real-time, and patterns emerge. There is showmanship but also honesty - with many acknowledging their vulnerabilities and frustrations. By the time the conflux winds down, there‚Äôs a feeling that nothing important has been left unsaid. We leave energized and each one has their own takeaways.Why this conflux format? In a regular meetup, alpha personalities may drown out other voices. Even the choice of topics to be discussed may become a power play. So we invented this simple format eight years ago and have watched it work like a charm ever since. Company politics is like a termite infestation. It is best avoided.In fact, the real business of the conflux is at the breakfasts, the lunches, the coffee breaks, the dinners and long parties afterwards.¬†This year, I went to bed at 3 am, 4 am and 5 am on the three dinner nights.¬†Somewhere in between the drinks, the bad singing and the poor jokes, we had been making good friends.Since 2019, we have expanded our leadership conflux with the participants of the rotating Glass Window diversity program. This year, we went further and live-streamed the entire event, making it available to everyone in the company. Several thousand Nagarrians tuned in live, which may be a first for a (near-)billion dollar company.

To mitigate climate change, we must join forces and speed up the transition. As a member of the World Economic Forum‚Äôs Alliance of CEO Climate Leaders, I endorse the open letter that we have shared for world leaders at hashtag#COP27 ‚Äì aiming to foster cooperation and shared responsibility between the private and public sectors. Business needs to work side-by-side with government to deliver bold climate action, and is already doing so effectively in many cases. We encourage all business leaders to halve global emissions by 2030 and reach net zero by 2050. At Allianz, we are driving that change. We will limit our greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2030. And as a founding member of the Net-Zero Asset Owner Alliance (NZAOA), we are committed to transitioning investment portfolios to net-zero emissions by 2050. Accelerating the transition to net zero also requires cooperation between developed and developing countries. The good news is that the capital to fund that transition is available. Blended finance is an innovative way to leverage capital at scale for climate solution investment in emerging markets. Learn more about this by listening to a replay of the virtual blended finance event hosted by hashtag#Allianz on October 5, 2022, with the NZAOA, including a panel discussion with G√ºnther Thallinger, Allianz SE Board member and chair of the NZAOA: https://lnkd.in/dmWBxhHa hashtag#AllianzOnClimate hashtag#ActOnClimate

We are excited to share that Dr. S Shankar Sastry has taken charge as the Founding Chancellor of Plaksha University. He is a global academic leader whose vision of technology has touched several fields of engineering. He steps into this position with the experience, ingenuity and strength needed to lead Plaksha on its path of excellence.Prior to this, he was the Dean of Engineering of the University of California, Berkeley, for over a decade (2007-2019) and is currently the Thomas Siebel Distinguished Professor of Computer Science at the University. I always appreciate my exchanges with colleagues as a source of feedback and inspiration. Net-zero portfolios for asset owners are more necessary than ever. In a world facing much uncertainty and an ongoing war in Europe, it is perhaps human nature to focus on the next 10 days, or the next 10 minutes, instead of thinking about the next 10 years. But we must consider both short and long-term issues. Our future depends on the action we take now.  I recently joined Christiana Figueres, founder of Global Optimism and Emmanuel Faber, Chair of International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) for an insightful discussion on ‚ÄòRethinking ESG and Sustainability Goals‚Äô at the United Nations Environment Programme Finance Initiative (UNEP FI) Roundtable. We addressed both the opportunities and challenges that asset owners and financial institutions face when working toward a net zero economy. At hashtag#Allianz, we are leading the charge with the Net-Zero Asset Owner Alliance. Members of the alliance must adhere to short-term targets for 2025, progress is clearly measured, and frameworks for target setting and incentivization are carefully assessed. Asset owners have the ultimate responsibility to ensure asset allocation is done in a way that supports the race toward net zero. Despite challenges that may arise for some financial actors, such as regulatory risk, political agendas, and commitment of resources ‚Äì we must stay the course and stick to science-based targets. The time for talking is over. Now, more than ever, we need to take climate action. Watch our full panel here: https://lnkd.in/eCQpb9Mphashtag#ActOnClimate hashtag#ESG hashtag#SustainableFinance

Today is Mental Health Day. If you are suffering from hashtag#mentalhealth issues, remember that you are not alone. Rather, mental health issues are very common. Maybe that will help you a bit - the knowledge that there is nothing unusual about your issues. This knowledge definitely helps me.I have had my years of depression and still remain faintly bipolar. I still wake up many mornings either somewhat depressed or slightly manic. That mood often lasts the entire day, or at least the management of the mood lasts the entire day.Over the years, I have discovered the five simple factors can trigger depression in me: sleep (too little), alcohol (too much), exercise (too little), water (too little) and food (too much). While the factors appear trivial, the depression which they create is heavy and painful. But it helps to know that this depression is not "real" in the sense that some more sleep or some more exercise will fix it.External mechanisms can also trigger depressive moods in me: 1) Being in a situation where I helplessly wait for someone else to make a decision that will affect me a lot. 2) Having some important and unpleasant chunk of work due some time later, not so soon that I have to get working on it but soon enough that it starts to eat me up with worry. 3) And of course, one gets depressed if one sees a loved one struggling in some way.This categorization of issues works for me. It helps me look at my mood rationally and understand what is driving it. I am not an expert on this topic, nor do I want to hold this approach out as a solution. Rather, I'm sharing this with the POV that if we talk about how we deal with our mental health issues, it will help remove the unnecessary and silly taboo that is still associated with them.

In reality, it is even more impressive than I had imagined - the start-up nation Israel.  On our innovation trip, my colleagues of the management board Jean-Jacques Henchoz Wilm Langenbach Christopher Lohmann Edgar Puls Caroline Schlienkamp Jan Wicke and I was given the chance to dive into a unique ecosystem with such a high density of start-ups. We were able to discuss business models of many relevant start-ups in the cyber, internet of things and insuretechs areas ‚Äì all of which are strategic for the Talanx Group. We also learned more about the development of our investments in Resec and Planck.  What is Israel's recipe for this impressive start-up scene? I am convinced that their unique culture is one of the success factors for the start-up-scene in Israel. The mix of tradition, a special geopolitical environment and an incredible will create powerful energy for innovation. Moreover, Israel educates young people in strategic fields that are relevant for start-ups: solution-orientated and outside-the-box-thinking, for example. It confirms my thesis: Culture eats strategy for breakfast.  For us at Talanx HDI Group this means: a culture based on trust combined with our purpose ‚Äútogether we take care of the unexpected and foster entrepreneurship‚Äù creates an environment for growth. The values of collaboration, engagement and transparency are brought to life in Israel. Let us further anchor these values in our company. Winter is coming to the Northern Hemisphere and an economic chill is blowing. Soaring energy costs are fueling inflation and putting significant financial pressure on households around the globe. And according to the just-released Fall Global Economic Outlook by Ludovic Subran and the Allianz Research team, inflation is expected to remain elevated into 2023.  Today‚Äôs challenging economic situation calls for new tools and innovative thinking by governments and businesses alike. One perspective I found to be particularly innovative, can be found in the recent Allianz Research article on averting a ‚ÄòGasmageddon‚Äô. This is the idea of introducing a new ‚Äúenergy money‚Äù benefit whereby households make payments to an ‚Äúenergy savings account‚Äù in which the amounts are partially saved and then topped up by the state. This would encourage a reduction in energy usage and help support the build-up of financial reserves ‚Äì particularly important for lower and middle-income households who are most feeling the brunt of inflation.  Particularly in times of rising economic and political instability, business as usual is not the answer. Swift and forward-looking action by both the private sector and policymakers alike is needed. By working together, we can create innovative solutions that transcend short-term thinking, help grow the middle class, and stabilize democracies around the globe. You can find the full Economic Outlook report, and other relevant publications from the Economic Research team, here: https://lnkd.in/enepzhMbhashtag#DemocraciesDeliver

The global wind industry was founded in Europe and is a strategic industry that is a crucial part of the hashtag#GreenEnergy transition. It is high time the wind industry be viewed and treated as the strategic industry it is. Offshore wind has a clearly defined role to play in decarbonizing Europe and securing our energy supplies ‚Äì and at Siemens Gamesa, we‚Äôre ready to unlock the full potential of this renewable energy source: Since building the first hashtag#OffshoreWind plant in 1991, we‚Äôve led the industry by supplying a large portion of Europe‚Äôs hashtag#WindEnergy. We stand ready to invest in this vital area. And, with strong government support behind us, we‚Äôve been able to realize some of offshore wind‚Äôs vast potential while lowering costs. Yet, as I stated yesterday at the North Seas Energy Cooperation Ministerial Meeting in Dublin, we need further support, in the form of: ‚Äãüîπ Transparency regarding market volumes.üîπ A streamlined and accelerated permitting process.üîπ A level playing field for competition outside Europe.üîπ Trade agreements for green energy transition technology at the EU level.üîπ Additional investments in R&D, value creation, grid infrastructure, port extensions and vessel availability.Ultimately, we must ensure that these changes materialize in time to guarantee a greener, cleaner, more secure future. We can realize the full potential of wind, but only if we work together. Watch the recording of the North Seas Energy Cooperation Ministerial Meeting in Dublin here: https://lnkd.in/eH56XX4P  hashtag#EnergyIndependence hashtag#ClimateEmergency

Sport is more than just a pastime. It is a powerful unifying force for peace. Even in competition, sport teaches us unity, patience and respect. It also forces us out of our comfort zones and makes us question our norms. I am proud that Allianz has sponsored the European Championships Munich 2022, the biggest multi-sport event in Germany since the 1972 Summer Olympics. This year‚Äôs event that ended on Sunday was particularly meaningful on several levels. Taking place in our home base of Munich, the Championship exhibitions paid moving tribute to history while also looking to the future. The venue itself served as a model for making large sporting events more sustainable. Organizers took extra steps to reduce the environmental impact by repurposing existing facilities at the Olympic Park, offering carbon-neutral transport and mobility options, and minimizing litter and waste.  Behind the scenes, we also supported the Young Leaders Forum, a group of engaged individuals aged 20-30 who are working to shape the future of sport. This included a Hackathon to innovate ways to inspire the next generation into sport ‚Äì the mission of our MoveNow program. I look forward to seeing these ideas come to life.  As the Worldwide Insurance Partner of the Olympic and Paralympic Movements since 2018, we are proud to play a role in contributing to a better tomorrow through the power of sport.  Learn more about the Championships and how hashtag#Allianz supports the world of sports. https://lnkd.in/e4cavZpx  hashtag#Munich2022 hashtag#backtotheroofs

J√ºrgen Lawrenz, who is standing next to me here, is an employee representative on the Supervisory Board of Allianz SE and the Chairman of our EU Works Council. The circular economy is crucial to achieving net zero goals, which is why Siemens Gamesa is committed to pioneering wind circularity. Located at the Kaskasi hashtag#OffshoreWind project in Germany, this turbine is a manifestation of our leadership and commitment to create a wind turbine by 2040 that is fully recyclable. Until now, the composite materials that make up wind turbine blades have made them difficult to recycle. Earlier this week, I had the honor of attending the 70th anniversary celebration of the German financial newspaper, die B√∂rsen-Zeitung, here in Munich. I was particularly pleased to accept this invitation because I am convinced of the importance of balanced, well researched, and fact-based journalism to build trust in an increasingly polarized world.  According to the Edelman Trust Barometer, only 51% of Germans have trust in media, and globally, 46% of people see media as a dividing force in society.¬†These views on media become even starker when seen through the lens of income, with those in the lower brackets less trustful of media in general.  Lower income citizens, particularly in Germany, are losing trust in their societal institutions overall compared to their higher income counterparts. This is a critical signal that we need to address. Under the current economic pressures that we now face in Germany, ensuring the well being of our lower income population -- without overly taxing our country‚Äôs potential to meet future challenges ‚Äì will prevent the internal divisions that currently undermine many democratic nations. Creative solutions for affordable housing, retirement security, and healthcare are required, and the private and public sectors must be willing to collaborate in new ways to deliver better outcomes for people.  A free press that respects the intelligence of the reader makes democratic institutions stronger. A free press is also the foundation of a fair and free market. Congratulations to the B√∂rsen-Zeitung on its anniversary. And, a thank you to the professionals in journalism who work hard to maintain such high standards of balance and integrity amid extraordinary pressure. ....hashtag#70BZ hashtag#DemocraciesDeliver hashtag#Allianz Mirjam P√ºtz Lutz Knappmann Stephan Winkelmeier

The world of work is changing. People are working flexibly from different places ‚Äì at home, in the office, in shared workspaces. But one consistent thing we must maintain is the importance we attach to the health of our workforce. At Allianz, we place great emphasis on ensuring our global workforce enjoys a working environment that promotes¬†mental and physical resilience, as well as motivation and engagement. Guidelines and wellness programs, and audits that assess the effectiveness of these programs, are important. But it‚Äôs also important to directly contribute to employee wellbeing, health, and motivation through workplace benefits like healthy food in canteens, fitness programs, check-up and counseling services, help with starting a family, and much more. Now we have a new Health Center at our headquarters in Munich, which mirrors some of the facilities already available at our operating units in Italy and Germany. It includes state of the art gym equipment, and also provides employees the opportunity to take part in yoga classes, nutrition and personal training sessions, including physiotherapy and health counseling services. And, because community connection is equally important to our health, there‚Äôs also a ‚ÄúTreeTopBar‚Äù space to simply meet up with colleagues on the terrace. ‚ÄúPrepare and prevent, don't repair and repent.‚Äù This is a phrase that rings true for promoting a healthy culture at Allianz. I greatly enjoyed getting a sneak preview of the new Health Center during my recent visit. After all, my fitness needs a boost too every now and then! ....hashtag#Allianz hashtag#FutureofWork hashtag#LetsCareForTomorrow

The US-German relationship matters to Allianz. It matters to our company, and it also matters to the world. This relationship is indispensable for defending democracy at home and abroad, promoting jobs and inclusive prosperity, and mitigating the climate change that threatens the entire world.That is why this week we are hosting the 2022 German-American Conference of Atlantik-Br√ºcke e.V. and the American Council on Germany at the Allianz Forum in Berlin. It is also why we have underwritten a survey, conducted by Edelman DxI, examining the state of trust in the US-German partnership. This survey highlights the role that our business and government sectors can play together in tackling the biggest issues that our world faces today.The current arc of crisis - threats to democracy, war, inflation, fears of recession, concerns about the climate - makes it imperative that the two spheres work closely together. It is the outcomes, the concrete improvements in people's lives, that make them advocate one form of government or another. It's about solutions that work. To this end, businesses and governments must join forces to inspire people with reasons to believe in free and open societies, especially as authoritarian regimes expand.There is much power to be unleashed in public-private cooperation across both nations, and there is more we can do together:- The private sector can help to deliver decarbonization outcomes by transforming their businesses in line with climate goals.- It takes two strong partners to face the fact that the rising costs of living are undermining the economic security of our middle classes and threaten our political stability -- and manage these pressures accordingly.- We must also join forces to prevent media from being a source of discord. This is a matter of an overarching culture of self-responsibility that also ensures that a lie has consequences for the person who knowingly tells it. Just as in business, where someone who does the wrong thing does not last long. This is a matter of holding leaders to account, and it's also a question of responsibly regulating social media.In building trust, we build a bridge. This is a bridge that connects our peoples. But, as we look forward, we also have to use the bridge of trust to connect our singular advantages on each side of the Atlantic to the benefit of the world.It is time for an invigorated German-American partnership.I encourage you to take a look at the full survey found here: https://bit.ly/3tBTxjA....hashtag#USA hashtag#Germany hashtag#business hashtag#climatechange

Today, we‚Äôre hosting our ‚ÄúUnlocking European Energy Security Webinar‚Äù at @SiemensGamesa where experts will discuss how we can reach energy independence by accelerating green hydrogen production in Europe. Russia's invasion of Ukraine has brought this issue into stark focus. Europe relies on large volumes of imported oil and gas from Russia, and it's this dependence that threatens to expose our governments, businesses, and communities to volatilities in supply and pricing.  Wind energy is needed to decarbonize and secure our electricity supply. Yet, it is also required to power the production of green hydrogen, a clean fuel for hard-to-electrify industries. Accelerating the production of renewable energy was already on the agenda before the invasion began. It‚Äôs now an imperative. How can we strengthen energy security in Europe? This was the main question of a panel discussion held in the framework of the International Charlemagne Prize of Aachen, Germany, today. hashtag#karlspreiss22In the face of the ongoing Ukraine conflict, the importance of energy security and a forward-looking energy policy is more important than ever before. As a result, our current priority is not only decarbonizing the economy through the promotion of renewables, but also strengthening energy security through the generation of competitive domestic renewable energy.The latest hashtag#REPowerEU proposals target the supply of 480GW of wind energy (from 191GW today) by 2030, as well as 15 million tons of renewable hydrogen, on top of the 5.6 million tons already planned by 2030.To deliver on these targets, we need a strong, resilient, innovative, and sustainable European wind industry. And coordinated European action will be key to achieving this. The wind industry has always delivered, and we are committed to doing so in the years to come. Leveraging on our long-standing record and experience, we know that renewables have the potential to enable a just transition.I was honored to address these issues today alongside Nicola Beer, Vice President of the European Parliament, Eila Kreivi, Chief Sustainable Finance Advisor der European Investment Bank, Marija Kolak, President and CEO & President of National Association of German Cooperative Banks and Klaus Ernst MP Bundestag, Chairman of the Committee on Economics of the BundestagBy working together, it is possible. hashtag#energysecurity hashtag#greentransition hashtag#windenergy

Yesterday was a historic day in the Danish port of Esbjerg as we were proud to welcome to our facility Mette Frederiksen, Prime Minister of Denmark, Ursula von der Leyen, President of the European Commission, Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, Alexander de Croo, Prime Minister of Belgium and Mark Rutte, Prime Minister of the Netherlands. There the Heads of State signed The Esbjerg Declaration that set Europe on ambitious new targets for Offshore wind and confirmed the North Sea as the Green Power Plant of Europe. The unprecedented pact that will see them work together to speed up Offshore deployment. They pledged to achieve 65 GW offshore by 2030 and 150 GW by 2050. This is about half of the EU¬¥s overall target of 300GW of Offshore wind by 2050. Additionally, the four countries‚Äô Ministers of Energy signed several bilateral declarations that cover ambitions on green hydrogen and the establishment of more energy islands in the North Sea.It was a pleasure to give the Ministers and the Commissioner a close up view of the technology that will drive Offshore wind. After I was able to give Robert Habeck, Vice Chancellor of Germany, Federal Minister for Economic Affairs and Climate Action,¬†Dan J√∏rgensen, Danish Minister of Climate, Energy and Utilities, Kadri Simson, European Commissioner for Energy, Rob Jetten, Dutch Minister for Climate and Energy Policy and Tinne Van der Straeten, Belgian Minister of Energy, a close up view of the energy revolution. They joined me on one of our 8MW nacelles in the port. Our manufacturing plants across the globe play an important role in helping to battle climate change. The North Sea is also an important area of economic activity and export hub, with this nacelle destined for Project Greater Changhua in Taiwan.hashtag#offshorewind hashtag#renewableenergy

How can we accelerate the buildout of offshore wind projects in the North Sea? Only by doing so, will we be able to scale wind projects sufficiently, invest in necessary R&D and create a healthy and resilient European wind industry. It was a pleasure to speak alongside √òrsted¬¥s Mads Nipper, Elia Group‚Äôs Chris Peeters and WindEurope¬¥s Giles Dickson and I look forward to working together to strengthen future of renewable energy. hashtag#renewableenergy hashtag#offshorewind hashtag#windenergy

If the world needed a wake-up call to the urgency of climate action, today's State of the Global Climate report from the World Meteorological Organization provides it.The report starkly points out the 'dismal litany of humanity‚Äôs failure to tackle climate disruption'. So 2021 won't be remembered as the year that we got a grip on the climate crisis, but instead a year that saw new records set for sea level rises, ocean heat, greenhouse gas concentrations, and ocean acidification.Author Professor Taalas and his colleagues make clear the danger we when they say, 'the global energy system is broken and bringing us ever closer to climate catastrophe. The war in Ukraine and its immediate effects on energy prices is yet another wake-up call.'So now is the time for everyone - all of us - to wake-up and act.We have to build an energy system that is sustainable and resilient. Not tomorrow, or next year, but today. We no longer have the luxury of time on our side if we are to keep the 1.5 Celsius target alive which is vital if we are to halt the worst impacts of the climate crisis on our societies, economies and communities.I lend my support and commitment to working together with customers, partners, investors, governments to delivering on the actions the WMO proposes to build a more sustainable future.As the report states, "every country, city and citizen, every financial institution, company and civil society organization has a role to play."So let's all wake-up, step-up, and act now.hashtag#climatecrisis hashtag#renewableenergy

Today, myself and other industry leaders sent an open letter calling upon the President of the European Commission and Heads of State and Government to take necessary steps to strengthen Europe‚Äôs energy security and resilience by accelerating the green transition. As the letter states, in a volatile and complex world, the leadership we need is one with a sustainable long-term vision, one that embraces change and can deliver a safer, healthier and more prosperous Europe. At the core of the current energy security and price crises sits an overdependence on volatile, imported fossil gas, oil and coal. The EU has the power to change this by steering away from new fossil fuel projects and phasing out dependence on Russian gas and coal, which combined only serve to lock in our future and create stranded assets. The time for action is now if we are to safeguard our shared future and continue our path towards the Paris Agreement‚Äôs 1.5¬∞C target. hashtag#greentransition hashtag#climatechange hashtag#renewableenergy

Sometimes, the big and scary milestones go unnoticed. A few days ago, the climate sensors on Mauna Loa on Hawaii measured a new record level of CO2 in our atmosphere, of more than 422 parts per million (ppm); during the summer months it‚Äôs expected to get even worse. This may not sound much, but it‚Äôs double what it was at the start of the industrial revolution. Some experts estimate that earth may now have reached the highest CO2 level in more than 4.2 million years.  hashtag#Climatechange is real, it‚Äôs driven by human activity, and if we want to contain its worst effects, the shift away from a carbon-powered global hashtag#economy has to happen faster than planned. Add the geopolitical dimension, where access to fossil fuels has become a political weapon supporting a very real war, and it‚Äôs clear: we cannot afford any further delays.  That‚Äôs why we at Allianz, are now accelerating the implementation of our hashtag#netzero strategy. We know, of course, that the transition from an energy system that has been powering our world for 150 years takes time. But we can speed up change if we look at this not just in terms of demand and supply, but also what risks we insure and how we invest on behalf of our insurance customers.  As our Sustainability Report shows, we have already achieved a significant reduction in greenhouse gas emissions per employee and a decrease of the carbon footprint of our proprietary investments.¬†However, we also know that change has to speed up. That‚Äôs why from January 1, 2023, we will neither invest in nor underwrite new single-site or standalone oil and selected gas projects, oil and gas activities related to the Arctic and the Antarctic, extra-heavy oil, and in the ultra-deep sea.  Then, from 2025, we will require a robust ‚Äònet-zero by 2050‚Äô commitment from the largest hydrocarbon producers, as a pre-condition for company-level insurance coverage and investments.  In our own operations, we are also speeding up our reduction path and plan to reach net-zero for all our operations as early as 2030, instead of 2050.¬†And we will have switched to 100 per cent renewable electricity as early as end of next year.  Systemic changes are needed. Our world is trying to take an economic system that evolved and operated for many generations, and completely rebuild it within just a few years. We need to make changes at all levels: demand and supply of energy, and according insurance and capital. At Allianz, we are¬†doing our part to help win the world‚Äôs¬†race to net-zero. Frankly, we have to, because our world has no alternative. Read more at https://bit.ly/3krjpcE....hashtag#climatechange hashtag#sustainability hashtag#netZero2050 hashtag#decarbonization hashtag#racetonetzero

This week, I‚Äôve been visiting some of our key manufacturing and research hubs in Spain and Portugal. I‚Äôve really enjoyed seeing the sites in action, and meeting some of the inspiring people who make Siemens Gamesa a leading innovator in the wind industry. My first stop was our remote control center and research and development headquarters based in Pamplona, Spain. The remote control center operates round the clock, monitoring 9,000 turbines in 450 wind farms around the world. It uses advanced digitalization techniques, making use of data such as blade inclination and wind speed to troubleshoot any faults and fix them remotely.¬†The center‚Äôs activities are essential to our global operations. I was impressed by the activity of our team of 30 colleagues who have worked onsite throughout the pandemic to keep our turbines functioning.  In addition, I visited our nacelle plant in √Ågreda, Spain. The site is one of our major export centers for nacelles and is also a key manufacturing hub for our new generation of Siemens Gamesa 5.X turbines. My visit ended with a trip to our onshore blade factory in Vagos, Portugal, today. The site is the largest of its kind in Europe and, much like our nacelle plant in √Ågreda, is a central export hub for international markets.  Throughout the week, I have been struck by the passion and technological expertise of the people at our sites, and their dedication to taking wind energy to the next level. It was a pleasure meeting all of you, and I look forward to continuing to work alongside you. hashtag#greentransition

I love town halls. I prefer them in person, but even virtually they allow me the pleasure of engaging directly with the colleagues who are closest to our customers, and with those who steer entire business processes to ensure that our customers‚Äô experience is simple and intuitive.  Last week, during a town hall with our Business Transformation team, I got to hear what was going well and what needs to be readjusted. Our discussion was honest, open and casual ‚Äì our custom at Allianz.  It is important to me that we make rapid progress with digital transformation in practice, not just in theory. We want to move away from an overwhelming suite of confusing products towards simpler offerings that customers actually want and understand.  We are well on our way. By making progress with our master product design, we will be able to reduce our offers from 1000 products worldwide in 2020 to about 150 in 2024.  This is the core of our ‚Äúsimplicity‚Äù approach: everything we do needs to be scalable. This means making sure that activities that do not add value to our customers are eliminated, and that we continue to create a satisfying experience for our customers in every respect. ....hashtag#business hashtag#team hashtag#digitaltransformation hashtag#productdesign hashtag#allianz hashtag#townhall hashtag#simplicity hashtag#businesstransformation hashtag#customerexperience

It's been a busy and productive week at @WindEurope2022. It has been enormously encouraging to meet so many customers, suppliers and peers from across our diverse and vibrant sector.  What has struck me is the clear determination that exists across our industry to ensure that wind is recognized as a major contributor to both the energy transition and strengthening global energy security.  While those of us in the industry recognize the huge potential of wind, and the major contribution it is already making to securing the net zero economy, we need to be clear-sighted about the challenges that lie ahead.  We cannot be complacent in thinking the arguments in favor of wind have been won.¬†¬†Nor can we ignore the turmoil in the supply chain that must be resolved if the industry is to achieve its ambitions.  We need be relentless in communicating the benefits of wind energy, both offshore and onshore, to policy-makers, politicians, communities, investors and businesses day-in day-out.¬†We need to act fast and lobby hard for the policies and frameworks that will unlock a healthy and sustainable wind sector, which is vital to building a greener and cleaner future.  Let's resolve to work together in partnership to: - Drive up the volume of permitted projects.- Simplify and standardize permitting processes at a national level.- Focus on grid expansion and the infrastructure needed for storage and renewable hydrogen - Reward the value of wind in auction design, recognizing its contribution to jobs, skills and innovation.  I have no doubt that by doing so we can drive the green energy transition.  hashtag#WindEurope2022 hashtag#greentransition hashtag#energysecurity

On the first day of the WindEurope annual event, we were honored to receive a visit from HM the King, Felipe VI, together with Spanish Minister for the Ecological Transition and Demographical Challenge and third VicePresident, Teresa Ribera, and the President of the Basque Country -Lehendakari-, I√±igo Urkullu, at our booth in the Exhibition Center in our hometown of Bilbao.  HM, the VP-Minister and the Lehendakari met members of the Siemens Gamesa Executive Committee and learned about our pioneering RecyclableBlade technology. The RecyclableBlade is an industry first, offering a sustainable solution to one of the industry's biggest sustainability challenges.¬†Until now the vast majority of wind turbine blades have been destined for landfills, but this blade can be broken down and its fibre glass mats used in other industries such as automotive or boat-building.  Siemens Gamesa is committed to sustainability and ambitious that not just our products but our own footprint are sustainable. We are very proud of our track record of leading on environmental issues. hashtag#WindEurope2022 hashtag#sustainability hashtag#technology

The war in Ukraine, geopolitical uncertainty, the rising cost of energy and commodities have all made energy security one of the defining issues of 2022. Alongside the present and real threat of climate changes, it is time for all of us in the renewables industry to step up to the challenges of today.  We know that wind energy is a cost-effective and efficient solution to drive down carbon emissions. We know that onshore and offshore wind energy can strengthen energy independence, reducing Europe‚Äôs dependency on imported fossil fuels which still accounts for 58% of its energy needs. We know that the renewables sector supports the green economy, generating new sources of growth, long-term job creation and the revitalization of communities. However, there are still roadblocks to fulfilling its potential. And with the huge problems we in the supply chain are facing, we need to be honest about the challenges we face in building a health and sustainable industry. So, I was pleased today to be able to address colleagues in the industry and the policy makers who determine the environment in which we work at the opening session of WindEurope¬¥s annual event in Bilbao today. We all have an interest in creating a resilient and sustainable industry in Europe. Doing so requires clear and determined steps forward, and I put forward a number of points for consideration.  Firstly, in Europe, we need to increase market volumes rapidly. To meet EU targets for 2030, we need to build 30 GW of new wind capacity every year, and yet last year we only built 11 GW. Unless we drive up the volume of permitted projects, we will place unsustainable cost pressure on manufacturers and suppliers.  Secondly, national targets have increased across the EU, which is great. But the lack of ambition around permitting stands in the way of those targets. Unless we simplify and standardize permitting processes at a national level we will fail to deliver on those targets.  Thirdly, we need to focus on infrastructure. We need to speed up the planning, permitting and building of grids as grid expansion is a prerequisite for more renewable energy. And we need to think ahead to the infrastructure required for storage and for renewable hydrogen to avoid future bottlenecks.  And finally, we need to rewarding the value of wind in auction design. To strengthen the global competitiveness of the European wind industry, we need to reward the value that it brings in terms of R&D, job and skills development, and innovative, sustainability solutions such as recyclable blades.  By working together, now is the time to address the challenges that stand in the way of a healthy and sustainable wind industry, that is so vital for building a secure, net zero global economy.  hashtag#WindEurope2022 hashtag#windenergy hashtag#energytransition

With every day that has passed since the unprovoked invasion of Ukraine, Allianz has deepened its resolve to serve our people -- and the world -- by shaping a more secure future based on the values of open and free societies. This means a future built on trust, not fear.  Our actions have reflected our approach: thoughtful, consequential, and people-first. From the outset, we have focused on the physical and psychological safety of our employees. I am pleased to share that all of our employees in the affected region are safe, and our support for them and their families is ongoing.  Allianz‚Äôs humanitarian response currently focuses on emergency support as well as the immediate and near-term needs of refugees, particularly those of children.  Our philanthropic efforts are complemented by a range of activities and donations led by our impressive employees. Their empathy and creativity is on display in myriad expressions of support designed to lessen the anguish of conflict: aid convoys, the collection of clothing and medicines, the accommodation of refugees in their own homes, and, last but not least, financial donations of extraordinary personal generosity.  As a company, we are not conducting new business in Russia. No new investment has been made in Russia or Belarus on behalf of policyholders since before the invasion, and our insurance businesses are decisively reducing exposure. Instead, we are seeing how to leverage our business capabilities to help people affected by the invasion, in Ukraine as well as in neighboring countries.  This is an unsettling moment in history, but we can draw strength from the examples of courage and resilience that we are witnessing every day. I hope that you are as motivated as I am by the character and the actions of the people of Allianz, which prove how steadfastly Allianz stands together: with each other, and for the ideals we share. ....hashtag#StandWithUkraine hashtag#GermanRedCross

Today is #saferinternetday. Last year, at the invitation of the Adenauer Foundation, I delivered the "Bonn Speech" on this topic and put forward five theses on discourse on the Internet. You can find the text - slightly updated - here. For me, one thing is clear: We need clear (legal) rules that govern the interaction between the state and platform operators. The latter may also apply something like "domiciliary rights," but transparency rules must apply here. Above all, however, one thing is important to me: The network is us. It fulfills our expectations (consciously or unconsciously). So it's also up to us to redefine our expectations. And from that, our actions.

"Inflation is like toothpaste," former German ‚ÄòBundesbank‚Äô President Karl Otto P√∂hl once said. "Once it's out of the tube, you can hardly get it back in. The best thing is not to squeeze the tube too hard."  Inflation can cripple entire societies, and when it hits:  Lower-income households suffer from rising prices, making the basic needs less affordable and worsening income inequality. For higher-income households, assets also lose value, and pension and retirement provisions earned over a lifetime gradually vanish from sight. For companies, serious planning becomes practically impossible, and important investments for the future are postponed or not made at all.  Financial market players take refuge in unproductive investments such as gold or real estate - instead of investing in young companies and new technologies. Only one party is pleased: highly indebted countries ‚Äì since their debts are also depreciating in value.  The announcements made yesterday by the Federal Reserve are good news for everyone. Central banks deserve all the support they can get in the fight against inflation, as this is a struggle for the long-term preservation of our prosperity.....hashtag#inflation hashtag#planning hashtag#future hashtag#income hashtag#pensions hashtag#retirement hashtag#investments hashtag#debt hashtag#interestrates hashtag#federalreserve hashtag#allianz

Across all our businesses, we continue to innovate with our customers and partners to help them transition to sustainable energy.¬†‚è¨ I‚Äôm sharing some of my thoughts on how we are accelerating our work and looking forward to hearing your thoughts too.

Im Rahmen einer Vorlesungsreihe an der TU M√ºnchen (Forschungsinstitut f√ºr Unternehmensf√ºhrung, Logistik und Produktion) habe ich heute mit einer Vorlesung zum Thema ‚ÄûTransformation eines Energietechnologie-Unternehmens im Zuge der Energiewende‚Äú teilgenommen.  Die hashtag#Energiewende ist eine weltweite Aufgabe, sie ist DIE Herausforderung der kommenden Jahre und Jahrzehnte. Im engeren Sinn geht es um die Abkehr von fossiler hin zu regenerativer Energieerzeugung ‚Äì hin zu alternativen, hybriden, klimaneutralen Technologien. Doch Energiewende ist weitaus mehr und betrifft die hashtag#Dekarbonisierung aller Sektoren unserer Wirtschaft: Industrie, Verkehr, Geb√§ude, Landwirtschaft. Mit anderen Worten: Energiewende geht die gesamte Gesellschaft an, diese und die nachfolgenden Generationen. Wir k√∂nnen sie nur dann erfolgreich vorantreiben, wenn alle gesellschaftlichen Kr√§fte mitmachen. Dazu brauchen wir vor allem Rahmenbedingungen, die zur Entfaltung dieser Kr√§fte f√ºhren.  Die Kraft von Siemens Energy ist zweifellos da, gesch√§tzt ein Sechstel der weltweiten Stromerzeugung basiert auf unseren Technologien. The world only works with trust ‚Äì as Francis Fukuyama once suggested in his 1995 study. Indeed, societies could not possibly function without trust. Trust relationships are not only morally desirable, but economically necessary. They promote well-being, productivity and prosperity. That‚Äôs why it is so highly commendable, that each year, Edelman prepares a Trust Barometer. It is the most global, longstanding, and comprehensive study of trust in institutions. It is the 22nd year of the study, and covers 28 countries. Understanding whom stakeholders trust ‚Äì and why ‚Äì offers powerful insight for building a stronger society. I'm excited to attend Richard Edelman‚Äòs presentation of the latest results tomorrow, January 18th at 4pm CET. On this occasion, we will also be joined by Becky Frankiewicz, Enrique Lores, Ajay Mathur, David Nabarro and Gillian Tett to discuss what these results mean for business, society, the workplace, and the condition of our global economic system. This conversation comes at a time particularly relevant to Allianz as we recently began shifting our focus on reputation toward a more ambitious aspiration to be "the trusted partner for growing and protecting our customers‚Äô assets." We are focusing on trust because we believe: ‚û°Ô∏è Trust is linked to clarity and confidence, which drives stakeholder decision-making.‚û°Ô∏è Trust is binary, which makes it more measurable than reputation.‚û°Ô∏è Trust directly supports the brand funnel and complements our Net Promoter Score‚Ñ¢.‚û°Ô∏è Trust offers insight on the issues that affect investor and employee perception, and that contextualize customer needs. I would be delighted if you would like to join me and follow this insightful discussion, register for the presentation and discussion here: https://bit.ly/3A3fMRq....hashtag#business hashtag#society hashtag#brand hashtag#trust hashtag#productivity World Economic Forum

The world‚Äôs first CO2-free glass production: a blueprint for green hashtag#steel and hashtag#cement from Germany. Today was about hashtag#energytransition in the making ‚Äì here in hashtag#Herzogenrath with our partners Saint-Gobain and hashtag#NorthRhineWestphalia.What is the story behind my visit today? Saint-Gobain wants to modernize its energy-intensive glass production and ‚Äì by 2026/27 ‚Äì gradually switch from natural gas to hashtag#hydrogen.We at Siemens Energy are preparing to supply electrolysis capacities of up to 50 MW, powered by nearby Energiepark Herzogenrath. Moreover, the heat (of up to 1,500¬∞C) generated during glass production can be used to hashtag#decarbonize the region‚Äôs heat supply.  This project can serve as a blueprint for the gradual decarbonization of hashtag#industry in Germany. If we manage to decarbonize glass production, we can succeed in producing green hashtag#cement and hashtag#steel .That is why we need a hashtag#hydrogen breakthrough ‚Äì now ‚Äì by creating a market in which green hydrogen pays off.This requires framework conditions which further expand hashtag#renewables and climate-neutral energy sources while promoting technological openness and swiftly enabling the development of a much-needed hydrogen infrastructure (using natural gas pipeline networks). We are grateful for the support of hashtag#NorthRhineWestphaliaand today‚Äôs visit by State Premier Hendrik W√ºst and Minister Prof. Dr. Andreas Pinkwart. Thanks to all our partners ‚Äì let‚Äôs keep up thegood work!Source photos: Saint-Gobain

As people and economies continue to adapt to the virus that grips our globe, we have been thinking about what the world of work at Allianz should look like to best support our people.üí° And, because we are active in more than 70 countries, we decided to create global standards for it.  Our WOW ‚Äì Ways of Working establishes global standards that take learnings from the pandemic, and turns them into real ways to support our employees.¬†At the core of this is more flexible working, adapting to individual needs, and allowing more time for dedicated learning. We expect this to lead to a more resilient organization, a powerful evolution of our corporate and work culture, and better outcomes for our customers and employees. Germany is a country of inventors, artists, engineers and scientists. But when it comes to entrepreneurial skills, other countries are far ahead. To improve this situation, Allianz is contributing to the Entrepreneurial Skills Program launched by Stifterverband, which is co-funded by Campus Founders and the Dieter Schwarz Stiftung.  The mission of this program is close to my heart: it selects universities with the best concepts for integrating entrepreneurship into the curriculum. Entrepreneurship coursework should be more than an optional offer to students, rather, it needs to be an integral part of their academic education. This is true no matter which subject they study -- from mathematical and scientific disciplines, to the humanities and the arts. The best concepts have now been selected for the 2022-2024 academic year. I am impressed by the results. üéØ My congratulations to the winning universities! ‚ÄúClimate policy is only about measurable results now‚Äù -- these are the words I wrote from Glasgow two weeks ago. The time for making proclamations is over.  It is important to be clear about what constitutes action. This week, at the United Nations Environment Programme Finance Initiative (UNEP FI) Leadership Council, I addressed what taking action means for the Asset Owner Alliance for Net-Zero (AOA): - Showing concrete, measurable emission reduction outcomes in the real economy. üè≠- Advocating for legislation that supports the net-zero transition. üìù- Providing a clear framework for how members will set targets, with our 2025 Target Setting Protocol. üéØ In order to make progress üöÄ , we also need to understand our pitfalls. So, what do we need to work on? - Sovereign wealth funds should not leave rebalancing to private asset owners, they also need to commit to intermediate targets. - We need to establish legislation to hinder private equity from purchasing de-listed assets.  These actions¬†will accelerate and support the decarbonization process¬†üåø. Tackling climate change is a marathon, not a sprint. This is the time to get started, and the AOA ‚Äì referred to as the ‚Äúgold standard‚Äù by UN Secretary General Ant√≥nio Guterres - is leading the way.  üåéüåèüåç ....hashtag#climatechange hashtag#decarbonization hashtag#ESG hashtag#sustainability hashtag#racetonetzero hashtag#climateprotection hashtag#allianz hashtag#financialIndustry

Last week I had a few eventful and busy days in Glasgow, Scotland, the host city for the COP26 climate conference. Im Januar dieses Jahres hatte ich einen Artikel f√ºr das World Economic Forum verfasst. Ich schrieb dar√ºber, wie #Technologien einen nachhaltigen Wirtschaftsaufschwung erm√∂glichen k√∂nnen. Seither ist viel passiert - sowohl die EU als auch die USA haben gr√ºne Konjunkturprogramme angek√ºndigt. Viele L√§nder haben Ziele zur Verringerung von CO2-Emissionen formuliert. Unternehmen wie Siemens ergreifen Ma√ünahmen, um ihre eigenen CO2-Emissionen zu reduzieren, und sie schlie√üen sich mit anderen Unternehmen wie der Alliance of CEO Climate Leaders zusammen. Aber das wird nicht ausreichen. Denn der Klimawandel versch√§rft sich, und der CO2-Aussto√ü nimmt weiter zu. Das aktuelle Treffen von Regierungsvertretern auf der Weltklimakonferenz #COP26 ist ein entscheidender Moment f√ºr die Welt. Wir haben bereits Technologien, die uns helfen, Emissionen zu senken. Und deshalb m√ºssen wir jetzt handeln ‚Äì gemeinsam und sofort. W√§hrend der Finanzkrise hatten wir schon einmal die historische Gelegenheit, den Klimawandel zu bek√§mpfen. Aber wir haben es vers√§umt, sie zu ergreifen. Wir haben nicht die Zeit, diesen Fehler noch einmal zu begehen.

Back in January, I wrote an article for the World Economic Forum about how #technology can enable a sustainable economic recovery. A lot has happened since then ‚Äì both the EU and the US have announced green stimulus programs. Many countries have announced carbon reduction targets. And businesses like Siemens are¬†taking steps to reduce their own carbon emissions¬†and joining together with other companies like the¬†Alliance of CEO Climate Leaders. But this won‚Äôt be enough;¬†climate change is intensifying, and¬†CO2 levels are still increasing. As government representatives meet at #COP26, this a critical moment for the world. We have the technologies to curb emissions, now we need to take collective and immediate action. During the financial crisis we had a unique opportunity to tackle climate change. But we failed to seize it. We don‚Äôt have the time to make the same mistake again.

The topic of artificial intelligence is often discussed with fear, especially in Germany. The central question is: Will it take away our jobs? Can it "replace" people?Deutsche Telekom has been dealing with this issue for a long time - and now we have dared to experiment: We have completed Beethoven's 10th Symphony with the help of an AI. We're celebrating the premiere on Saturday. You can watch it live on #dabeitv.The result of our experiment is not purely musical. It is also a technological one. An ethical one. It shows where AI currently stands. At the same time, it shows the limits of AI and therefore gives us courage. Because in my eyes, AI can help us on many levels. Our brain hasn't been updated in 50,000 years. With the help of AI, we are making leaps and bounds. #AI is not our adversary, but rather a good helper when used correctly. It can do a lot. But at the same time, it is nothing without humans. It does not replace us. It complements us. It expands our possibilities, just like many technologies before it, with which we have also learned to "deal civilly". I have written down some thoughts about our experiment and the questions it raises.PS. I think the 10th turned out really well. "Divine" it is not necessarily. And what is melody in it is actually from Beethoven and his fragment to the 10th.

Artificial Intelligence is sometimes talked about as if it were a new medical device. It isn‚Äôt. I see #AI and algorithms as the bonding link for better care. When we see it in this way, it becomes more than some elusive ‚Äúneural network‚Äù, or a virtual doctor alternative. Instead, we will be talking about actual improvements to care processes at different levels of complexity ‚Äì which culminate, for example, in individual risk prediction and personalized simulation of therapeutic measures using multidimensional datasets. #PrecisionMedicine #Healthcare

As governing bodies worldwide increasingly emphasize AI ethics, so does society expect more transparency on the impact AI-powered technology can have on their lives. To gain trust, we need to develop a new level of ‚Äúexplainablity‚Äù around #AI in #MedTech. By combining the raw computational power of AI with the experience and empathy of human healthcare professionals, we have an unprecedented opportunity to transform #CareDelivery.
